Room: "B-" since it was just average small complaints the bathroom light took over a minute to turn on, slight musty smell (which is common for the beach), and mold on the couch. We had one of the "best rooms" in the hotel yet there was no view of the ocean just of the fountains/pool area. Housekeeping: "A-" the room was cleaned everyday time did vary and the turndown service was a nice touch but not consistant. Grounds: "A+" the hotel grounds were some of the best we had seen in all of Playacar after visiting the nearby sister hotels. Food: "B" we realized what kind of food we would be getting after staying at other all inclusive hotels. There was always something to eat but we became bored with choices by the end of the week. Reservations to the specialty restaurants ;F since it took so much effort to make plans for dinner. We chose to eat there one night at the steakhouse and were sat beside the salad bar. We did request another table but we were told no with many empty tables out under the veranda. Service :A the hotel staff were all so kind and helpful each trying their best to accomodate our needs. The pool waiters were constantly walking around offering cocktails etc. GYM/SPA: D we were very dissapointed in the facilities and lack of treatments available. Beach; B unfortunately mother nature has destroyed most of the beach it was cleaned everyday but we felt that all of the chairs were right on top of eachother. There was no glass that we saw in the sand. It did become annoying later in the day to hear the constant sound of jet skis and the parasailing boats racing up and down the beach. If you turned right you could walk a long distance down the beach which was nice however very dirty with trash and debris all over the place. Pool : C the pool was very weird and small. The side with the pool bar was kind of dirty and the water was very shallow...it came up to my knees in some parts with paper cups and straws floating in the water. The other side of the pool was less crowded but we found entrance/exit tricky since there was only 1 ladder available. Maintenance: D although the hotel was clean there were some issues with broken tiles, worn paint on the exterior of the buildings, missing artwork, broken lights in the hallways, room service trays left in the hallway for days. After a week of staying at the Riu Palace we did enjoy our time but were dissapointed after spending over $5000 for a week away. There was an issue with our flight on the way home and we were forced to sit infront of the hotel from 11am to 7pm. Again, Manuel could not have been nicer check in on us but the front desk staff would not make a local call for us since we did not have a cell phone or access to our room. Again we had spent quit a bit of money during the week and tipped the same people upon check in. We felt that the lack of concern/help would keep us from going back.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful resort....wonderful time, with a twist!”
Reviews.Author: deezerd22
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Riu Palace Mexico March 17-21. It is a beautiful resort-the grounds are immaculate, and there is daily evidence of the hard work the grounds crew and housekeeping do. The whole resort is gorgeous, and while it's not big it's certainly impressive. Our room was comfortable, though the beds are hard, and very clean. The place, as mentioned in previous reviews, is noisy. Bring your earplugs. There is a secondary door past the bathroom into the room-use it. Things start up early around there, and some people are noisy at night, and you will hear them. Could be disruptive to a light sleeper! There have been many questions about the beach. Well, it does have some issues. Just in the four days we were there the beach changed drastically, to the point that yesterday morning the grounds crew was transplanting palm trees further away from the breaking waves. When we first went to the beach there was not a drop-off. When we left, there was a huge one, and it happened literally overnight. The beach is still very viable, but you can tell it's a struggle to keep it up. While we were there we ate at the buffet as well as two of the specialty restaurants, the Rodizio and the Gourmet. Of the two, I would recommend the Gourmet. The buffet was good, especially on seafood night, and there was a huge assortment of food. One thing that this resort excels in over others is the salad fixins'. They do a great job at both lunch and dinner providing a wide variety of greens and other items with which to make a salad. That hasn't been the case everywhere we've stayed. Overall the food was very good, and no one in our party got sick or had issues from anything other than overeating! One warning. Though it says explicitly on many websites "No Spring Breakers," we were inundated with them. And many were not great neighbors. There were several groups of kids, seemingly without parents, though we were told that they were lurking in the background somewhere (we saw a few who were more hungover than the kids!). Many of these kids were drinking huge amounts of alcohol, and paying the price. The behavior of many reflected very poorly on the group, and we were really waiting for something serious to happen to one of them (which we heard did happen the night we left). This put a damper on an otherwise wonderful long weekend at a beautiful resort that we would be happy to visit again someday.

Reviews.Title: “An Excellent All Inclusive Option”
Reviews.Author: DG330
Reviews.Content: I have recently returned from this excellent all inclusive resort hotel. I chose the hotel as I had stayed in several RIU Palace hotels in Europe and have always been very pleased with the standards. The RIU Palace Mexico did not disappoint. All areas were spotlessly clean and the bedroom was cleaned throughly everyday with a turndown service in the evening with fresh towels if required. The food was excellent with a wide variety and themed evenings in the buffet restaurant. The option to eat in the 4 A La Carte restaurants without limit was a huge bonus, especially as we stayed for 2 weeks. The only drawback was having to queue up on the morning that you wished to dine in the A La Carte to get a number as they tables were reserved on a first come first served basis. They tell you can book from 8.30am, however in reality numbers are given out from approx 8.00am. These restaurants were all wonderful,especially the Japanese and the Gourmet. There was never any problem having as many drinks as you wanted-including wine with lunch and dinner, a choice was given here and the bottle left on the table. The only area that was disappointing was the beach, unforntunately it has become very narrow and therefore became very crowded. That said just behind the beach front the hotel has sunbeds set in a beach like area amoung palm trees which extends back towards the pool area. There are even hammocks here.! This area was always quite with plenty of beds available for late risers plus the benefit of the sea breeze. I would have no hesitation in returning to the hotel and have already recommended it to friends. Another excellent offering from the RIU chain.

Reviews.Title: “Great Place, but beware of noise”
Reviews.Author: stormsteamboat
Reviews.Content: We just got back from the Riu Palace Mexico in Playa del Carmen. We stayed there from March 10-March 17th and we had 4 children with us between the ages of 13-18. The place is beautiful as all the reviews stated and the beach was the best part of this resort along with the food. The beach is probably one of the nicest around. Some of the neighboring beaches have not fully recovered from the hurricanes and some of them have poor beach areas. I would highly recommend this resort to anyone who wants to have a top beach as one of their priorities. We were always able to get beach chairs close to the beach. We were not impressed with the pools at this resort, but we knew that ahead of time by the reviews and that was not a big concern to us. If you are wanting large pools, you may want to reconsider this property. The other Riu resorts had larger pools and the Riu Palace Playacar had a great pool, but not that nice of a beach. I think many of these resorts with nice pools may not have the best beaches, at least that is what we have experienced. We stayed at the Iberostar Pariso Maya 1 1/2 years ago and they had amazing pools, the best we have ever seen, but the beaches weren't as nice as the Riu Palace Mexico beach. The food was also another huge plus, the best we have ever had. We only ate at the buffet, since we have been to other all-inclusive resorts and have never found the speciality restaurants to be any good, so we stayed away from them and were very pleased with the food and their incredible staff! The buffet changed every night to a different theme dinner which was great, plus they also had the other basic food, like mexican, salad bar etc. They also had a chocolate fondou bar every night with fresh fruit which our kids loved. The mini bars in the room were always stocked with water bottles, pop and corona beer and you could get more of any of these items at any time. Our children had the room service many times, but as many of the reviews stated there isn't a huge selection, but at least it was offered and the food was good enough. Our kids loved the disco across the street at the Riu Tequila and went there every night. The only complaint we had was the noise on one side of the building(the north facing building, next to the Wyndam resort). The band at the Wyndam played very very loud music everynight from 11:00-3:00 a.m. and our first rooms were on that side and miserable to sleep there, even with ear plugs. We asked to be moved the next day, but they couldn't move us for 2 days to the other side of the resort, so we waited until then. (We were told by the front desk that many people want to move from this area, so there is a large demand of moving rooms). They did move us to an inside garden room on the south side which was very nice, but on the ground level. They usually want $30.00 per person per night for these rooms, which we wouldn't pay for since we had such a large group with us and it would have been so expensive, but they finally agreed not to charge us. We had rooms 0056 and 0057 inside garden view and my sister in law had room 0032 which faced the other building not the garden view, but was away from the band. This place is still very loud overall, so just beaware of that ahead of time and maybe bring some ear plugs if you are a light sleeper. I would recommend the 2nd or 3rd floors since you have less people traveling the hallways in the morning and night hours, but I still think it could be loud due to the tile floors etc. If you are looking for a king bed you will not find it at this resort. They are 2 double beds(large double beds) pushed together, but there is the space between the 2 beds that make it hard to sleep like a true king bed. The beds are very hard, which all beds are in Mexico, but we requested the egg carton mattress pads which we finally got after 4 days( We were not very happy with the front desk servie on getting this done, since we asked for these the first night we checked in (since we had read the reviews and knew we would need them). We were very surprised that this resort had so much to offer, but couldn't even have a standard king bed. Every other resort we have stayed in had king beds, so this was one thing I wish they could change. Overall, I would recommend this property and I would stay there again, but I know more now that I could request which room I would prefer to stay in. Have fun!

Reviews.Title: “Riu Palace Mexico - AMAZING!!”
Reviews.Author: WisconsinLor
Reviews.Content: I chose the Riu Palace Mexico for my husband and I to get away for the first time without the kids. I originally asked a couple of travel agents about adults only resorts but they were priced out of our range. We saw maybe 4 kids at this resort the entire time we were there and they weren't bothersome. And we spent much less!! We have never done an all-inclusive resort before and I wanted us to have a great time so I researched all the hotels on the Riviera Maya. It is much less commercialized than Cancun. The comments from others on tripadvisor.com's website swayed me from my original destination - Riu Palace Riviera Maya. I'm grateful to the other members for their honesty and candid pictures as we have yet to have a better vacation other than our honeymoon. We were there from March 2-6. Upon deplaning at the airport, we were pulled aside by a man who looked like he was from customs and started asking us questions about our transportation, etc. First, we thought he was customs, then just a helpful airport employee, then discovered he worked for Royal Haciendas (time-share). We were suckered into his spiel but ended up with $110 American dollars, free breakfast, our $20 deposit back and a deep sea fishing excursion for the two of us. The breakfast was fabulous and the 90 minute presentation was nice, but out of our price range and they took no for an answer without much fuss. If you have the time, I would advise trying one of these. We only lost 2 hours of our vacation and got cash to spend and a free fishing excursion which was lots of fun! We rented a car and I was very happy about that since we like to do things on our own time without much planning. The maps from Avis were not very descriptive so beware. That was the single discouraging thing about our trip, although easily overcome. The staff at the Riu were very gracious and gave us a wonderful cocktail upon check-in. I requested a courtyard room and a mattress pad as recommended by other tripadvisor.com members. The beds were very comfortable with the pad and had no problems sleeping. The refrigerator in our room could have been colder but there was no knob to change the setting, so our beverages were cool but not ice cold like we like them to be. We requested it to be fixed but I think that is just the way the refrigerators are there. We solved it very easily - Go down to the endless bars there and get a cold Corona on tap!!! Besides, it gets you out of your room and in the sun! The courtyard view was wonderful and we could hear the band playing in the evening from our balcony. We didn't go to sleep until 12:30 am every night so the band playing too late was not a problem. They usually finished up at 11 pm and we would go down to the beach and sit in the hammocks and watch the full moon while hearing the waves crashing in. Spectacular! The beach was definitely better than the Riu Riviera Maya and I was very glad we chose this resort over that one. We had their buffet lunch once and I liked our lunch at Don Julian (the buffet lunch by the courtyard at our hotel) much better. The food was wonderful and there was something for every palate. The two restaurants down by the beach were not as good as the Don Julian buffet but for a quick bite, they were satisfactory. One note of advisory - if you're bringing children, there are Europeans that go topless on the beach. We had two different women that were topless everyday out there. One was more discreet and away from the main walking area, the other was right by the pool. We went to one dinner at the Brazilian restaurant at the Riu. The reservation process was easy. I went down at 7:55 am to the reservation ticket area, got a number and ate breakfast at the buffet. Then at 8:30, I went back and got seating for 6:30pm that night. There are only two seatings, 6:30 and 8:30 at the restaurants. After we were seated, they invited us to the soup/salad buffet and then brought out the different kinds of meat on skewers. They gave a moderate portion but would give more if you requested. I believe we had 5 different kinds of meat, all good except for the turkey breast (a little dry). Then they have a dessert buffet if you're still hungry. It was a fun experience but we chose to eat at the Don Julian the rest of the time and were able to eat as much as we wanted and had many different choices to choose from each day. The only criticism was all the restaurants need to work on the chocolate desserts. The desserts were dry and lacked flavor. But don't let that deter you. By the time you get to dessert, you're so full that it really doesn't matter. We ended up eating the yummy ice cream they had. It was about all we could fit in after eating the buffet! We are very active people when we go on vacation, so the water sports were essential for us to have access to and to make it better, they were included!!! We went sailing twice which was phenomenal if you know how to, boogie boarding once with the wonderful waves that were crashing in one day, and signed up for a Discover scuba diving trip with the hotel after an exciting introduction to scuba in the pool. When we read the fine print, it said not to do it if you had any problems with the ear. My husband was still on an antibiotic from an ear infection and we decided to cancel the trip which they graciously refunded the money. The next time we go, we plan to get certified. It was exciting. A little about Tulum - we went one morning before the heat of the day and drove our car. It was neat to see, but we were very glad to have our own transportation, I can't imagine being stuck there all day with a bus group. On our way back, we stopped at Hidden Worlds cenote and went snorkeling in a cave. It was one of the most incredible experiences we have ever had. I am claustrophobic and get freaked out by dark places, but our guide was so cool and so informative that I didn't even worry. His name is very long and he said for us to call him "the skinny guy". If you are able to do this, ask for him, he is very nice and we tipped him afterward. Don't miss an experience like this! Shopping in Playa del Carmen was lots of fun and I wish we had more time to do it. The shopping the furthest south on 5th street was high end, then got cheaper (less costly) the further north you went. Also, the shopping on 10th street (one street west), although less populated, was even cheaper because they don't get as much foot traffic. Two tips - never pay the price they ask, always haggle and do not pay with Mexican money. The American dollar rules and they are much more willing to drop the price since they can hang on to the money until the exchange rate is high and get more Mexican money for it. I got a bunch of American Express travelers cheques and when I went to cash them, they give you mexican pesos, even at the hotel (watch the exchange rate, it's different everywhere). The next time I go, I'm taking U.S. dollars! We went to the Riu Tequila one night and stopped in the disco that they kept announcing at our hotel every night. Our hotel was much more subdued and laid back and the night ended at 11:00pm but the Riu Tequila was a very young crowd, very rowdy and a lot of pretty drunk people everywhere. A constant party. My husband and I are 39 and we have three children, ages 3,7 and 9. We were commenting on how we didn't quite fit with the majority of older elite crowd of our hotel, but definitely didn't fit with the the Riu Tequila crowd. We liked the higher-end architecture and feel of our hotel and were very comfortable with all of the people we met there. Not one of the people we spoke with was uppity or unfriendly. Just not rowdy and obnoxious. Overall, we had an absolutely amazing vacation and I would highly advise it. Enjoy!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Amazing Service”
Reviews.Author: campgv
Reviews.Content: We just returned from the Riu and had a fantastic time. The resort is beautiful. It's by far the cleanest resort I've been to in Mexico. The staff (Manuel and Roy) are very nice, and make you feel at home. There was always someone asking us if we needed anything. The grounds are impeciable. We really enjoyed the pool and the beach. If you're looking for a ocean view resort this is not the place. The beach is far from the resort and the view is blocked by a grove of palm trees. We found the food awesome. The reservation system stinks. We ate at the Brazilian resturant, and it was good. The buffet is not a typical buffet. It's fantastic. Tons of fresh fruit, and a huge assortment of cheese, salads, desserts, and main dishes. Yes the beds are hard, but all beds in Mexico are. They are probably the least firm we've been on in Mexico. At least the beds are high off the ground, and actually on springs. My mother was injured, and they were extremely helpful. The new hotel director of the Aruba Riu (Richard) was very nice, and helpful with my mom. They also have a doctor on call from the hospital that was there in 5 minutes in the middle of the night. They were great. We really loved this resort and would love to return. Playa Del Carmen is awesome. One last thing, If your looking for quiet time around the pool, then don't go during Spring Break. We had lots of them and were definately having a great a time. They were harmles, and fun to watch. Oh the good ole' days.

Reviews.Title: “Love the Palace!”
Reviews.Author: roxiemoxie2110
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for a second time and they did not disappoint! We love this place. It is super-clean, the staff is friendly and courteous, food is fabulous, beach is good. The place is just beautiful. It's everything we want. Plenty of activities day and night if you choose to stay on the grounds. We will stay here next year as well. I highly recommend the Palace!

Reviews.Title: “We would stay here again!!”
Reviews.Author: Warmdestinations
Reviews.Content: We just returned from a week stay at the Riu Palace in Mexico. This was our first time in Mexico and at this resort. We truly loved the resort. The Great Points: The resort staff are very attentive and friendly. The grounds to the resort are absolutely beautiful. We also found all the guests very friendly, and made friends with many people we encountered. The doorman's name is Manuel and gives high-fives to everyone. The lobby bar makes the best drinks. Elsewhere (pool bar, beach bar, etc.) you will find the drinks a bit on the week side, but it only takes one request of an additional shot of liquor to make the drinks better. The food quality at the restaurants is good - not exceptional, but good. The Don Julian restaurant serves buffet style for all meals and there you will find a large variety of food to choose from. While buffets can get old, you have the option to make reservations at four different "sit-down" restaurants (for dinner only). We only dined at two; Sir Edward's Gourmet restaurant and La Bodega the brazilian restaurant. While the wait staff was very attentive, and the food good, the service was EXTREMELY slow by American standards. Be prepared for a minimum of 2 or 2 1/2 hour dinners at these restaurants. All of the rooms are a short distance to the pool, beach and restaurants. We stayed in a suite, and it was beautiful room. Strange, though, that we had a desk in the suite, but no chair in the room. When we reported a missing chair, we were told that the desks do not have chairs, but we were given one in response to our requests. And yes, the beds mattresses are hard, but after long days, we hardly noticed. (Request a mattress pad - it does help a bit.) Pillows are hard too. The pool area is very nice and was never very crowded, although we checked out the pools at the Riu sister resorts (Tequila and Yucatan) and found the pools there to be much larger than Riu Palace. Riu Tequila and Riu Yucatan were also MUCH more crowded that Riu Palace, so we opted to stay put at our pool at Riu Palace. (Yes, you can drift from Riu Tequila and Riu Yucatan at your leisure -- for meals, or pools, or other activities.) There are a variety of pool activities the Riu Palace staff entice the guests to participate in (e.g. water aerobics, water volleyball, bingo, rifle shooting, etc.) The beach was also great - more shade than I expected, as there are A LOT of palm trees throughout the beach. The shoreline is slightly difficult to walk due to the strong waves and the steep incline. The Turn-Offs: The Riu Palace website advertises that no Spring Breakers are allowed. We took the chance to take this trip in March (Spring Breakers month) and found there to be a good number of late high school/early college age students. Most were well behaved, however, the college kids who decided to do their beer bongs in the pool and we found this definitely NOT appropriate behavior for a resort of this caliber. One of the adult guests approached the kids about their inappropriate behavior, and utlimately, I do think the hotel staff became involved to clear up the group and the beer bong party. Overall, we would stay at this resort again.

Reviews.Title: “Very nice, outstanding service”
Reviews.Author: donahuer
Reviews.Content: Returned yesterday from a wonderful vacation at the RIU PALACE. It's behond me why anyone would have anything bad to say about this place. Although we are not experienced All Inclusive travelers we did talk to many of them during our stay and were assured that the RIU is very comparable, if not better than the others out there. The Good----SERVICE- A++++++(OUTSTANDING) BEACH - A++++ (SLIGHTLY CROWDED) FOOD - A++++ (I'M EASILY SATISFIED) ROOM - A+++ (COULD USE BATHROOM UPGRADE) GROUNDS-A+++++ (BEAUTIFUL,WE ALSO LOVED THE WONDERFUL LIGHTING AT NIGHT) The Not So Good--------MMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM.. I got the dreaded Mexican Bug.2 days of (I'm good oops I'm not so good) NOTE TO ALL TRAVELERS:Do not let anyone tell you that getting sick should not be a problem in Mexico.It's always possible and you need to take all precautions during your stay. I even brushed my teeth with bottled water, did not eat any salads and still somehow let that little bugger get in me.However, my wife did not get sick. I HAVE A REMEDY: Drink a liter of Coca Cola with lemon juice. IT REALLY WORKS I did not find out about this until I was already sick for two days but it worked almost instantly . Oh, at check in we requested a 3rd floor room (we had upgraded to courtyard when we booked,highly recommended) and were pleased to find out were given one of the very few ocean view rooms.THANK YOU RIU..

Reviews.Title: “The Real Deal”
Reviews.Author: jlewis19
Reviews.Content: My family stayed there March 2 - 9th. We are in our early 30's with two small children under 4. The Hotel itself is very grand, immpeccably maintained and very clean. The staff is excellent, very quick to get your drink orders both around the pool & bars, while at the beach they had a server that regularly came by with drinks and handed them out. In fact, the staff was unbelieveably welcoming - many times the staff played with my children and even put flowers in my daughters hair one morning during breakfast. While this resort is all-inclusive, tipping included, I have a recommendation for anyone about to stay here: If you TIP early, you will find yourself pampered and catered to through-out the rest of your stay - this is HIGHLY recommended...by me. Ok - now for some of the important tidbits. The reservation system for the restaurants needs to be changed, but with that said, we had our choice of any restaurant every time. However, we found the restuarant food to be very average...average at best actually. The Japanese restaurant Miyagi was terrible, the french place average - the brazilian place was pretty good, but nothing here really blows your socks off. We are from Connecticut and have excellent food everywhere, and this place did not compare. BUT I will say - the buffet place, Don Julian had a different theme (style of food) every night and we found this quite good, with a multitude of choices, not to mention excellent service (again those early tips help $10) For those travelling with small children - the kiddie pool wasn't designed all that well - instead of small steps they have a gradual walk-in which is incredibly slippery and dangerous - you need to be careful here. Also - they have a regimented eating time, so you really couldn't eat dinner until 6:30pm - this definitely can affect small children's schedules, but overall it wasn't a big deal. The Beach itself was fantastic, about 150 yards of walking through sand and palm trees, so you had your choice of shade or sun. There were many hammocks, and the volleyball and other activities were very fun. The water was great for boogie boarding, body surfing or just plain relaxing. All in all, I would recommend this hotel for its amazing service, beautifully maintained grounds, fantastic beach and close proximity to shopping and other water/adventure parks. I liked Xcaret about 10 min away by cab.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel with Some kinks”
Reviews.Author: JawsBoston
Reviews.Content: Stayed the week of 3/5 - 3/12/07. My wife and I booked through Apple tours from Boston. First the good. Hotel staff could not be more attentive and friendly. Cleaniless: everything is absolutely spotless; and immaculate. Even the beach is cleaned every day. The beach is excellent; lots of chairs, lounges for everyone. The water; perfect. Pool excellent. Bars: many; but the drinks are watered down; they will make them stronger if you ask. Food: could not be better, the buffets change each night and are first class; amazing. I cant say the same for the on site restaurants: We ate at the gourmet and the steak restaurant; both stink ! I mean it...they could not be worse..just awful food. Another issues: mattresses: this places has only has doulble beds! If your plans include making optimal use of a queen size bed..forget it. Nada. The mattresses and bed spings are fourth rate ! Night life: sparse. Most guests are in bed by 11pm and the bars are empty by 12. The disco across the street smells bad and needs rennovation. The gym is outdated by 20 years and has almost nothing. Walking distance to playa del carmen is 15minutes. Make sure you don't book a room next to the cheap hotel next door; the disco will keep you up all night.

Reviews.Title: “The Good and Not So Good”
Reviews.Author: Dianna
Reviews.Content: We were there February 21-March 1. Prior to this trip, we have stayed at the Iberostar Tucan 4 times which is located two hotels away from the RIU Palace and have had nothing but praise for the Tucan. The Tucan was booked this year, so we wanted to try the RIU Palace, the location is great and we knew the beach was good. The Good: Upon arrival the hotel is absolutely beautiful, the room is large with lots of drawers and closet space. The sunken living room is great, the rooms are very nice and comfortable. The food at the hotel is very good, I would say excellent. We had room service every morning and occasionally lunch in the afternoons that were good, try the club sandwich. A band plays on the stage on the patio at night, which is pretty good some nights and worth sitting down and enjoying a few drinks and/or dancing. The Not So Good: They have two double beds that make the king size bed, they even make them separately and push them together, which just doesn't work, it's two beds made separately and yes, we agree they are hard. Why not have a king-size bed, the Tucan has them? At check-in we were given the wrong room and walked in on another couple that were as surprised as we were, only we were wearing clothes. That's something that could happen I suppose, but it's never happened to us before. Be sure to close the metal safety lock inside your door so this doesn't happen to you. Our first night we walked down to the beach to find tons of chaise lounges at the beach, thought we would have no problem finding a chair. What we didn't know, was that the hotel next door (RIU Yucatan) and across the street (RIU Tequila) also uses the same chairs, so when we arrived at 10:00 a.m. on the beach our first morning the chairs were full. We did manage to get chairs, but it's an extremely crowded section of the beach. At the Palace they never took drink order and delivered drinks at the beach, why? We couldn't imagine why everyone had to make trips to and from the bars, the Tucan takes your order and delivers. As I've read from other reviews, our towels were also in very poor condition with tons of strings hanging from them and we occasionally encountered bugs in the bathroom. For us, we're in our 50s and it just wasn't a relaxing, fun vacation place we had hoped - it was pretty and nice. We didn't like the rules for dinner reservations, as everyone has complained about them, don't bother. As you've probably read, they only let you make them for that day and you have to be there at 8:00 a.m., they give you a number like at a deli and then at 8:30 they begin calling the numbers. The one reservation we got was for Sir Edwards and it was only half full, I thought it was a little stuffy and we left. Don't bother, just go to the buffet, it was always good and lots of variety, why put yourself through it. At the Tucan you can make your reservations for the entire week any time you want, when you arrive, any time for any night. One other thing I have to comment on, as it just amazed me. The men have to wear pants and sleeves at every restaurant for dinner, although the women were in shorts and tank tops at the buffet. The male servers wore a full tux, while the women servers wore short skirts with short sleeve blouse and black vest, they were cool and comfortable. Not sure why the male servers have to wear the full tux, with those jackets they looked very hot and this was February. We had a great time, but in the future we'll have to pass on the Palace.

Reviews.Title: “7 Days at the Riu Palace Mexico”
Reviews.Author: jwks
Reviews.Content: We stayed 7 days at the Riu and had a great time overall but just a few things I wanted to point out to try to help anyone considering a Riu vacation. Hotel and the grounds are excellent. Hotel is very loud due to the tile floors throughout, it might help to bring some earplugs. Beds are hard but just ask for a pad at check in. We did see some mold on our room couch but once again asked for a couch cover and it was put on in a few hours. Mini bar and fridge was always stocked. Towel animals on bed every night! Best drinks are in the lobby bar and order by brand. Cigar shop on lower level has some great cigars and the guy will make you a deal. Shows in Hotel are nothing to brag about. I would make sure you visit the Blue Parrott for the fire show. They do one at 11pm every night ladies drink free down there on Mondays and Thursday nights. Beach is pretty nice I found nothing to gripe about on the beach. (some women do go topless) Make sure to visit all the other Riu's around the area. The Tequila across the street has a Disco although small it can be a lot of fun. Food on the resort was pretty good but I could not give it more than 4 stars and that might be a stretch. I got sick on the last day from something I ate or drank but as they say it's bound to happend. We had a great time and this was our second Riu visit. We stayed at the Palace Las Americas in Cancun the last time and I would have to say they are pretty close in quaility. We went down to shop on 5th Ave. and just be carefull as we did hear some people got robbed in a small off the main area shop. About the hotel, the staff goes out of their way to make you feel good. The door guy always made us feel great by calling us by our names. Room service is quick but kinda plain. The reservation system as you have read is a pain but not a deal breaker. They have 2 types of rooms I would reccomend the garden view and they have 2 types of balconies. Ones you can walk out of and set down and see out of and some that are semi private wall that if you sit down, you see a wall. Make sure you ask what type it is. I got a nice massage on the beach and it was well worth it. Hot tubs are located at the spa (wich is operated by another company) and is not so hot. Pools are clean but I would not reccomend this resort to families with small kids. If it sounds like I disliked the trip, that is not true I just want to make you aware of some things you might encounter. If you don't sweat the small stuff and if you do find something you don't like just call the desk and ask them to take care of it. Also buying a phone card from the front desk for 20$ it will still cost you 3$ per call from you room or from the lobby phone. Had a great time overall and I would reccomend this Hotel to you if you don't sweat the little details.

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyed the experience”
Reviews.Author: Elena&Alex
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Riu Palace Mexico for nine days towards the end of February/07. It is a very well maintained property, consistent with its higher rating and price relative to most other Rius. It offers a great beach, a number of different bars, restaurants and very friendly service. However, for a truly five star rating it should address the following items: 1) Linen and towels are consistently stained. There were a number of occasions during our nine day stay when we had to request (and promptly received) replacement towels and linen. 2) The buffet restaurant was good. However, the menu did not change much from day to day during our stay. We had lunch at the nearby Riu Palace Riviera Maya a couple of times. Although both hotels are classified as "Palaces" within Riu's offering, Riviera Maya appeared to offer a more interesting food selection. Overall, we were very pleased with our experience, and would likely come back in the future.

Reviews.Title: “Service Unparalleled”
Reviews.Author: JDK/ABK
Reviews.Content: Most of the other travelers reviews that I've read seem to be right on target. The resort was immaculate, the food was very good and the service was the best we've seen. You could hardly finish a drink anywhere on the grounds without a new one being put right back in your hands. I agree with another traveler that it seems most people do not tip at all. This seemed odd to us based on the exceptional level of service. The staff was expedient, courteous and excellent overall. I would also recommend dropping a few extra dollars their way. They certainly deserve it. The reservation only restaraunts were good with the best being Miyagi's (Japanese) we ate their twice. Both the lunch and dinner buffet's were exceptional. I had fried grouper fajita's every day for lunch. The resort was large enough that one could actually get a beach chair at the pool or at least near the beach at any time of day. Our only slight complaint was the hardness of the bed. Who needs sleep anyway? I would recommend the palace for the 30 year old and up couples who are looking for more relaxation and quality than partying. Everyone there had a blast but this is not the spring break atmosphere that some younger singles seem to go after. One last negative which had nothing to do with the palace. We will not travel with Apple any longer. We've gone with Funjet in the past and they blow Apple away. The Apple reps at both the Airport and Resort were unavailable and basically incompetent and unorganized. We had one day messed up because of a botched reservation for a snorkeling trip thanks to our Apple rep. I could go on, but wont. I think you get the idea. We like to hit different destinations, but will definately be looking to the Riu resorts. Feel safe to book this one and have fun!

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful Vacation”
Reviews.Author: nickyweb
Reviews.Content: I recently returned from staying at the Riu resort Feb 17-24. I thought the resort itself and the area was fantastic. ROOM: We were three people (myself, sister and mother) staying in one room with two double beds. We we arrived the staff had also made up the pull out couch for us and although we didn't use it, it was a nice touch. The beds are a bit hard but we didn't feel the need to ask for a mattress pad. Rooms themselves are clean and ours had no "musty" smell. FOOD: I thought the food at the resort was great. We ate at the buffett everyday and didn't have one complaint and no one got sick. There is always a different theme everyday (Itallian, Mexican, Mediterranian, Oriental, etc). The service at the buffet was outstanding. Breakfast had everything you could think of eggs, pancakes, french toast, bacon, the list just goes on. For lunch we ate everyday at the El Patio near the beach, they have hot dogs, hamburgers, salads also had no complaints. BEACH: We spent every day at the beach. We were always able to find three chairs side by side. There is some beach erosion to the north of the resort but at the Riu itself the beach is fine. Lots of palm trees, no rocks in the water, beach was clean. We had a great time. SERVICE: I can't even start to tell you how much I appreciate everything they do. Always friendly and willing to help. My sister got sick on the third day, they sent up the doctor right away and made sure we had the proper medication delivered to our room. Our room was always made up fast during the day and turned down at night. Top notch service all the way. AREA: The resort is located in the Playacar area. Very clean, safe and nice to walk around. Saw lots of joggers thoughout the day. We also walked (20 mins) to the downtown Playa del Carmen to 5th avenue. It's a great place with lots of little shops, restaurants, bars. Also felt like a safe area to be in. All in all we had a great time at the Riu and would recommend anybody who wants a great relaxing vacation to go!

Reviews.Title: “wonderful week”
Reviews.Author: sunworshipperPoole
Reviews.Content: just returned from a wonderful sunfilled week. Please be reassured ( especially you brits) that this place will not disappoint. The hotel and grounds are beautiful and constantly Being attended to by an army of cleaners. They even polish the lamposts! Food generally good with variety at every sitting. The waiters work hard and are very attentive. We enjoyed eating in the outside restaurant as it was so warm in the evening. A warning to you all make sure you have comprehensive health insurance. I broke my toe and needed hospital attention (which was excellent) The bill was $950 Or £500 !! Enjoy your holiday !!

Reviews.Title: “Amazing!”
Reviews.Author: rachelle82
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I stayed at the Riu Palace Mexico back in October 2006. It is now February and I'm still thinking about how amazing that place is. I would highly recommend the resort to anyone looking for a relaxing, fun, and romantic vacation. While we were there we met a couple who came back for a 4th time . My boyfriend and I are envious of this couple and hope to make it back to the Palace for a 2nd visit! The service is top notch, so if you do have any concerns or if any issues come up it is nice to know that there is someone to help you! During our week long stay we visited all of the sister RIUs, but found the Palace Mexico to be better than all the rest. However, it was great to have the option of checking out the other RIUs. While my pictures from vacation are absolutely beautiful, it is even more breathtaking in person. Overall, no complaints... a wonderful place!

Reviews.Title: “A perfect honeymoon!!!”
Reviews.Author: cjsclark
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Rui Palace Mexico from Feb. 16th – Feb. 20th for our honeymoon. It was my first time to Playa and I loved it. In fact, I’m looking at booking another trip to take our kids to an Iberostar resort. Rooms – Our room was very clean with no musty smell. It was always spotless. The beds were hard but not enough that I woke up stiff or anything. We tipped housekeeping $5 a day and had towel animals every day and flowers at night. The ONLY bad thing is that we had a second floor room, 1113, facing the “gardens” and the band next door played every night from 11-2! We like to stay out late and party, but when we did go to bed at 1 or so, it felt like there was a band on our balcony! Food/Drink – The buffet was ok. After three days, I couldn’t handle it anymore so we went to Playa. There was a wide selection but it just seemed to taste all the same. We did eat at Sir Edward one night and found it to be the best dinner at the resort. Room service was also very good and I preferred to eat that for lunch instead of the buffet. I loved the margaritas though, and also had some great mixed drinks. We tipped the bartenders and never were without a drink! We could drink the wine, it just did not taste good to us. We also took our 32 oz. Bubba Kegs for the beach and never had a problem getting them filled. Beach/Pool – The beach and pool are the best part of this hotel. It was mild and cloudy (72 degrees) while we were there, so we never got in the pool. However, we could always find a lounger at the beach, and found it to be very quiet. We rented a jet ski ($55 a half hour) and loved looking at all the different hotels. Never had a problem with the towel cards, it was a very easy process. Staff/Overall Hotel – I found the staff to go out of there way to be VERY accommodating. The hotel was always clean and beautiful. This hotel was not meant for kids, there is nothing for them to do. In fact the median age was probably early 40’s. It was a beautiful hotel but now that I have stayed there, I could have just as much fun at the Yucatan next door, as it seemed more like the crowd that we like to be with. Playa – We went into Playa for the day. Had lunch at Senor Frogs, and dinner at the Big Lobster, both which were very good. The shopping was good and we had fun bartering with the shop people. I was amazed at how clean it was. We went for a walk down the beach there and had fun checking out all the different hotels.. I would go back in a minute… Cynthia

Reviews.Title: “Disregard the nitpicky reviews, Riu Palace Mexico is a great resort.”
Reviews.Author: LX3
Reviews.Content: My girlfriend and I (25 and 29 years old respectively) stayed at the Riu Palace Mexico from February 10-16. In short, the resort is one of the nicest resorts in the Playacar area and a great value for your money. We obsessively read these Tripadvisor reviews in the months/weeks leading up to our vacation and became a little bit concerned by some of the negative reviews. Now, let me preface this by saying that we are both well-traveled and have stayed in some of the nicest hotels in the world (e.g. we know the difference between a good place and a bad one), rest assured that, for the money, this is a very good one. Therefore, I can only conclude that the people who spent their vacation in a tropical paradise perturbed about the brain cell burning complexity of making dinner reservations (extremely user friendly) or the “under ripened fruit” at the buffet, were just the type of people that complain for sport and would probably have found fault in any resort. Now that that is off my chest, here is my summary of the place: Beach: Lots of sand, palm trees and beautiful crystal clear water. The location gives a nice view of Cozumel which shields the beach from the rough currents typically associated with the area. Because there is plenty of real estate, we never had a problem finding a few beach chairs, though the beaches do get crowded. What else can you ask for? Oh yeah, drinks. There is a beach bar just a short walk from the water and staff walking about with trays of beer and tropical drinks. If you are a Riu guest, you have the option at using the beach at the adjoining resort if you can’t find a space. We never did, but the option gives you a very large beach area to enjoy. Also, there are plenty of palm trees and shaded areas. IMPORTANT NOTE: The hurricanes that came through the area a few years ago caused significant erosion and really ravaged much of the coastline north of the Riu Palace Mexico. In fact, the resort just next door (the dreadful Wyndham Maya) had virtually no beach. Be very careful when choosing your resort if you are looking for nice beaches. We took the short walk to the Riu Palace Riviera Maya and found that the beach area was significantly lacking by comparison to the Riu Palace Mexico, though the resort was nearly identical otherwise. Food: Keep in mind that you are at an all-inclusive resort and a moderately priced one at that. That being said, the food was pretty good. The breakfast and dinner buffets were good with a great variety, though lunch was sub par. We went to two of the specialty restaurants, Sir Edwards (“French”) and La Bodega (Brazilian). Sir Edwards was mediocre to bad. I had a beef filet which I’m pretty sure was actually a hockey puck with gravy. In short, I wouldn’t bother. The Brazilian place was very good by any standard. And, as a general rule of self-preservation, I don’t eat Japanese food in Mexico, so I couldn’t tell you about that place. Now, I’ve heard a lot of complaining on this site about the reservation system. Basically, all you need to do is show up downstairs between 8:30AM and 10:00AM and tell the staff members where you would like to eat and at what time. It is very, very simple. You need to make reservations because the restaurants are a little smallish so if you have a strong preference for seating time or venue, get there on the early side. Bottom line, it’s not complex or confusing in any way imaginable. But you can decide for yourself if you think it is. Ask yourself these questions: 1. When ordering meats at the deli counter, do you often get confused, frustrated, angry, or simply forget why you are there? 2. Do you find bright lights or shiny objects irresistibly distracting? 3. Do you speak English, Spanish or any other language for that matter? If you answered NO to questions 1 and 2 and YES to question 3 then congratulations, you should have no problem making reservations for dinner at the Riu Palace Mexico! Staff: Outstanding. When you get there, Manuel, the doorman who seems to work 24 hours a day (I suspected he was a cyborg of some kind), will greet you warmly with a “welcome home” and probably a high five. This pretty much sums up the whole staff. They are very hard working, friendly, and good-natured. As you walk through the resort or down the halls you will always be greeted with an enthusiastic “Hola” from employees. If you are in your room for any period of time, you will undoubtedly receive a call or a friendly knock on the door from staff asking you if you need anything and if your stay is enjoyable. I know it’s all-inclusive, but if you can drop a couple bucks here or there for these people you should consider doing it when possible. They work too hard for the money they make ($200 per month on average). Area: The Riu Palace Mexico is located in a very nice and clean community called Playacar. It has a variety of other hotels, an outdoor shopping area, cabs etc. The area is much nicer and safer looking than a lot of the other surrounding areas. Just a 5-minute cab ride from the resort is 5th Avenue, the commercial center of Playa (a.k.a. tourist trap). Lots of shops and even more shop-employed people standing around out front shouting for you to come into their store. It was sort of disappointing but if you can get off the main street, you might find some local restaurants/bars on the water that are more subdued with a great view of the ocean. Pool: We're not pool people (hung out at the beach mostly) so we didn’t spend any time there. But it looked pretty nice with a swim up bar and plenty of space to lie around. Drinks: There are bars everywhere serving mixed drinks, beer wine etc. The only beer at the resort is Corona. Unless you ask, the drinks will be a little weak but they have no problem adding whatever you want upon request. Drop a buck here or there and they’d probably give you the bottle with a straw. Rooms: We had a junior suite and were very surprised at the size of the room. It was quite big with a sitting area, outside deck, stocked min-bar full of water, soda, beer, and bottles of liquor. It’s true though, the beds are stiff and a king sized bed is actually two fulls side-by-side. Not a big deal unless you want it to be. Clientele: The people at the resort were typically middle-aged and American. If you are looking for a party place or an opportunity to dust off your dormant keg standing skills, look elsewhere. But, if you want a relaxing time with a reserved and polite clientele, this is your place. I guess the demographics were about 50%-60% American. I found the guests to be surprisingly friendly, well mannered, and generally nice people. I hate nothing more than to see tourists hassle or be rude to resort employees that are making $7 per day. I saw none of that. In fact, there was actually a lot of conversation and friendly exchanges between guests and staff. Grounds: A lot nicer than I expected. The resort is meticulously landscaped and impeccably clean with large water fountains and a “piazza” where bands would play at night and cocktails were served outdoors. Both Riu Palaces have really beautiful and large grounds. Airport: We flew into the Cancun airport. It pretty much the worst airport I’ve been to. It took our bags over an hour to come through the carousel and when departing it took us an hour to get through the massive lines to check our bags. Figured I’d give a heads up, when you leave, get there at least 2 hours before your flight. Bottom Line: Beautiful resort, nice beach, pretty good food, nice location, great staff and an exceptional value. If you are looking for a relaxing vacation and don’t want to break the bank this is a great spot for you. If you want something very exclusive/high-end or a party oriented resort, this isn’t your place.

Reviews.Title: “Love it!!”
Reviews.Author: JoeNewYork
Reviews.Content: This was our second time staying at this hotel. We love the grounds, the service and the food at the the self serve buffet. I personally think this is the best all inclusive in Playa Del carmen. We ate once at Sir Edwards, one of three sitdown restaurants and it was it disaster. The soup was cold, the grouper was fishy tasting and everyone elses dinner arround our table was very much the same. We observed other tables arround us with similar comments. I suggested them to use the food that they serve in the buffet at the restaurant. I hope they listen because they served great food and a good selection. Everything else was positive. I would come come back anytime to this above average resort.

Reviews.Title: “Best week in history!!”
Reviews.Author: rockstaranddutchess
Reviews.Content: It's gonna be very hard to top this trip! We had an awesome time! The resort is very beautiful and you'll love it! Beach: One of the best we've ever seen! It is very large with tons of chairs available even if you get there in the afternoon. There was also hammocks. There was a couple of rocks on the left side of beach, but nothing to worry about. It seems like it IS the only decent beach in the area. (the beach at the Riu Palace Riviera Maya was horrible) Rooms: Very clean rooms. The in-room bar is usually stocked or just call room service - all free! The bed is about as comfortable as a rock. If thats a problem you may want to bring something soft??? Food/Drinks: Buffet restarant was exellent. You do have to dress for dinner. Men wear long pants only... Food is out of this world. Lobster, lamb, duck, a different theme every nite. Specialty restaurants: La Bodega- Nice, meat eaters delight- a 7 course dinner. Sir Edward- Very romantic dinner, good food. Piano bar was our favorite for drinks. Premium alcohol and service. Very high-class atmosphere. Not necessary to tip but their service was worthy and ocassionaly did. Try the Mojito-different. Staff: The staff is very polite, courteous, and very very attentive. You'll never have to wait for anything. There is always a seat everywhere you go. beach, lobby, etc.. Best service ever! You won't get this at the other Riu's near by. We did visit them and we wern't impressed. Don't go there!!!!! It's the Palace Mexico or nothing!!! Overall: Best week of our lives and we've been on alot of trips. Not for kids or singles. Would make an awesome honeymoon.

Reviews.Title: “Very little to complain about.”
Reviews.Author: AceAndGary
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Palace Mexico for a week in February this year. If you're the kind of person who can accept a few flaws in an overall wonderful resort, you will not be disappointed with the Palace. Yes, the beds are a bit hard. Yes, the buffet can get a little old after a few days. Then again, you could eat at the finest restaurant in Mexico for a few days and it would get old. The dinner menus at the buffet are different every day, so there is variety. We ate at 2 of the 'Restaurants,' the steakhouse and the Japanese one. Both were very good. The beach is nice. However, if you like to snorkel off your beach, you'll have to go elsewhere. You can get kayaks and sail boats there, so there are activities for those who don't want to sit on the beach for 8 hours. The pool was also nice. It's not chlorinated! And there's a swim-up bar. Plenty of umbrellas, plenty of waiters to bring you drinks, and plenty of quiet. I spent a lot of time there. Overall, the atmosphere of this place is a excellent. The staff is very nice. Some of them don't speak much english, but it wasn't much of a problem. I tried a little spanish on them and they were amused. Tip the guy who stocks your mini-bar and he'll be right up the next time you call. Note: The guests at this place tend to be on the older side. So if you're looking for hard bodies on the beach, you might want to try another place. It's a little on the expensive side, which is most likely the reason for this. Nonetheless, the other guests were generally very pleasant to be around.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing time at the Palace”
Reviews.Author: JumpingJax
Reviews.Content: We stayed at RIU Tequila for 1 day before transferring to RIU Palace Mexico from Feb 4-9. To sum it up, my boyfriend and I had an absolutely amazing time at the Palace!!! The grounds are spectacular. There is a beautiful fountain in the middle of the complex, and the gardens are always well maintained. The cleaning staff works around the clock to keep things clean, including areas that aren't heavily used. The tiles are starting to get worn out a bit, but that does add to the character of the resort. The pool is smaller than the ones at the surrounding RIUs. The RIU Palace Maya has the biggest and most spectacular pool, made of a larger borderless pool spilling out into a main pool. However, the pool was still nice; it had a swim up bar and always had room for swimming. On entering our room, we found a cute elephant towel animal. The room was bright and cheery, when compared with the one at RIU Tequila. The bed was slightly hard, but had a nice padding on top, and was much softer than the one at the Tequila. The bathroom was large and clean. I did find that the towels brought to the room were sometimes stained. Beside our closet was a mini bar that was well stocked on a daily basis and a liquor cabinet. The beach was fantastic. There is a lot more beach left compared with the other RIU Palace and the Playacar. Also, there was always a lounger available when we got to the beach in the late morning, compared to fighting for one at the Yucatan. There was an area where hammocks were hung, perfect for a lazy breezy afternoon. Near the beach was a bar and restaurant perfect for a convenient drink and snack. The food was very good for an all-inclusive. The french restaurant was quite tasty; the lamb was very juicy and tender. I liked the Brazilian restaurant best, where they served 7 different types of meat cut from a skewer. We also went to the japanese restaurant, but that could have been skipped. The buffet was changed every night for variety and was always presented in a grand fashion. On our last night, they grilled whole lobsters right in front of the guests. I almost liked the buffet better than the a-la-cart restaurants. There was more variety and the food was always good. As for activities, the Palace was never as rowdy as the other RIUs. The crowd at the other RIUs was younger, and more people participated in the activities. But this left for a very tranquil time at the Palace, which I liked anyways. We spent some time with our activities guy, Mickey, in salsa dancing, rifle shooting, and boccia ball. He did a great job. The service was always 5 stars. I felt so well taken care of. By the end of the week, I didn't want to leave. I recommend the RIU Palace Mexico. Great sun, service, food, and relaxation.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent service and immaculate grounds”
Reviews.Author: MNMNTraveller
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Riu for a week in January. The weather was just about perfect. It rained twice for a short period of time during our stay, but no day was a complete washout. We have been to Sandals, Couples, El Dorado and several other all inclusives, and without a doubt, this place had the best kept grounds and service of any place we have been (all-inclusive). The good: The resort was beautiful, and extremely well-maintained. The staff were wonderful as they literally ran to get you a drink when you were running low. Staff at the front desk and the doorman were very friendly and helpful. The live music in the courtyard every night was very relaxing and a pefect way to top off a long day in the sun. The location of the resort was also great. It is very close to shopping in Playa del Carmen, and the Playacar area feels very safe (I felt comfortable going out for a run on my own). The pool area was very quite and relaxing (with the exception of the last couple days when a John Deer sales convention arrived). The food was ok and probably better than most other all-inclusives (my husband who eats meat thought it was very good and was surprised that even the steak was great). The beer was good (corona and negro modelo) and always cold. Neither of us drink the hard stuff, so I can't comment on the mixed drinks. I drink wine and thought it was ok. Usually the wine at all inclusives is terrible. The rooms were very spacious, and kept clean with service twice each day (no bad smells and always had warm water). Room service was very prompt. The not so good: There is little to no insulation between rooms, and if you are a light sleeper you should bring ear plugs. We had a group of five European women on holiday in the room next to us and they woke us up several mornings at 3:00, 4:00, 5:00, etc talking and laughing loudly. Everything is tile so there is little to absorb sounds. Of course, a little consideration for others would go a long way toward alleviating the sound issues. Other reviews have mentioned the beds--we too experienced extremely hard beds. As with any all-inclusive, the food does get a little dull and repetitive after several days. We went into town a couple times for a little variety. Misc.: We spent a couple days over at the Riu Palace Riviera Maya (within 3-4 block walk of Riu Palace Mexico). It is very similar to the Mexico resort, and guests staying at either resort can go between them and use all of the facilities and eat any meal except dinner. The pool at the RM resort is very large and has a beautiful infinity pool to relax in. Because the RM has one large pool, it is much more busy than the pool at the Mexico. If you are looking for peace and quiet, I think the pool at the Mexico is more your style. The beach is much larger at the Mexico, but we found the beach at the RM more relaxing because part of it has been washed out, and consequenty there is not much foot traffic. At the Mexico there are several resorts along that stretch of beach and it was very, very busy. Don't get me wrong, you will never be without a lounge chair or a space to relax at the Mexico, but you will certainly not find a secluded place to lie by the ocean. There were probably fewer than 50 people at the RM beach. No, you cannot walk too far at that beach, but if all you want to do is watch the waves crash on the beach then it is great. Overall, we thought this was an absolutely wonderful vacation. We try not to go back to the same place twice but we may have to make an exception. Sandals usually charges twice the price for a week vacation and they could learn a few things from the way this place is run.

Reviews.Title: “You will have a wonderful time at this resort”
Reviews.Author: JAGChicago
Reviews.Content: My husband and I just returned from a week at the RIU. Let me extinguish any doubts you may have about this resort. It is absolutely fabulous. All members of the staff are friendly and very helpful. The food was excellent. The rooms were large (the beds are not that hard). The beach and pool were excellent. The palm-tree lined walk to the beach is something I will never forget. Even though you are not required to tip, we could not help but tip some of the staff members because they were so customer service oriented. I do not believe it is rude not to tip; as others have indicated, you simply have to use your best judgment. I would recommend bringing one or two dressier outfits. No one wore jeans to dinner. The women, in particular, dressed very nicely for dinner and for the evening entertainment. You will not regret staying at this resort.

Reviews.Title: “nice resort bad food”
Reviews.Author: ralph2761
Reviews.Content: The resort was very nice. The building is very beautiful. However the food was very bad, the fruits were always under ripened. The food is pretty much the same everyday except Wednesday, the food was very good that day. Infact I thought the food was so bland that we ate out four days out of seven.Me and my wife don't drink so can't comment on the booze. The A la carte restaurants were worse than the buffet and the steakhouse was the worst.steak waslike rubber so if you're thinking the Keg you're in trouble.The workers are excellent and the staff good too.This resort is a bit on the stuck up side so if you are here you are best to play at the Yucatan or the Tequilla and just come back to your place to sleep. To be honest I did not think this resort was worth the money. Last year we stayed at the Bahia Principle Tulum and I loved it. Found it had much better food and golf carts taking you from one resort to another also it was a lighter mood and people just seemed very happy there.As far as Mexican safety goes alot of it is common sense we went out alot, we rented a jeep and we went to alot of places were most would not go. I loved it I gave the children candies and chocolates and they loved it and appreciated it too. Going to a massive dance club and dancing with a mexican girl I would not advise or walking around full of gold and diamonds not too bright either. Keep in mind this country has the majority of its people living under the poverty level, many have nothing so bragging or showing off is not only stupid but it also rude. The majority of Mexicans are wonderful loving people and they work hard to get what they have. I loved Mexico and will gp again next year.

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous Grounds”
Reviews.Author: CarolSmu
Reviews.Content: We just returned from a weeks stay at the Palace Mexico to the bitter Chicago cold. I feel I was well satisfied with the food, service, and our room. Grounds: So well kept it was often difficult to get in a siesta with the patio open. There was always someone trimming, sweeping, etc. The fountains were outstandingly well kept and soothing with the doors open in the evening. Room: I loved the size of the room with the sunken seating area. It was actually larger than the more expensive Riu Palace Rivera Maya which was in walking distance. Since I have an extra firm mattress the beds were fine with me. I have slept in heavenly beds in other resorts and actually woke up sore due to the softness. Again, this may not be for everyone as they are very firm unlike the average. I have heard from others on tripadvisor you can order pads which have helped other guests. I felt the room temperature was very comfortable as we had the doors open to our third floor room all evening with a cool tropical breeze and great ceiling fan. The air kept the room cool during the hot afternoons. I only experienced the animal towels everyone spoke of one day, but we did get roses on our bed one morning. I actually witnessed our room service on his hands and knees scrubbing the tile with a brush and bucket. I guess he didn't have time to make a towel swan. The only odor I experienced was the cleaning solutions after the maid service. Pool: Average and very cold. It did feel good in the hot afternoon, but not child friendly or nice for an evening swim. I did witness several screaming youngsters when their parents attempted to take them in for a quick dip. People kept towels on the loungers all afternoon and rarely used them or the pool. This was very inconvienent as we often had to carry loungers or wait until closer to evening. Beach: There was an extensive change in the beach from our arrival to departure. We lost half of it towards the ends with some very massive waves. My husband actually helped the staff drag in palms from the ocean which staff madly worked at replanting. I was very grateful for the palms. There is PLENTY of sun even in the shade. Due to this loss seating did become a problem near our departure. There was also a much larger increase in guests toward week's end. Food: Above average. The selection at the buffet changed each evening so it was not repetative. I did go to Sir Edward one evening, but it was actually more enjoyable at the Buffet with a larger menu. They always had a Mexican section if you did not care for the main entrees. Of course as it was Mexico these items were always great. The chicken tamales were excellanto. I have had much tastier tropical drinks at other resorts, so that was my only disappointment. Activities: This was OK. You better pack dress clothes as jeans appear very rarely and very few women wore slacks at dinner. I did like the relaxing music and the fact the entertainment ended early as we enjoyed the quiet a few evenings. Some of the guests in the outer rooms complained of loud noise from the discos at the surrounding resorts. We did go to the RIU Tequila across the street for dancing and more late night life. This resort was more of a laid back night crowd. It was fun, but I was glad to get back to our place for the evening and the much more tranquil surroundings.

Reviews.Title: “Wedding at Riu Palace”
Reviews.Author: kathy78749
Reviews.Content: We held our wedding at the Riu Palace on January 19, 2007. In the end, it was beautiful, but it did come with some stressful situations. First off, I will start by saying that the Riu Palace has a lovely atmosphere -- the grounds are perfectly manicured. The interior of the palace is very grand, with large chandeliers, marble and winding staircases. The staff is very pleasant and accommodating, with the exception of the front desk, who is extremely disorganized. For anyone wanting to hold a wedding at Riu Palace Mexico, a few warnings. I wanted to have a beach wedding until I saw one performed a few days before mine was scheduled. There is very little space cleared out for this: the wedding I watched had beach goers literally surrounding the ceremony, with many wandering or standing in the "aisle." The outdoor massage hut was about 2 feet away from the ceremony, with someone being massaged in it. The Riu Palace staff started stacking chairs during the ceremony, making quite a lot of noise, which their wedding coordinator tried not-so-subtly to get them to stop. With that said, we had our wedding at the gazebo. It was still outdoors, but definitely more private and more organized. Except that a weed whacker began buzzing as our ceremony began and a family member had to go ask the coordinator if they could stop momentarily. An additional problem with the front desk was the purchasing of guest passes. For every person not staying at Riu Palace, I purchased a day pass so they could attend the wedding. The cost was $70 per person. I wrote a list of names out (3 times) for the front desk, who assured me that these guests would not be asked to pay for their passes by accident. Sure enough, they were and my guests paid -- despite telling the front desk that they were part of my wedding and the passes were already paid for. Another quick bit of advice: I sent one box of wedding decor to the Riu Palace that never arrived and still hasn't been returned or found to this day. Never ship anything there. Take it with you or use what they have (which is slim). Overall, I would go back to the Riu Palace for a vacation, but wouldn't advise anyone to hold their wedding there. The food was just fine for us (however several of my guests did have 24-hour stomach bugs during their stay). And I didn't have a problem with hard beds as mentioned in many TripAdvisor reviews. It's a lovely place . . .if all you're looking to do is kick back and relax.

Reviews.Title: “Liked it...but wouldn't go back!”
Reviews.Author: BCodes
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the Riu Palace, Mexico from Jan. 19th thru the 26th, and since we basically booked our trip thru research we gathered on Tripadvisor, we felt we owed an honest review. We used Tripavisor to help us book an AMAZING vacay a year and a half ago at Dreams in Puerto Vallarta. We trust the reviews on this site, it is a very helpful tool. You may spend thousands on your vacay...you should know excatly what you're getting. We are both in our early thirties, no kids. We're from upstate New York...regular married couple just looking to relax in Paradise. We're picky, but FAIR. Enjoy... THE HOTEL: The hotel itself is beautiful. Perfectly manicured and clean. Awesome location---walking distance to downtown...in the middle of it all! The staff was above average. From the folks at the front desk to the people who greet you inside the restaurants to the wait staff around the pool, everyone was very friendly. *Tipping is not necessary, but we brought a bunch of 1 dollar bills and tipped all week when we thought it was warranted. The staff works hard. They deserve a couple of bucks here and there. We were amazed at the people who didn't tip. Rude in our estimation...oh well. Our room was decent...the beds were hard but we like that. The one problem we had with our room was a horrible smell that eminated from the bathroom. It was sour. We had to burn incense daily to rid us of that horrible odor. We laugh about it now, but the "lighting of the incense" was like a daily ritual for us! It works...but we shouldn't have to do that on our "paradise vacation" DINING: The food was also above average. The buffet was GREAT for breakfast, luch, or dinner...you cannot go wrong. Fresh---good variety. Dinner at night was spotty. All inclusive restaurants are not really that great. The food is generally the same stuff you can get at the buffet, packaged a little differently. There are some exceptions... The restaurant that felt most like a "real" restaurant was "The Bodega" Brazillian steakhouse. Varied choices of skewered meats! Good stuff! The Japanese rest. was very good. Some "real" sushi was offered! Definitely a treat! On the other hand, we ate at El Patio and it was horrible. I understand that it's tough to keep bugs away when you have outside dining, but this was disgusting. Dead mosquitos EVERYWHERE. In the salad buffet, in our drinks, on our entrees. We were grossed out---we left. Stay away from this place for dinner. Unless you want to dine like the people do on Survivor! ;-) THE BEACH: This is our biggest complaint, and for the life of me, my wife and I can't understand why the hotel is laid out like it is. The pool area is great. But if you want to spend a week at a pool, you can go anywhere and save thousands of dollars. There are NO ocean front rooms in the hotel. We knew this going in, but we thought we'd at least be able to see the ocean from our room. No chance. The hotel is set way too far back and it's shaped like a horseshoe, so the only views are of other walls of the hotel or the fountains in the middle of the grounds! WHY???? I want to see the carribean....not fountains However, when we did venture down to the beach to enjoy the crystal blue waters...we found that endless palm trees by the beach made it feel more like a jungle, and less like a sandy piece of paradise. The beachfront was small and very crowded with people seemingly laying on top of one another. If you're looking for peaceful tranquility...you are not gonna get it here. Very disheartening. ...no views of the beach and misuse of their property were our two biggest complaints. IN SUMMATION: You're probably rolling your eyes thinking that we're waaay to picky...how could all of these previous reviews be so "amazing" and ours so "average". It's just our honest opinion...and we are picky travelers. But for 3 plus grand...you should be!!! Our Playa del Carmen experience was very average. We expected much more. ONE MORE THING: We did a day long excursion to Chichen Itza to view the ruins. Great trip albiet very looong! The best part was the bus ride through these tiny little Myan villages to get to Chichen Itza. We were amazed at how people lived....dirt poor in these little huts. Chickens and pigs room freely. Their 5 person huts the size of your bedroom......amazing. The children were so cute as they walked home from school. Makes you realize how good we have it, ya know?

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful place, but with significant maintenance problems”
Reviews.Author: lebelgo
Reviews.Content: This resort definitely has a lot of strong points, but had some significant maintenance and other issues which I felt were not appropriate given the prices they charge and their reputation here and as a 4* resort. I'll go through what I feel are their strong and weak points, and let the readers decide if they feel this resort is worth their hard-earned money. I paid $371/night (apparently a discount from $464) for a non-courtyard room, and am basing my overall satisfaction on the basis of this price. We stayed for 8 nights in the 2nd week of January. Strengths: (1) Beautiful lobby and grounds. The two Palace resorts are the only Riu resorts with indoor lobbies. The lobby is immaculate and stunning with a beautiful chandeleir, art work, woodwork, etc. The inner courtyard is likewise quite beautiful. (2) Gorgeous beach with ample seating available. The beach is 10X better than that of the substantially more expensive Royal Hideaway Playacar where my in-laws stayed. (3) Strict attention to room and common area cleanliness. (4) Tasty and quite varied buffets, often with rather expensive offerings such as lobster one night a week, carpaccio, and even prosciutto on a couple of mornings. (5) Always good water pressure and hot water for the showers, and large bathtubs (unlike the Royal Hideaway Playacar, though, the water isn't purified/safe to drink). (6) Consistently good service from wait and maid staff. There was absolutely no pressure to tip (service included). If you wanted Havana Club Anejo rum in your Mai-Tai, you only had to ask. Any tips given were discreetly taken. On our last night, we had a simple note with "Gracias" written on the envelope where we tipped the maids. The hard liquor selection was decent but limited (only one flavor of vodka, for instance). (7) I actually enjoyed most of the entertainment, especially the Mayan night. Sets/props were minimal to non-existent, and the choreography wasn't terribly innovative, but the dancers were talented and enthusiastic.
