For those of you reading reviews and aren't sure how to take the negative reviews...remember you are in Mexico at an all inclusive. The beds are going to be hard, the drinks will be watered down and the food will not always be top of the line. But if you are looking for a beautiful resort with an excellent staff and some place to really enjoy yourself stay at the Riu Palace Mexico. Watch for pictures to be posted in the next few days.

Reviews.Title: “110% Pleased”
Reviews.Author: Bighurt
Reviews.Content: Having used this website on several occasions prior to trips I often wonder about the travel experiences of some of the reviewers. The reason is that some of the complaints seem so petty. This was my 6th trip to the Playa del Carmen area, 8th trip to Mexico and 10th trip to the Caribbean. On previous trips to Playa del Carmen I have stayed at Riu Yucatan, Iberostar, Barcelo, and Bahia Principe x2. Other trips have included visits to San Jose del Cabo, Puerta Vallarta and two trips to Punta Cana, Dominican Republic. I feel at least that I have a solid foundation to provide sound feedback regarding this location. First I will begin by stating that this is probably the finest of all of the locations I have experienced in all of my trips. Upon arrival Manuel greets you promptly with a smile to take your luggage and direct you to the check-in counter. Here you are met by staff members handing you tropical drinks. Although this is done at many resorts it is always nice after a long flight and transfer (approx 1.5 hours) from the airport. Check in was very quick as there seemed to be plenty of staff members available to handle a somewhat heavy flow of travelers. Since most travelers will arrive beyond the time to make dinner reservations, the first nights dinner will most likely be in the buffet. I always have considered most vacation resort buffets acceptable but this was a level above simply acceptable. Considering that these resorts are providing food to as many as several thousands on any given day I don’t have high expectations but this was truly a surprise. Nightly there is a different theme in the buffet (Mexican, Italian, seafood, etc…) which was identified prior to entry along with a schedule for the entire week. As in most resorts there is a wide selection of fruits, cheeses, pastries, vegetables, etc… There is also a carving station providing guests with the cut of the day. Probably the most notable feature was the wait staff. I don’t think there was a moment where my glass was empty. If you were a wine drinker they would also gladly bring you the bottle so that the chance of your glass running low would be completely eliminated. The one food item that I cannot comment on is the desserts. In 7 days I didn’t try any however I can say that they looked great. Lunches are typically the same however a little lighter selection. Of course guests could get the typical burger and fries but one could also get fresh fish, chicken or a variety of Mexican style foods. Breakfasts in my opinion are pretty tough to mess up. Scramble some eggs and add some bacon and we are in business. I did not venture far beyond that most days. There was choice of fresh pancakes, french toast, homemade donuts, pastries, yogurt, cereal, etc… The gourmet restaurants were also good. This required an extra step as guests needed to make reservations between 0830-1030 daily for dinner. There were two seatings and from what I could tell two restaurant choices daily. The choices included Japanese, Mexican, Steak, Brazilian and a last that I cannot even remember, maybe seafood. It was called Sir Edwards and was actually the only one I ate in during the stay. Not because it was bad but I actually enjoyed the buffet and the luxury of not being held to a reservation. I can say that I would have gladly eaten at Sir Edwards daily if that had been an option for me. It was great. There were several choices on the menu so of course I am speaking based on having only one of the choices, shrimp and scallops. Enough with the food. There seems to be a common complaint regarding this resort and it had to do with the beds. I will agree with them all. These have got to be the hardest beds on which I have ever slept. The first night truly felt like I was on concrete. Luckily though, since I had read nearly every review on this website I had learned that there was a remedy. A simple phone call to request mattress pads and the situation was resolved. Now it probably won’t be like home but it is an improvement. I will make one recommendation regarding the beds. If you can, travel with your favorite pillow because even though the mattress pads do make an improvement the pillows are still a little less than desirable. Since we are on the rooms let’s just stick with that. I found them to be nicely decorated and perfect size. The king beds are simply two twins pushed together which was actually good because my wife and I didn’t get into the cover “tug of war” all night. If you have the need to catch up on any TV there were plenty of channels which included programming for all languages. There is a balcony which could be facing beautiful ocean, courtyard, or you could have mine which faced the building at Riu Yucatan. No problem for me as I was not spending any vacation on a balcony. I had read some previous reviews indicating the presence of mold or mildew from the flooding caused by the hurricane. If it was present it was not noticed by me. Of course this is a very humid area and everything seems to feel damp. The fridge is nicely stocked and will be restocked on request. I am sure tipping a few bucks gets you more of what you want but probably not necessary. In the wall you will find mounted a built in bar. There are bottles of rum, vodka, brandy and tequila. This of course is available free of charge. Now for the reasons we all come here, the beach and pools. Wow!! The ocean is beautiful especially if you have never traveled to the Caribbean. The water is shades of blue and green and appears to be crystal clear. There are plenty of chairs on the beach so guests don’t have to go out at 6 am to reserve a chair (this was also true with the pool too). There does seem to be little shade available which was no problem for me but I am sure others appreciate the option. There was a bar located on the beach which never had a crowd. Wisely I packed large insulated mugs to lower the number of bar trips which proved a smart choice. It also kept the drinks cold in the hot sun. There is nothing worse than a slushy pina colada that is nothing more than a cup of coconut milk by the time you get back to your seat. There are complementary water activities (kayaks, boogie boards, etc…) There did seem to be a charge for the catamarans and windsurf boards. I am not sure if it was a charge for the equipment or if they made you take a lesson for which they charged. At any rate, be aware. Bottom line the beach was lovely. The pool is very nice. Maybe not the largest of pools as compared to other resorts but since this place is not as massive there was not the need. If someone did want a larger pool, all of the adjacent Riu properties are available to Palace guests however those guests cannot use the Palace property. The swim up bar was of course pleasant. Nothing spectacular but it was nice. The bar service was very friendly however one stood out among the rest. If you have the chance make sure you introduce yourself to Armando and he will take good care of you the entire time. You will also find him in the other bars in the evenings. Super waiter/bartender and even more so if you show him some paper gratitude but not necessary. There were a couple of features at this pool that I liked above others. Probably the best was the drink service that wandered through the chairs taking orders and promptly serving drinks. This truly made it relaxing. There was little need to ever get up. Also nice was the absence of loud music and annoying entertainment crew harassing to participate in every activity. Of course there were requests to play volleyball, ping pong or other sports but it was not an annoyance. Most of the guests seemed to be of the generation that did not want to guzzle booze all day long and listen to overly loud music. I will agree that it can be fun at times but not for seven straight days. If that is what you are looking for then I think you may be disappointed. You can go over to the Yucatan and I bet you will find it there. Some features I want to mention that I think set this place apart from some of the others. There is always a bar or restaurant open someplace. The bars carried not what I would call top shelf but not the typical watered down liquor either. For example, not that it is great whiskey but if you wanted bourbon you could get Jim Beam or Early Times. That is the first time I have ever seen KY bourbon at any resort in Mexico. The lobby bar was extraordinarily nice. In the early evenings there was a piano player to provide light entertainment and a wonderful wait staff to provide drinks. There was also a super concierge staff. I only met one, Tamara, however it seemed that every time I turned around she was asking if our stay was good or if there was anything she could do to make it better. This was top notch in my opinion. She arranged for my wife and I to eat off of the property one night. We had been to this area several times but had never patronized any local businesses and wanted to try something different. She arranged for use to go to Alux (pronounces Aloosh). It was a restaurant built inside a cave. Basically you are sitting around stalactites and stalagmites. It may have been one of the most interesting restaurants I have been. During the evenings in the courtyard area there was typically a band playing a variety of music followed by a show. Constantly I would hear guests comment on the shows and their reviews were less than stellar. In this reviewers opinion they are great. I don’t expect broadway shows. The kids performing are the same kids that are serving drinks, handing our towels and making sure guests are comfortable during the day. Considering this I think they do a wonderful job. Probably the most entertaining is the Michael Jackson show. Following the show the band provides more music. If you want to further your evening the Riu Tequila (adjacent property approx 200 yards away) has a night club opening at 11pm so guests can dance for hours if they desire. I would highly recommend this resort to anyone that wants a relaxing vacation in a beautiful setting. The advise I would give would be to ask for mattress pads upon checking in, bring insulated mugs and also be aware that men MUST where pants to dinner regardless of the restaurant. Some of the other locations have allowed shorts to the buffets but not the Palace. It seemed to catch some travelers off guard. Tipping is not necessary but the staff warrants it. Oh and one last thing, enjoy yourself.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic holiday”
Reviews.Author: racheljohn
Reviews.Content: We have just come back from staying two weeks at this hotel and it has been fantastic. Where do I start? Firstly the room. It was a comfortable size and very clean and the beds were firm. A few guests had complained that their rooms smelt musty and their clothes felt damp but we did not experience this. If you had complained about this, the hotel had no problem with moving you to another room. Food:- there was a very varied selection for all three meals, the hotel tries to cater for all tastes. I would suggest to try something difference each day, dont stick to what you know, you will be surprised. (The cakes are irrestistable!) As the hotel did not have a full occupancy while we were there, they only opened up two of the four specalised restuarants each night. These you have to book on the morning of the day you wish to eat in them. (The steakhouse was lovely!) The pool and surrounding area was clean and the bar staff do a great job of constantly refilling up your drinks! There is always something going on round by the pool, water aerobics, volleyball, shooting etc so if the sun gets too much there is always something to do. The beach was very nice but you do get the constant stream of beach traders! The evening entertainment started at 9:45 and usually lasted just over an hour. We saw most of the shows and they were very colourful. If it rains be warned, the tiles in the corridors and outside by the courtyard the tiles get very slippery when wet, even if you are wearing flat shoes! One point I would like to make is that although this hotel is advertised as 24 hour all inclusive, if you require any food after 10:30pm you have to go accross the road to the Tequilla Hotel for a microwave hotdog/pizza/burger. They do serve cheese and ham sandwiches in the lobby bar from midnight but these are not to everyones taste! All the staff from cleaners to waiters were very polite and friendly and could not do enough for you. We would definately return to this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Third trip to RP Mexico”
Reviews.Author: Garlic_Addict
Reviews.Content: Riu Palace Mexico Trip Report 8/31 – 9/9/06 This was our third trip to RP and our sixth trip to the area. This was a relaxing no-stress vacation. One of the employees said the resort was only 30% full. We are usually beach people, but the lack of shade on the beach forced us under the pool umbrellas. The poolside drink service was excellent. I think they need to install some palapas on the beach or at least some umbrellas or tarps between the trees until the palm trees fill back in. We visited the Riu Tequila pool and enjoyed its jungle feel (shade!) and wildlife—we saw lots of iguanas there. It was nice being able to go eat at the buffet at any time from 6:30 p.m. on and sit anywhere. I missed being able to order off the menu in the buffet (as we did previously) but the food overall varied nightly and tasted wonderful. We went to Sir Oliver (the gourmet restaurant) one night. They waited for everyone to arrive, took everyone’s order, then served everyone appetizers at the same time, waited for all to finish, served everyone the main course, waited for all to finish, then served everyone dessert. It took about two hours. You need to make sure you have plenty of time if you go to the restaurants. You also need to make reservations early as they limit the number of people and have only two seatings. I missed the piano player in the piano bar—I’m not sure if we just missed when he was playing or if it had been discontinued, but we enjoyed the courtyard music instead. The music in the courtyard varied nightly and was overall very good. There were very few children at the resort but we changed rooms because of a screaming baby next door two nights in a row around midnight. Our new room was near the courtyard right by the stairs, and we clearly heard the music in our room. The music stopped at 11 p.m., so it wasn’t a problem. In our first room, we got turn down service all three nights and even had chocolate kiss on the pillow one night. After we moved, no turn down service—we tipped the same amount, so I guess it was different maids. Second room’s hair dryer didn’t work but a phone call got a quick replacement. I guess they were unable to fix the patio door—it didn’t lock—but being on the third floor, we weren’t too worried about burglars. We were told by a couple of the animation staff that they were going to be off work a month—no pay. They thought they were going to do some renovations while attendance was down. I mentioned it to the check-out clerk and he said the Riu wasn’t closing, so it must just affect the animation staff. We were very pleased with our vacation, found plenty to do at the resort and plan to go back. Planning a trip to the Excellence Riviera Cancun next month and will do a comparison/review afterwards.

Reviews.Title: “Relaxation scores a 10”
Reviews.Author: msucheer
Reviews.Content: My husband and I just returned from a 5 night stay at the RIU Palace Mexico. This was our first experience with an all-inlcusive vacation. We booked directly through the hotel which was a great idea because we had free transportation to and from the airport which is about a 45 minute drive. The positives: Relaxation scores a 10 at this resort! It is quiet, sophisticated and intimate. The beach is fabulous and September was a great time to travel because there was never a lack of chairs or towels. The water is beautifully clear. We snorkeled around but not much to see...still fun. There are kayaks and lots of opportunity for water activities without interrupting the peacefulness of the beach. There are plenty of palm trees so it is easy to seek shade if needed. The pool is also great. Even though not as big as the Riviera Maya, much more quiet and relaxing. The area with the swim up bar is wonderful and the other areas of the pool are very empty and great for privacy. I only wished that there were the loungers to lay on in the pool...but still a great place to relax. The grounds are gorgeous and very impressive and the staff is extremely courteous and friendly. The atmosphere at this hotel is drastically different than the other neighboring RIU resorts. The Palace Mexico is quiet, a little older crowd...very few children, sophisticated, and few Americans. It is great to be able to visit a more lively place when you want it and then come home to your quiet resort for relaxing. The hotel bar was nice. Most everyone gathered for drinks before and after dinner. It stays open until 7 am but we stayed until 3 am one morning and we were the only ones there late. The drinks are kind of weak...so we started asking for a double and that did the trick. Most of the action happens across the street at the Tequila. The Tequila is quite lively and although we never visited the disco we did frequent the sports bar. Negatives: I was extremely disappointed in the food. We did find a good meal on occasion, however. El Patio has a good ribeye and the Mexican themed night of the buffet was great. You will always find something to eat at the buffet...but I never left a meal so full that my pants wanted to pop because there was such a plethora of great food. I was expecting the food to be the same calibur of a cruise and was sorely disappointed. The Brazilian restaurant was just simply not good and I ended up eating dinner rolls for dinner. Some of the restaurants were not open every night....probably because low season. The rooms are a little musty and the beds are hard even after asking for a mattress pad. I also do not like the two double beds. When we went on our cruise they at least had king size sheets and could make up your two beds to sleep as one. Now that I'm home...all my clothes smell musty. Overall: We had a fabulous time and would return. You can't beat the relaxation factor. Just don't plan on pigging out while you're there. Take advantage of the Tequila and the Riviera Maya while you're there. Tequila has the night life and the Riviera Maya has a fabulous pool, but the Palace Mexico wins the beach award hands down.

Reviews.Title: “Good service overall disapointing”
Reviews.Author: paulcurran
Reviews.Content: We booked with Thomas Cook on a last minute deal. I originally wanted to book Secrets Capri having read the reviews on trip advisor but in the end Palace Mexico was so discounted I decided to give it a go. In hindsight a mistake. Holiday didn't start too well. (no fault of Riu). A very long flight was followed by reps who simply didn't listen or know anything outside of their cancun comfort zone. Having managed to convince Thomas Cook's rep that we were staying at the Palace Mexico and not Riu Tequila she informed the coach driver to take us too Riu Palace Las Americas. (totally different resort). when i pointed out that this wasn't our Hotel she rolled her eyes and told me that this was the full name of our resort. I convinced the driver that we were at Palace Mexico but despite spending the first 2 hours telling everyone this we were still dropped at the the wrong place. (Palace Riviera Maya.) Finally after we paid for a cab we reached our destination. If I'm honest after being dropped at the Palace riviera Maya initially, the Mexico was a disapointment. Not only were we met and greeted at the Riv May but the reception looked newer and more elegant whilst we lugged our bags without help into mexico. The guy at reception was friendly enough but we were disapointed with the room. As we walked in the overwhelming sense was of Damp and an overpowering chemical smell - now at leat the smell showed that it had been recently cleaned but it was very unpleasant. The British disease of not making a fuss kicked in. When reception rang a few minutes later my girlfriend informed them the room was satisfactory despite the fact I was finding out that the bathroom light didn't work, the mini bar was leaking with coke everywhere, (how did they not notice) 2 optics were missing and most importantly from my girlfriends point of few the TV had a loose connection meaning I had too spend half the night adjusting the cable trying too get sound. I know we should have complained so it's our fault. Now to the nitty gritty. The service was very good. I was expecting it too be good and it was. It wasn't world class but very good. You got so used to a waiter refilling your glass when it looked in danger of emptying, or taking your used plate as soon as you got up in the buffet, that you noticed on the rare occassions when it wasn't in comparison as quick. I became spoilt you might say. Food I had read literally hundreds of reviews before coming here and against my better judgement managed to convince myself that the food were not be just adequate but good. Please, Please do not kid yourself. The waiters try too add gusto too the proceedings (especially in Sir Edward) but the food is far from Gourmet. My view may be coloured by the fact that my girlfriend got quite bad food poisoning on the 2nd night in Miagis Oriental restaurant and was laid low most of the trip. No honestly it's not great. 2 highlights- breakfast was decent enough and I had a adequate Tuna steak in the Steakhouse. Other than that poor. only 2 'A La carte restaurants' were open for dinner (I assume because of low occupancy) and the main buffet never opened for lunch (not that I cared) The booze was fine. Again staff very obliging and although we were very easy to please I don't think they failed to meet the demands of the the most demanding guest. If Im being picky I would say wine in the room would be nice. Overall I would say if you are going to use an all inclusive then you either want a family based activity resort( which this is not.) or if your without kids surely food and entertainment are key. On these fronts Riu Palace scoes low. It has stuffed up all inclusives as far as my girlfriend is concerned because although I've talked up other places such as Secrets for future holidays she doesn't belive the food will be any better. I can't give total advice having only been to the Palace Mexico but if food is important to you pay extra and don't stay here.

Reviews.Title: “Had a wonderful holiday”
Reviews.Author: bridgenut
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at this resort from 11th - 18th August. We are in our 50s and have stayed at many resorts in the Riviera Maya, Cancun area over the past 4 years; Palladium, Viva Maya, Barcelo Maya, Bahia Principe Coba, Iberostar Maya, Secrets Capri, Gala Playacar, Copacabana, Riu Yucatan, Riu Cancun and now Riu Palace Mexico - so I feel I have plenty of experience on which to base my comments!)) A lovely beach is top priority for us, and this resort certainly has that! Gorgeous white, soft sand and on most days, lovely, blue, CLEAN, warm water (there was some seaweed for a few hours on a couple of the days, but nothing to bother us). I had e-mailed ahead requesting a room with certain criteria (based on other trip-advisors' advice) and received the standard reply...."we will do our best, but can't promise". On arrival at check-in, I asked the front-desk clerk to point out our room allocation on the map of the hotel....of course, it was nowhere near where I had requested, but when I politely asked for a change, he did it with no problem = top floor, courtyard, in building nearest the beach. Check-in was very quick (the usual welcome drink) and the clerk was friendly and funny with perfect English. Our room was spacious, clean and nicely furnished - a sleeping area with step down to a sitting area. The bathroom, although adequate, wasn't the largest I've encountered! I agree with other reports; the bath, shower area is very dark and a bit outdated. However, it serves its purpose and I didn't see any mould. Plus, there doesn't seem to be any air-conditioning in the bathroom (unless ours just didn't function very well), so it did tend to become rather hot in there.....The mini-bar was stocked every day; I requested more of one thing than another and that was done most days; if not, a quick phone-call to housekeeping and someone was there within minutes with supplies. Also as per advice on trip-advisor, I asked for mattress pads (yes, the beds are hard!) and they were provided with no problem. I like the fact that there is a corridor with a door to the sleeping area that you can close - keeps out the noise from the hallway outside the room. If you have mobility problems, the only elevators are located at the lobby end of the buildings; otherwise, use the stairs - the exercise certainly came in handy after all the food and drink! It was a pleasant stroll to the beach through lovely landscaped gardens with fountains. Plenty of chairs, but not much shade - yes, there are palm trees, but the foliage hasn't grown THAT much since last year's hurricane. No towel game here, fortunately! However, I took my own beach umbrella (bought it at Shopko, in the camping section, small enough to be hand-luggage, tho I did check it on the way back), as I knew beforehand about the lack of shade and being fair-skinned and red-headed, need to seek shade after a while. We are beach-lovers, so, although the pool area looked very nice, we were never sitting there. The animation team is much more low-key than other resorts, tho' there are activities to take part in most of the day (but no beer-chugging contests around the pool).....more sedate activities! We enjoyed the buffet food and only ate twice at an a la carte - the Brasilian restaurant - it was good, but not great (we lived in Brasil for 13 years), and the Japanese (again, good, but not great). You do have to make reservations in the morning for that night's a la carte.......which might not suit if you aren't an early riser. We always ate lunch at one of the two buffets near the beach, so can't comment on the lunch in the main building restuarant. Breakfast was more than adequate too - something for everyone, from cold cuts to hot dishes and a great selection of breads and pastries. There was a theme to the dinner in the buffet each night; the food was about the best we've encountered at an "all-inclusive". We watched the show most nights and enjoyed it. The outdoor courtyard is a nice place to sit and have a drink and listen to the band that plays before and after the show (you can dance there if you want to). However, all entertainment stops at 11pm - I asked the head of entertainment about this and basically it's because the sound can be heard in most courtyard rooms and, for the most part, the clientele isn't the partying kind! There is a disco in the Riu Tequilla across the road that is available to Palace guests too.....there used to be one in the Riu Yucatan next door, but that seems to be closed now and I couldn't find out why. You could find most top-shelf alcohol brands in the lobby bar; the beach bar had some, but limited. This is an elegant hotel, with an old-world European feel in the furnishings and decoration. They do enforce the dress-code in the buffet in the evenings....long pants are a must for men......however, the buffet IS air-conditioned with outside seating being an option. We had a few minor problems which were quickly rectified, including a follow-up phone call by management to make sure all was well. We had a wonderful holiday here and it is one of the few we would return to. In closing, we travelled with Funjet for the first time (most others being with Apple) and have to say they did a great job, especially as we left USA the day after the last airport scare with heightened security. Our check-in in St. Louis and immigration and customs in Cancun was the quickest ever and our return pick-up was not nearly as many hours before the flight as we usually have with Apple. Plus, no long lines at check-in......maybe we just got lucky)).

Reviews.Title: “Incredible Service!!!”
Reviews.Author: JCSquared
Reviews.Content: This is the first vacation/hotel review I have ever written, in fact the first online review I've ever written, but our stay at the Riu Palace Mexico in Playa Del Carmen was exceptional. My wife and I spent our honeymoon here, we've both always been more adventurous travelers, but decided we'd plan a nice relaxing honeymoon. The Palace was absolutely beautiful! gorgeous beach, incredibly beautiful blue water and I'm a surfer that has been on several surf trips around the world, beautiful beach and water! Good food, I'd say it was great, but I do live in San Francisco the home of some of the best food in the world! and the customer service was unbelievable. There is no pressure to tip anyone at anytime, but we did at the end of the week as we jsut couldn't imagine not tipping some of the folks that worked there. You really get to know some of the crew pretty well and they were just all incredible, so friendly and helpful. There is plenty to do, snorkel, scuba dive etc, but we just relaxed and enjoyed the beautiful resort and incredible beach and water. I highly recomend this all inclusive resort, I'm recomending this particular Riu resort because we went to a couple of the other Riu resorts in the area and the Palace Mexico was by far the best, although the Palace Riveria Maya was also nice. There's not much to do in Playa Del Carmen if you're not a diver, although we might be a little jaded, we've been on several baja trips and I went to school in San Diego, so the "Mexican" mall was a little "been there done that" for us, but if you're looking for a beautiful resort with unbelievable service and good food, look no further than the Riu Palace Mexico!!

Reviews.Title: “Read this especially if you are travelling with an infant”
Reviews.Author: ahloofu
Reviews.Content: Is your dilemna choosing between the RIU PALACE MEXICO or RIU PALACE RIVIERA MAYA? For us it was a $138cdn difference...as the Riviera Maya was newer so it cost more. HANDS DOWN...I would have chosen the Riviera Maya next time. We tossed and turned over our decision, but booked the Palace Mexico b/c everyone was saying the beach was nicer. In hindsight, I realize that it is better to stay at the hotel with the better pool and walk to the beach...instead of vice versa. We spent 3 days at the Riviera Maya because their pool was BEYOND gorgeous!!!! The thing was insane...you could lounge there all day and not be bored. And the hotel was quite a bit nicer. It's worth the extra money. Email me if you'd like more details or pictures. I have pics of BOTH resorts so you can compare. TRAVELLING WITH AN INFANT: (*I was travelling with a 2-month old) THINGS TO CONSIDER: 1. The Pool: The good thing was there were umbrellas that could provide shade. As for the pool, not only is it small...it is pretty dirty, however during some parts of the day there was a nice amount of shade in the pool where I could take my baby in and play. 2. Beach: The beach IS gorgeous...but useless as there is close to no shade to be found. We would find a small patch of shade (very difficult unless you went first thing in the morning) however the problem is that the sun moves around and so does the shade. Every 15 minutes we were finding that we'd have to shuffle the baby to 'follow' the shade. Bringing a UV shade/tent is a MUST for your infant!! We had brought one, but it ended up not being good enough. A baby 'tent' seemed to work best. 3. The heat: It was sweltering hot! Good thing was I met other mothers who gave some great tips. One is...lightly soak a blanket with water and drape it over your infant...it helps to keep them cool and comfortable. 4. Elevators: The resort is a long U-shape...and the annoying thing is there are only 2 elevators and both are located near the front lobby area. We were lucky that our room (Room 2019) was in the middle of one of the U-sides so we didn't have to walk too far to get to an elevator. We did however find it a hassle as there were a set of stairs right in front of our door that would take us down...but we weren't able to use them b/c of our stroller. 5. Resort-provided Crib: The crib is a good size and they were great about bringing it up promptly...however the rooms provide you with 2 double beds pushed together which ends up being much larger than a king sized bed....so really, your child could easily sleep with you. OVERALL: We had an unfortunate incident where one of the housekeeping staff made an aggresive pass at me in the doorway of my room. My husband was at the beach and I was holding my infant...it was a little scary, but I managed to push him out of my room and bolt the door shut. Again, this is a VERY isolated situation, but I'm sharing it b/c we were impressed with how the hotel staff handled the situation. The manager came promptly and took down the details, contacted the police and fired the staff within the day. I'll end it here...email me if you have any specific questions about the resort(s)...I'd be happy to help! :)

Reviews.Title: “Best Hotel in Cancun!”
Reviews.Author: NatalieSA
Reviews.Content: I have just come back from a terrific vacation in Cancun! and I am here to talk to you about a fantastic hotel, the Riu Palace Mexico. My boyfriend and I enjoyed a spectacular week at the palace that had one of the best beaches on the shoreline!...think postcard, picturesque, palm tree layden beaches, it was awesome! The room was great, very roomy, and may I say the showers are great. The air conditioning was a great escape from the humid air. The only thing is that the beds are a little hard. The buffet at the Palace was fantastic, better than we expected, but like my boyfriend said, probably better then most buffets in North America! The three other restaurants offer great variety, Sir Edward, a french restaurant, Miyagi, Japanese, and Le Bodega, Brazilian. What was also great was the amount of activities that are offered. We went parasailing, AMAZING!! and we also went on a couple of tours. The coba adventure tour, which was a tour of the mayan ruins and old mexico! great tour but you need alot of energy, cause it is a long day! Also we went on a catamaran, which took us to a secluded beach and snorkeling! One tip of advice is take alot of sunscreen and be prepared to get wet! The service is great and every night is a different entertainment show at the hotel! But you are also persuaded to visit and use the other Riu hotels in the area which is great! Overall, we had a very memorable time, great vacation, very relaxing and we wish we were still there!

Reviews.Title: “Rest and Relaxation”
Reviews.Author: TPerl
Reviews.Content: We traveled to Mexico during the second week of August 2006. We booked our trip through itravel2000 and flew with Sunquest. Both organizations provided us with excellent service. Upon arrival at the Riu Palace Mexico we were joyfully greeted by Manuel the doorman. (Everytime we crossed paths with Manuel was a joyful experience.) Our luggage was taken into the hotel room for us and the front desk provided us with refreshments as we checked in. When we arrived to our hotel room, we were greeted by a staff member who checked our fridge to make sure it was full of beverages (this became routine throughout the week) and also we received a telephone call from the front desk who reconfirmed our satisfaction with the room. As we encountered staff throughout our stay, we were always greeted joyfully. Staff was helpful, friendly and went out of their way to serve us. Visually, this hotel is extraordinarily appealing. The grounds were cleaned and trimmed on an ongoing daily basis. After experiencing the remnants of tropical storm Chris during our second day of travel, the staff was quick to react to the overwhelming amount of water that accumulated on the grounds. It was evident that the overall appearance of the hotel was important to staff. As for our hotel room, again, this room was beautiful. I would have to agree with other reviews, however, that the beds are not comfortable and if you are experiencing a sun burn the bed sheets tend to feel like sand paper. Another downfall is the noise level throughout the hotel. Considering the fact that the hotel has ceramic tiles throughout, the noise traveled very easily. At times we were awakened at very early hours of the morning either by other visitors or staff walkie-talkies. The maids visited our room on a daily basis, sometimes they would forget certain minor items like rolls of toilet paper, drinking glasses, etc. When we called the front desk they were quick to react and items were replenished without hassle. There was one day that we arrived from our excursions at around 5:00 pm and found that the maid did not visit our room. Being tired at the time we changed the door sign to “do not disturb”. However she did arrive at around 5:30 pm and still knocked on our door and offered to clean our room. At that time we were more interested in resting and we asked that she only replenish our toiletries and towels. The food and drinks offered by all restaurants and bars were absolutely wonderful. Desserts need some improvement. However this could be a good thing if you don’t want to gain about five to ten pounds on your trip. Just remember that “American” based food such as pizza that is presented at the buffet restaurants is their “Mexican” version of it (Which you should expect since you are in Mexico). Making reservations for the specialty restaurants is not difficult; we did not encounter any huge line-ups early in the morning. However you still need to make reservations early because the restaurants have limited space. The specialty restaurants do an excellent job with the food and the service. One evening we ate at Sir Edwards which serves gourmet. My husband noticed a live tiny green worm (about 5 mm in length) on the tomato of his salad (these worms are common and usually associated with broccoli). We notified the waiter; he was greatly apologetic and offered to replace the salad. Afterwards we were greeted by the hotel supervisor, she was informed of this incident and offered to provide us with a special order from the chef, we said that it was okay, then she offered to make us reservations at a restaurant for the next day so that we would not have to wake-up early, considering that we were going on a snorkeling trip early that morning and wouldn’t be able to make reservations we took this opportunity. The beach and the weather were both amazing! The water is a crystal clear aqua green in colour. You need to swim further out to experience the clarity of the water. The water temperature is very warm. The beach is very clean. There were a few issues concerning salespeople on the beach who continuously disturbed visitors. One day after we came back from a swim, we were notified by a nice American man to check our things because there was an older man (supposedly a thief) roaming the beach and he went through people’s belongings including ours. The staff at the swimming equipment kiosk by the beach was not as friendly as expected. We booked some equipment for a specific time and did not end up using the equipment because other visitors had ignored the time lengths and did not return the equipment within suitable time. Staff was very lethargic towards this issue. My husband booked a snorkeling trip there as well. The girl that did the booking wanted American dollars and we only had Pesos. She was incorrectly calculating the exchange rate and refused to recalculate. So he used his VISA hoping that the exchange would be correctly calculated there. Somehow she still managed to charge us $40 more. We did not enjoy the town of Playa del Carmen. Almost all items for sale were ridiculously priced and not very nice anyways. We opted to participate in the night entertainment at the resort. The bands that played in the at night were fanatastic, but they did not play long enough. If you are the type of traveler that likes to stay on a resort and do minor activities this trip is for you. If you like to leave the resort and explore the parts of the country, basically, there is very little out there and it doesn’t seem very safe. We had a very relaxing and worry free trip. The resort and beach are like paradise. I fully recommend this resort for couples who are looking for rest and relaxation.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel, Some minor issues”
Reviews.Author: Trafficnerd
Reviews.Content: My Wife and I just returned from a 4 day 3 night (Arrive Fri-Leave Mon) stay at the Riu Palace Mexico and loved the hotel. The grounds were immaculate, the hotel staff were always courteous and very eager to help with anything. The water was gorgeous and the sand beach was well groomed and swept of trash every night. Buffet style food was good, and many dishes were above average. My wife especially enjoyed the ceviche they served on two occasions. I liked the fact there was always a decent variety of dishes even though the buffet did have an overall "theme" every night like italian, mediterranean, mexican, etc. There was always an excellent selection of fresh fruit and salad "items" at all meals. We ate at the Sir Henry specialty gourmet restaurant one of the nights of our stay. While the presentation was improved and the service was there, the food was not tremendously better than at the buffet dinners. Quirky reservation system for the specialty restautrants forces you to eat buffet the night you get there because you were not able to make a reservation from 8:30-10:30 AM at the lounge bar as required by the hotel. Snorkeling off the beach was fair, did get to see some schools of fish near the large "tubes" that are present off the beach. Can't really complain about the snorkeling other than the fact that the "all-inclusive" gear had a 1 hour time limit. Also, the included non-motorized watersports such as the Catamarans and Windsurfing gear were only free after you had 3 private lessons ($20-$35) a lesson and could prove you could handle the gear. I suppose I see some merit in this so that you don't get hurt, but the hotel (or orbitz) could have been more upfront about it. Be ready to pay between $18 a person (shuttle van) and $45-65 (taxi) for the ride from CUN to the Hotel if you don't book through the hotel. Our trip arrangements did not include ground transportation from CUN to the hotel or the hotel to CUN. For the ride back to CUN we snagged a Taxi out in front of the hotel and agreed with the driver to get a $40 to the airport. Also, if you forget stuff, don't buy it at the hotel gift shop, just take the $3-5 taxi ride to wal-mart and stock up and grab the $3-5 ride back to the hotel. We had forgotten quite a few things and were able to pick them up for substantially less than at the hotel, even once the cab ride was factored in. While we had these minor quirks on our stay, overall we had a great time at the Palace Mexico, and would return to it or the sister RIU properties in Playa without hesitation. The hotel was exactly what we were looking for in a weekend getaway.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Riu Mexico”
Reviews.Author: ktduomo
Reviews.Content: Had a very relaxing stay here recently. Arrived from Cancun and immediately felt relaxed. Beautiful design felt nicer than the new Riu hotel nearby. However rooms need refurbishment and not as nice as rooms at new Riu nearby although very comfortable. Dining and service just excellent. Reception personnel outstanding and especially impressed by Tammy the host for her oustanding customer support. Slight problem with being charged fifty dollars more on card than had signed for awaiting resolution of this. Saw some excellent weddings being held - very impressed by hotels organisation of these. Just a beautiful hotel - one of the best.

Reviews.Title: “Could have been better!”
Reviews.Author: Starjm
Reviews.Content: We decided to change from our usual vacation in Cancun to the Riviera Maya. We decided on the Riu Palace Mexico in Playacar after extensive research. We were there from August 8 through August 15th. To begin with, if I had never been anywhere else, I would have rated this place better, but since there was a basis of comparison, especially nearby in Cancun, I have to downgrade my marks overall. I have to say I was for the most part disappointed. First, I must comment on Apple Vacations. The airline they use, USA3000 is top notch - with decent food, more legroom, movie and a very cheerful flight crew. When we landed in Cancun (40 minutes early), the experience changed. After an easy pass though customs and baggage claim, we found our transfer. It was a bus which we boarded and had to wait for the rest of the Apple vacationers to get on - of course, there was that elusive 2 people who never showed which delayed our journey. Finally we left the airport at 10:30 AM and due to the many stops at other resorts and the traffic, we didn't arrive at the Riu Palace Mexico until after 12 noon! It was supposed to be a 45 minute trip. When we traveled previously through Liberty Travel and also through Palace Resorts transportation, we were always in a van and arrived at our resorts way before lunch! We were greeted at the door and our luggage was placed near the gift shop. We were then escorted to the lobby bar for a drink and "orientation". I was surprised when the hotel rep said they had the three rooms ready for our group. But when I noted that two of them were located quite differently from the other, I opted to check it out before accepting it. That was a good thing as we had 2 rooms overlooking a rooftop facing directly at a wall... I politely returned the keys and said we would wait it out until 3pm and asked if he could please get us on the first level as close to the pool as possible. We wandered around and got some food. I was standing in the lobby around 2pm looking for my sons (they took the odd room) when the hotel rep called to me and said that he had our rooms ready. It couldn't have worked out better as we had 0018 and 0020 which, as you walk out of the main building at ground level, are directly to the right. We had easy access to everything from there and although a little noisy in the morning, closing the middle door in the room cut the noise off completely. We also had a statue in a garden directly outside of our patio for a nice view. As previously posted by others, a courtyard view is $30 extra per person per night - totally not worth it! Quite a change from our usual hotels in Cancun where 60% of the rooms are ocean view with no upcharge! There is a small downside sitting on the patio in the late afternoon, as you are listening to the people and carts using the the beach access walkway for the Riu.Tequila. The accommodations were very good and it was a plus to have the sitting area. I enjoyed the high-backed lumpy couch with sinking cushions which were my savior for the week. The beds are worse than sleeping on rocks (for me) and even getting a pad on the bed didn't help (like putting a tissue over the rocks) so after two nights of really painful sleep I hit on the idea of using the couch cushions on the bed. The first two nights I shared with the wife but when she started to toss her cushion to the floor mid-way through the night I took them both over completely. The TV was quite small, but it did receive a lot of channels (American included). The mini-bar was well stocked and the liquor dispensers were a nice touch. A coffee maker would be a plus, as the only place to get coffee is in the bar or in the courtyard (only at breakfast). Ice was a bit of a problem. The ice machine on our ground floor broke mid-week and 2 days later, the spot it occupied was walled over and repainted. The ice machine was taken away and never appeared again! The beach at the Riu Palace Mexico is superb! There are not the rolling waves of Cancun, so it is calmer and very beautiful. There are a few clusters of rocks, but not too much of a problem. The best time to go is in the morning - clear water. Afternoon, the water gets more cloudy & full of seaweed. No problem, though, we just switched to the pool. The pools are separated - one very nice and deeper with no swim up bar - the other is ridiculously shallow! It is only about 3' deep ....a little ridiculous when one goes to stand up and walk away from the bar (especially me at 6'6").Whoever designed the pool area in two sections and decided not to connect them obviously never walked on those hot paving stones. We NEVER went anywhere around the hotel or pool area without sandals on and there was always a line-up of them along the edges of the pool. It would be a great idea to take some of the vast expanse of jungle and sand and put in a larger deeper pool. Now for the food. It was just not up to par. The buffet was expansive, but mostly the same thing every day & night. If you want it to be fresh better get there early because the heat does wilt the food. They did have specialty nights, where they would add a few dishes, but if you has a seafood buffet the night before, you would see the same seafood the next day for lunch! I heard about a chocolate fountain but never saw one! While I didn't have any problems booking the specialty restaurants, even at 8:30 to 9am each day, I couldn't say there was much reason to make that effort. We did love the Japanese restaurant and tried to book it again for our last night, but we were informed it was closed due to low hotel occupancy. After the terrorist plot was foiled, there was a noticeable decline in people at this hotel with very few checking in. We were told there were around 600 people on Monday, the day before we left. The other specialty restaurants really aren't so special. The menus are very limited and they offer none of the presentations we have been accustomed to at other Cancun hotel specialty restaurants (pretty plate designs using the food & sauces). The Italian restaurant was never open at night and the steakhouse was so hot that the waiters were dripping with sweat! Also, except for the Japanese, they were all partial buffet as you had to get your own salad (except Sir Edward) and dessert (all). It was really ridiculous for the dress code to be enforced in the buffet restaurant. Men were required to wear long pants with a collared shirt. Women could wear anything. How dressy are torn jeans compared to a nice pair of walking shorts. More food notes which I wish I had known beforehand: except for the buffets served, there are no snacks to speak of. The Cubano bar serves nothing, but if you are sitting at the bar, the bartender has small plates of peanuts behind the bar - if you know to ask for them. The pool bar does have the nacho machine and the empty popcorn machine. It's difficult to drink alcohol without something to munch on. Other hotels we have been to have brought out snacks in the afternoon at about 4PM.; they also did specialty things like making mexican coffee or crepes- but not the "upscale Riu". I honestly think I only paid for their architecture and expansive property! No complaints about the alcohol - it was top shelf and always flowing. I note in other reports complaints about management but I have to say the staff that I encountered were excellent. They seemed to be not used to tipping, as when I did it, it took about two days for word to get around - I found my treatment to be very different on day three, as they all knew by then to look for me. My wife enjoyed her chair held, our napkins were always placed on our laps, etc.... My other encounter with the front desk involved a broken suitcase handle (manufacturer's defect - it was brand new). I asked where I could get a nut and a screw to temporarily fix it - the front desk person told me they would send maintenance when I went back to my room. A young handyman took the case away and brought it back repaired and better than new !! I was really pleased with that. Also as reported before, the doorman Manuel was amazing! He stood out in his uniform and always was friendly and helpful. Most of the staff were great and very hard working. We only received 2 towel animals in the room (we are accustomed to one each day - spoiled I know) although we tipped $5 per day. The night time entertainment was held outside in the courtyard. Although it was not as hot as when the sun was out, it was a little uncomfortable. They have a strange system of bringing you drinks. There is a main waiter who takes your order and another one brings it. There were several times we had to reorder when our order didn't show up. The band in the center of the courtyard was very good. They also had a kiddie show which involved the younger guests each night - this did not change - cute at first, monotonous later. The main entertainment rotated around the other hotels. The Michael Jackson show was surprisingly good. The Mayan show was amazing - do not miss it! Very professional. We took one trip to Xel Ha which was very nice. If you go to south to Tulum or anywhere through there, you need to check if they are done with the road changes in the Puerto Aventura area. It seems a pedestrian was run down on the road the previous week and the locals were very upset. They came in and shut the highway down to one lane and were installing huge speed bumps in the highway. This created an hour backup both ways to get through this town. I really felt bad for those staying at the Aventura Palace as this all occurred right at their front entrance. We also went into to the town of Playa del Carmen ($5 cab ride - well worth it) and enjoyed that immensely we did regret that we didn't get to try out any restaurants there as they all looked very inviting. We walked to all the other Riu's in the area and were satisfied with our choice (the Riu Palace Riviera Maya was the only other one with an air-conditioned lobby) although the other hotels had better pools. We did have the best beach area. When it was time for our departure, we discovered that there was no bell service before 7AM! There was also no room service for a quick breakfast before 7AM either! Our pick-up was scheduled for 7:10 AM, so we were almost out of luck. Fortunately, there was some coffee set up outside in the courtyard.with a basket of about 6 pastries. They call this "continental breakfast" and set it up at 6:30 AM. So all in all when I do go back to Mexico, it won't be to another Riu. The Palaces are way too quiet and stuffy and the others just don't measure up to what I am used to.

Reviews.Title: “Better than average”
Reviews.Author: actran
Reviews.Content: We went to the Riu Palace Mexico with our kids (14, 17 and 20 yo and his SO) for a 1 week vacation. For reference - my husband and I have stayed at the Royal Hideaway 3 times which has set the bar ridiculously high, and we took the kids to the Grand Xcaret last year. It was definitely a better resort than OGFX. We always use Cancun Valet for transportation and they came through again with flying colors. We arrived at the RPM and the driver unloaded our bags and we took them into the lobby. I said to my daughter that at RH you don't touch your bags and they meet you at your vehicle. Comparing wasn't going to help me enjoy the RPM, and it is a resort that deserved to be enjoyed on its own merits. We were checked in quickly, given welcome drinks (tropical jiuce blend), wristbands (they asked who was under 18 and when I said my daughter was almost 18 they wouldn't give her and adult band. That was fine with me and I wasn't going to say she was 18 when she's not, but I know this is an inconsistent rule and she met a girl who was 17 who was given an adult band). We were taken to our rooms. I had asked that the 3 rooms be in close proximity, and they were right next to each other. I had also asked for a top floor and courtyard view and we didn't get either. Our patio faced the neighboring resort, but it wasn't a bad view because there is a big strip of grass and a gazebo and other decorations. Our room was really hot and humid because the patio door had not been locked and the air conditioning goes off if it's not locked. It eventually cooled down. The room and housekeeping was fine. We tipped just about every day. We got towel animals for about 1/2 our stay. One maid was rather agressive in her cleaning and threw out a piece of paper in our kids room that had an important number written on it. They provided turn down service and new large towels in the evening. A couple problems (and what made the most significant negative impression on me) was 1)our room had no deadbolt and when I went to the front desk they told me it woud be fixed that day or the next. It was never fixed and once they called to see how things were and my husband mentioned it and was told it was because they were switching to a key card system. That didn't make a whole lot of sense because our other 2 rooms had deadbolts. They use keys that have your room number on them and when my husband went to the front desk to ask for another key they just gave him one without asking for any kind of id. Another problem was when I called the front desk and asked for a blanket. I had been cold the first night and when I was in another one of our rooms saw a blanket on one of the beds. They had 2 in their closet, but we had none. The guy who answered the phone said they would send one up. No blanket ever came even after 4 phone calls and a trip to the front desk. I was told it was on it's way, they were looking for one, it should be there soon. I finally got one from one of our other rooms. The next morning the same guy was at the front desk and I told him it had never arrived and if they had just told me that I wouldn't have kept waiting. He apologized and said he would send "something" to my room. That "something" must have stayed with the blanket that never came. The property is very beautiful and I really enjoyed the walk to the beach. There are fountains along the whole path and it is very nicely landscaped. The beach is HUGE and there are plenty of places to find shade - which was a big concern before we went. The food was average to good. The Brazilian restaurant was very good. The Steakhouse was not very good, but is outdoors near the beach and had a nice atmosphere. The Asian was pretty average. My daughter was really looking forward to the deep fried ice cream, but it was terrible with all the ice cream melted and the coating soggy. We ate at the gourmet twice. I really liked the duck, but the filet was average and my husband didn't like either of the seafood dishes he ordered. The buffets had good buffet food. But contrary to what others had written I didn't find it that great. It was still buffet food. There are 2 restaurants open for lunch but you can sit at one and go over to the other's buffet if you want. We didn't find the reservation system that much of a problem as we were usually up early enough to get in line early and get the reservations we wanted. My son tried to get reservations the first morning we were there towards the end of the time they take them and everything was full. When we checked in and they told us about the ala carte restaurants I asked if any were closed on certain nights and he said everything was open every night. In reality there was one that was closed every night. The staff at the restaurants were great. The gourmet restaurant had a really nice Cabernet, but I couldn't seem to get it anywhere else. The lunch restaurants only had beer, wine soda and water. No mixed drinks at lunch. The main breakfast buffet had a mimosa station, as well as a station with freshly made juices of many varieties. There was a restaurant down by the beach that served a continental breakfast from 10:30-12:00 for those sleeping in. I had heard you could get a continental breakfast via room service, but it wasn't advertised at all so I don't know if they still do that. The entertainment was pretty typical AI entertainment. They had a band playing in the plaza at night that we enjoyed listening to while we had drinks after dinner. A couple nights vendors were set up in the plaza. The animacion team was fine. They didn't seem to have a whole lot of people participating in their activities. I did take a Spanish lesson one day. He taught us a lot of numbers and a few phrases. Not too helpful. I asked when he was going to teach us how to say "Give me the good tequila." He never did teach me that. The staff seemed to appreciate efforts at speaking Spanish. At the Steakhouse they asked if we spoke Spanish and I said a little but my daughter speaks a lot. They proceeded to give her all the information in Spanish and then she told us what they said. We didn't spend much time at the pool, but there were plenty of chairs available throughout the day. There is a beach bar and a pool bar. The waiters would bring around trays of different drinks with bottles of rum and vodka to add if you wanted. Some days they seemed to come around every hour and some days it was like once I saw them. This may have been a function of how busy the pool was because they came around very frequently at the pool. We saw quite a few families with kids, although it certainly wasn't overrun with kids. I saw one single guy and lots of couples. There is a lot of topless and a lot of smoking. There are a lot of Europeans and they seemed to constitute a lot of the smokers. I hate smoke and wish there was an effort to seperate the smokers from those of us who like to breath clean air. One other issue I had was with the tap water in the room. No one ever said anything about it, but the hotel services guide in the room said the tap water was not drinkable and there was a little sticker that was not obvious at all next to the mirror. I brushed my teeth a couple times with tap water but after I saw that I used bottled water. My husband continued to use tap water. I got sick and he didn't. Another thing that makes the RPM a great place is the stretch of beach it is on and it's proximity to PDC - a $5 cab ride. The Riu Palace Mexico is a nice resort and a good value for what they charge. I don't know if I would return though. (I do know I'll return to the Royal Hideaway).

Reviews.Title: “Splendid Palace Vacations”
Reviews.Author: SteveEdmunds
Reviews.Content: Just returned from the Riu Palace Mexico 10 to 15 August and has a superb time with my wife and 13 yr old son. I am British and the wife is Mexican. We live in the north of Mexico. Pretty much most of the reviews in here are quite accurate but I would like to add my own findings and hope you find the comments as useful as I did when reading the other reviews. This Palace "Mexico" (there'a another four hotels along called the "Riviera Maya") is quite an experience. Its architecture is stunning, and really takes you back to a grand old Mexican 'Hacienda' type building, superbly laid out and abundant in gardens, lawns, fountains and beach, and palacial internal decor that makes you feel you are in the setting that it pretends to take you to. Al in all, a great place to take a relaxing holiday and staff that works happily with service in mind. These peole are very good at what they do and try their very best to please. Congratulations for all the teamwork and smiling faces. I admire you all. 10 out 10 across the board for this hotel but there are some little issues you need to take into acount ... here they are one by one: POOL: Very small and very warm. My thoughts here are that RIU should take advantage of the abundant space on the lawn found on the beach side of the pool area and either expand the current pool or build a new one ... and make it a little deeper! 3'0" just about all over and 4'0" here and there means that even the floor of the pool heats up with the sun's piercing summer rays and the water thus remains pretty warm. Also, it all seems so cramped around the pool bar as it is the largest area to 'hang out' in whether you are an adult or a child.If you are a pool lover, you will be disappointed with this one. RESTAURANTS: The speciality ones do require advanced booking for evening meals. I never bothered to book once as I didn't fancy queuing up for 40 mins at 8am every morning to make a reservation. We ate at the Don Julian Buffet every night, and it is delicious. I peeked into the specialty restaurants a couple of times and they seemed very quiet and deserted anyway and I cannot therefore comment o the food and service in those. Perhaps I wasn't the only one wishing to avoid holiday queues! The variety in the buffet was quite amazing and I wondered just how they keep so many dishes 'on the move'. A good logistics chef no doubt and certainly JIT!!!! Just one little complaint, the egg chef! Makes sure you clearly explain how you want your eggs as the guy there is clueless and takes offence if you don't like 'em 'his way'! ROOMS: Nice, but careful if you are looking for a) a sea view: only about a two dozen rooms offer this (and the sea is about 100 or so yards from these rooms) or b) a view of the fountains, because most folk are placed in c) rooms with a view of the hotels on each side of the Palace, and not too nice at that! I asked for a room with a view to the fountains and had to pay 30USD extra per person per room per night to get it! The lay out of the room was identical. so you pay for the view! DRINKS: I love a beer, much more so than top shelf liquor, and found it strange that while you could get a triple shot of Chivas Regal, Gordon's, Jim Beam, Napoleon, etc in ALL the bars it was only draught corona for the beer drinkers. Yukky stuff at that. Good old Don Julian at least served bottled Corona while dining, but apart from that and the two bottles per day in the room mini bar, that was it! Even the Patio bar with throngs of folk sitting enjoying themselves at night had to drink warmish Corona from the barrel. Come on Riu. A few tubs of bottled beer on ice is not too difficult to set up or that much more expensive than barrelled beer, if that is an issue. Also, the wife is partial to a 'light' beer. None to be found at this hotel, period. ENTERTAINMENT AT NIGHT The nucleus of this is the Patio Bar from sunset to 11pm. It goes like this ... Sunset: a band starts playing for about 20 to 30 mins. 30 Mins Later: the band stops for the kids mini disco held in the theatre adjoining the Patio. Mini Disco: No variation whatsoever night to night with same set each day for about 40 mins. (The songs and patter get a bit tedious after hearing them for several nights on the trot as the theatre used for this flows out onto the Patio where folk sit to enjoy a pre or post meal drink.) 40 Mins later: Mini Disco stops; band resumes for 2 more songs 2 songs later: Band stops for Nighly show in Theatre. Some of these were quite entertaining; some were cheesy (see other reviews) This lasts best part of an hour. 10:40pm or thereabouts: The band resumes again, plays about 3 or 4 songs, and then on the stroke of 11pm bid you farewell, and good night, like "Time for bed, folks!" And just as we were getting in the swing of things after dinner and a couple of warm Coronas! For me, I think that the theatre and its own bar is poorly used ... why the band couldn't play for another, say, one hour in there beats me or a roaming Mexican Trio band to provide a romantic and nice, cultural touch for the Mums and Dads enjoying the fresher evening air. I understand the need to 'quieten down' outside at 11 ish for folk that do want to go to sleep around then, but those who want to listen to music a little longer are left twiddling their thumbs. OK, so entertainment is available next door and at the other Riu's but ... I don't want to go the other ones! I want to stay in the Palace and relax, not move around looking for the entertainment. BEACH: The best on the Riviera Maya. Simply fantastic and certainly helps to take away the disappointment of the pool. If you are a beach lover, you will be in awe. As I said earlier, 10 out of 10, and that score remains, even after pointing out the little issues above. Would I go back. I most certianly would, but perhaps I'd give the newer Palace Riviera Maya a try first. I may well be wrong though as this hotel has so many good points. I just hope they brush up on some of the issues above. Enjoy your well deserved vacations, wherever that may be.

Reviews.Title: “beautiful hotel but.......”
Reviews.Author: pinegrove2
Reviews.Content: Being a travel agent I had contacted the hotel months ion advance to set up different things. It was our anniversary and birthday and I wanted tohave something special for that day and thought that 3 months ahead of time would be good. They gave us no discounts, which was fine, but booking alot of their hotel(s), I thought they would at least greet us when we got there. Even though the manager knew we were coming as per the e-mails!! We checked in and the room was wrong. We paid for a balcony with the garden view and they did not have any avail at that time and did not all week. We had a back room with a huge wall on our sitting area and no balcony! I had a group wanting to come down (over 50 people) and wanted to talk to the manager about booking these and having things set up for them. Also, my daughter is getting married in Cancun and I loved this hotel and wanted to find out information concerning that also. So the second day, I went to the desk and asked if there would be a chance to talk to the manager or someone in charge to go over these matters and to introduce myself. Well I went 4 days in a row and she never got in touch with me. I still have no idea who she is. Wanted to set something up special for our anniversary for my husband, no one could "understand me" Cake? How hard is that? The workers seemed to be thrilled we were there and went out of their way to have the room clean and small flowers in the rooms. Always stocked and never had to ask for a towel. But management....they could learn from their workers. They could car less who is there! Beautiful hotel and grounds, great rooms, good food, entertainment was first class...but....management needs an adjustment. If you want a wonderful vacation, I would go here. If you need to plan something special like a honeymoon, wedding opr something romantic that needs special attention. Go somewhere else!!!

Reviews.Title: “Palace Mexico is our heaven”
Reviews.Author: Tony&Chris
Reviews.Content: We are a quiet middle-aged couple who first visited Riu Palace Mexico in Year 2000, and have never found an equal resort. Would it be the same in 2006? It was, in fact better yet, a real Palace for us. We had a great room service, beautiful towel sculptures filling our room by week-end, and always had obliging and friendly staff. We slept well on spacious beds, and woke up very refreshed. Don Julian restaurant is wonderful for all meals bur especially breakfast and supper. Sit outdoors if you can! We booked every specialty restaurant and enjoyed El Patio Mediterranean best - Bodego the least. Too much Rodizio! We would have liked, and been ready to pay for, a wider choice of wine; Riu please note. There was a range of clientele from young families through leading edge boomers like us, and a good range of visitors from all over. If you like a rowdy, boozy, noisy crass crowd, go elsewhere, like Riu Tequila. All in all, our holiday was excellent. The beach is very spacious, and you can find areas away from the crowds if you prefer. The food was very good, buffets and salads stood out. However more fish options would be welcomed. 5 stars for Riu Palace, it has to be an example of how to run a great resort!

Reviews.Title: “A grand time”
Reviews.Author: Dutiel
Reviews.Content: My family and I just spent 5 days @ the Riu Palace Mexico and we could not have been more pleased. Accomodations were great, the grounds immaculate and the food just fine. What should be pointed out is the staff and level of service - friendly and helpful, they were the highlight of our visit and the model by which a resort should be judged. Because of their warmth and hospitality, we will be returning as soon as we can and will pass our recommendations on to friends and family. Again, the facilities were above par, the food generous and most importantly, the staff made us feel welcome, making our vacation one to remember. G.E.S. Round Rock, Texas

Reviews.Title: “Hopefully this review give you a bit more detail and tips”
Reviews.Author: Fyrectar
Reviews.Content: I am going to go over the trip from beginning to end because some things might help people going there even if it is not necessarily about the hotel itself. My husband and I stayed at the Riu Palace Mexico from July 29th, 2006 – August 3rd, 2006 for our 3rd honeymoon. It was booked through a travel agent as an Apple Vacation. First of all, everyone said it was a ½ hr ride but it was more like an hour and a half by the time you stopped at other hotels to drop off other people. We got in quite early, nonetheless, and checked in at about 10am. We were told our room wouldn’t be ready until 3pm and our stuff was just carted to the side of the lobby near the store which made me uncomfortable because people were over there pulling out stuff from their suitcases and nobody knew who’s was who’s, but there wasn’t anything I could do about it. Anyway, after a long trip I really wanted to change and get in the pool or something, not just loiter around the building. We went down to eat and walked around and I checked back at the desk at about 2:30 and got a room. The view I think may have been the worst in the hotel. It was on the side away from the pool with the slider going out to a patio, a patch of grass, and then a gate separating the resort from the one next door. That wouldn’t have been horrible but there was a building there that it looked like they might have been keeping supplies or something in that people were always out there getting into day and night. I had to keep the shades drawn the whole time since everyone could see in. The beds are very hard, I asked for mattress pads about 3-4 times but never saw any. I only got towel animals when we left at least $5 on the bed. But they did keep the rooms very clean and the shower had the best water pressure I ever felt. I was on the 1st floor and didn’t smell any mold or anything and the air in the bedroom worked great. The food was mediocre at best in the buffet. I think they definitely go for more quantity than quality. The restaurants though are wonderful. We ate at the Brazilian restaurant which was great besides one thing nobody mentioned. When you are making your reservations in the morning and they have the menus sitting out to look at the Brazilian restaurant menu is not a choice! You get ALL SIX Meats. They bring them out on skewers one at a time and you eat them all. I didn’t care for the appetizers or dessert. I will admit I can be a picky eater but my husband will eat anything and we felt the same way about all the food I am mentioning. We also ate at Sir Edwards which is the Gourmet French restaurant, I had the steak, and my husband had the duck. The restaurant was very good, even the dessert. But then we went back the next night and although the food was still good the air conditioning didn’t work and it was unbearably hot. All the other night we ate at the buffet and I am sorry if you though it was great but I though it was pretty awful. Lunch at El Patio and the La Traviata was better than the buffet; I could at least get pasta or a hot dog. Don’t expect the ice cream to taste like regular ice cream though. Unfortunately there wasn’t really a choice for breakfast so I had to settle for toast or generic cereal. Night life was practically nonexistent. We went across the street to the Club Hotel Riu Tequila and it was much livelier over there in the lounge bar. We stayed one night to check out the “La Pinata” Disco but it reeked of alcohol, the smoke was horrible, and it was more like an underage drunk fest than anything else. I saw them kick some kids out for not being old enough but they didn’t check everyone. Shopping was ok, even if you are bringing a camera I would recommend bringing a disposable one because mine broke while there and I had to buy one and it was like $15 for an outdoor only 24exp disposable with no flash. I haven’t yet seen how those pictures will come out. Shopping is nice over at la plaza. I wouldn’t recommend walking to 5th Ave, it’s worth the ride for $5 and trust me, 5th Ave is so long you don’t want to walk any further than necessary. We went to McDonalds to see what it was like and it was great and clean and they had a tv in it and an upstairs, it was awesome. The only complaint I had was the ketchup which I love, it was not the same. Back to shopping.. Make sure you barter! My husband bought a hat, it started out at $60 and we finally got it for $30. If you find you need supplies like anything normal, take a cab to Chedraui – it’s like a grocery store/target all in one, and meant for the locals it is a lot cheaper. Besides it is just fun to look. We took a couple of the trips, we did the ½ day snorkeling adventure thing. It was ok besides the fact that it was longer than advertised, some people missed their dinner reservations. I don’t know about you but I want to go, snorkel, and come back. They want you to go.. talk.. lay in a hammock.. snorkel for two hours.. eat lunch and lay around again… then snorkel again.. then just sit for a ½ hr before you leave. We left at 10:15 am and didn’t get back until a little after 6:30pm. It was not what I expected athough the snorkeling part was great. OH.. and make sure your sunscreen says BIODEGRADABLE or you have to buy theirs or not get in the water. The other trip we did was go to Captain Rick’s for deep sea fishing. It was a 4 hour trip on the boat, they told us to get there at 8:30 and we probably didn’t have orientation until 9:10 or so, then got split into groups of 5. My husband likes fishing and I don’t mind it but we had different ideas of fishing. I want to do something! We basically just sat in the boat for 4 hours and drove around “trolling” the whole time. The guy on the boat did everything. I never touched a thing, a rod, nothing. It was so hot and boring. We caught one fish and of course there are 5 of us on a boat and no one has a rod of their own so you just sorta pick who gets it. I was glad when it was over, I didn’t think it was really worth the $90 per person. It was sort of like we were paying Captain Rick’s men to fish, but whatever. I did get to see a dophin in the open water and caught a picture so that was my highlight of the day. At the hotel, we did the pool and the beach thing. I thought the pool was fine, it was never crowded and there was always a seat. We went to the beach which yes it beautiful but it is a bit of a walk.
