Taxi is $4 each way. TIP- tip if you want, service will be outstanding even if you don't BRING.... insect repelent, sunblock (will really need it), and an open mind!!! There were not many children which helps a lot when you are in on honeymoon (although we love children). There are not a lot of activities for children. The Riu is the best hotel in the Playacar complex (although there are others more expensive, including the Royal Hideway which has lost its beach due to erosion, unfortunately) We believe in always discovering a new place, that's the only reason we don't plan to go back to the Palace. But I will highly recomended it if you are on a honeymoon, want to relax, and at the same time be close to a vibrant town like Playa del Carmen. Loved the Palace!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “A Dream Vacation Come True/ A Class Act!!!!”
Reviews.Author: CanadaLoveparis
Reviews.Content: Our family stayed at the RIU Palace Hotel Aug.6-13. This hotel was a class act from the moment we arrived until the moment we left. Our family has travelled alot, and 2 times to Mexico and would consider going back to this hotel in a heartbeat!!! The specialty restaurants were a must and all the staff treated you as though we were the only ones there. Our children are 18, 19, and 20 and all loved it. They would come here as well. My only critisism is that you need to get your pool chairs VERY EARLY!!!! If you are going to Mexico, this is a hotel you must check out......

Reviews.Title: “Riu Palace Honeymoon.”
Reviews.Author: woodbutcher
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Palace Aug.7 to 14th my wife and I wrote this review together. Food: We ate at 3 of the ala carte restaraunts sir Edwards,La Bodega,El Patio.As far as food taste it was average but presentation was nice also atmosphere was good.But we feel the food was better by far as well as variety at Don Julian buffet and La Traviata for lunch by the beach Service: the service was very good and everyone who worked there was polite especially Noe who was was a pleasure to see everyday around the pool.We asked for a mattress pad upon arrival and it was there in an hour.Nightlife:Not much nightlife as for as dancing.We went to the tequila to the disco around 10:30 pm on 2 nights the first night there was at best 7 people in there and kind of boring not much dancing going on.And the second night we went there was 15 or so children running around the bar with no adults present and Shark Tales was playing on the big screen TV so no dancing for us.There were shows every night and were Ok but a little cheesy.But we would eat a late supper have a couple drinks and in bed by 11:00pm Resort and Beach:As for the resort,it was beautiful and impressive,lots of marble and tile with a hint of a new orleans feel in the iron work the palm trees are already showing signs of new growth and the grounds are continually being replanted from Emily. The beach was very nice and cleaned every evening and beach chairs all reset in rows.The palm trees on the beach still have an average of 5 to 9 full fronds on them and offer ample shade from the sun.Believe me it was very hot upper 90's and we had rain in the forcast everyday but we didn't see a drop.As for sunscreen we brought bullfrog waterproof 30spf and got great tans with no burning and we applied it before we went out if you applied it after you started sweating it would just glob on and not absorb,just a tip.As for the bug problems we didn't use anything while we were there sand fleas in the evening on the sand bite a bit but a small bottle of witch hazel and good to go.I actually got bit by mosquitos worse when i came home and checked my garden for 5 min. than I did in mexico no bites in mexico.But if you go near the jungle area it's bad from others that did cenote and jungle tours I talked to.We went on a sunset cruise $70usd each it was nice you were on a tri-hulled catamaran w/16 other couples they served drinks and hor'dourves and cruised around the calm waters for 45 min trip and then to the beach for a steak or lobster dinner under the palms.Lets see what have I forgotten? Oh yeah,check in was a breeze about 2 min. heres your key sir. We stayed in room 1114 the rooms were extremely nice and very spacious we weren't feeling closterfobic a bit.There was safe in the room and I was wary about who else had a key but did not have a problem and used it the whole trip.We left tips out for the cleaning people and they wouldn't take the money unless I specifically wrote tip on a piece of paper adjacent to it.Iv'e never said hola(hello) so many times in my life the people are very friendly and a complement as well as $ goes a long way.If you are worried about hurricane damage DON'T unless you look hard you wouldn't no it.This is not the Ritz Carlton but it is a very nice place with very nice people.Would I go back again? I would probably not.Because of the lack of things to do in the evening my wife and I are both 38 and still like to go dancing.If you want a place to relax this it! Enjoy!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “A Truly Perfect Vacation!”
Reviews.Author: calimomSanDiego
Reviews.Content: My husband and I can not say enough good things about the Riu Palace Mexico. Before our vacation I lived on this board trying to read all the reviews, and I have to say that most of them are dead on, I thought all the positive ones were too good to be true, but they were not - its really an amazing resort! We visited Aug 1 - Aug 6th, just after hurricane Emily and besides a few bare palm tree's you'd have no idea that a hurricane had hit. The grounds were amazing, and so clean! The staff was so attentive and gracious. I've stayed at five star resorts before and often felt unwelcome, or that the staff was too snobby. However, every member of the staff at the Riu Palace has a smile on and is there to help. I don't speak Spanish, and I had no problems communicating in any way. In fact the resort does cater to more of a European cliental, (it is a Spanish chain) so English is abundant for any one who had concerns. The rooms were fantastic, and so well cleaned. I read a lot of complaints about a musty smell, hard beds and a dark shower. There is no musty smell , its called humidity and there isn't much you can do about it. Things just stay a little more damp so it might bother some people who live in dryer climates. The bed's are hard, we didn't order a mattress pad though and were able to sleep just fine. The shower does not have a light, it would be a plus to have one but it wasn't an issue at all - we could see just fine! As everyone else says the beach is amazing, its a real slice of paradise. We never had any issue getting a lounge chair under the palm trees, there is shade but because of hurricane Emily the palm trees are a little bare - they grow pretty fast so in a couple months it should be back to normal. The resort was at 100% occupancy when we were there and it never felt overcrowded. The pool also looked very nice and clean, we never touched it though - I mean you can swim in a pool anywhere, so we spent most of our time at the beach. The restaurants were great, and yes you can now make reservations from 10:00 - Noon in front of Don Julian's restaurant. Here is a tip that we didn't pick up on till the end, you can book for more than one night, in fact you can book dinner reservations for the whole stay. If you don't have reservations, not to worry, we thought that the buffet at Don Julian's was great! They have different theme nights, so the food does vary. We were really impressed with the variety of food they offered. Like I said before there selection did seem to cater towards Europeans, but there is was plenty of choices for traditional American food, and they also have a great authentic Mexican section in the corner. Breakfast was great and so was lunch. El Patio is another one of their buffets, we ate there for lunch a couple of times. Not as large of a selection, but good nonethe less. We didn't get sick either, and I have a super sensitive stomach. I even came with medicine expecting to get sick because I always do in Mexico. The water is non-potable so you need to remember to brush your teeth with bottled water (supplied in room) and not open your mouth in the shower. When people complain of getting sick there can be several reasons, most of it is probably due to over indulgence in food, drinks, etc. Or just not remembering to stay away from the tap water. All the water that is served at the restaurants and the ice is purified. So no issue there. The resort does cater to a more mature audience, and isn't a wild party place if that is what you are looking for. My husband and I are in our late 20's and had a great relaxing time. Every night after dinner they have some sort of entertainment, and it you want more you can always go to downtown PDC or across the street to the Riu Tequila. Its not a place for young, active kids, there isn't really much to do for them there. One last thing to point out to everyone is that you are in another country - so there will be differences in food and the culture, appreciate the differences and don't let it bother. It was really refreshing to be surrounded by so many other cultures and be in a place that was less Americanized then Cancun. The Riu Place in my opinion beats any five star resort in the states, you can't go wrong with it!!

Reviews.Title: “Absolute Best”
Reviews.Author: springdreamer
Reviews.Content: My husband and I went to the RIU Palace last October for our 10 year anniversary. We were hesitate in going because it wasn't the resort our travel agent recommended. It was absolutely wonderful. What impressed us the most was how clean it was. We are very picky and this place was exceptional. We walked the beach one day to look at other properties but not one could compare to the Palace.

Reviews.Title: “Our New Favorite Resort”
Reviews.Author: PaulinColumbiaIL
Reviews.Content: RIU PALACE – OUR NEW FAVORITE RESORT BACKGROUND We are a married couple residing in Columbia, Illinois, a semi-rural suburb of the St. Louis Metropolitan area. Our previous travels to the Riviera Maya are as follows: July 1997Allegro (Diamond Resort) in Playacar (no kids yet) February 1998Iberostar Tucan (no kids yet) June 2000Iberostar Quetzel (with 1 year old son) July 2003Sunscape Tulum p/k/a Allure (with son and 1.5 year old daughter) June 2004Palladium (with both kids) We look for a good combo of picturesque beach, grounds and pool, a good variety of food, and some name brand liquor for me. We decided to celebrate our 10th anniversary with a trip alone, leaving our 6 and 3 year-olds at home. It was very difficult to arrange a trip because (1) I just started a new job and have no accrued vacation and lots of work; and (2) we don’t really have any willing and able family members to watch our children. The two living grandmas are elderly and can’t really handle the kids for more than one day. We originally planned a 3-night trip to the Riu Yucatan for the first weekend it opened (July 8) but canceled because Hurricane Dennis was moving by and we were concerned we would have 3 days of wind and rain. We re-booked for the Gala Resort the following weekend (7/15) and canceled at the last minute as Hurricane Emily was approaching. At this point, my wife was of the opinion that this trip just wasn’t supposed to happen. We decided to try one more time. Very few rooms were available anywhere because of many other travelers canceling and re-booking. We ultimately decided to spend a little more money and splurge on the Riu Palace. I know there has been a lot of Apple Vacation bashing because of the way its reps handled Hurricane Emily cancellations, evacuations, etc. I for one had no problems canceling and re-booking twice without penalty. We also re-booked the original trip once when the price went down $100 pp, all without problems. I did have to use 2 different travel agents because my regular agent, who operates a one-person shop, was actually in Playa with a large group just prior to Emily hitting. Our trip went off without a hitch. We ended up with a tag team of grandparents and one of our old babysitters watching our kids for the 3 nights we were gone. FLIGHT – USA 3000, 6:00 a.m. flight – Got aisle seats, took off and landed early and had a free movie if you wanted to watch (Madagascar (sp)). No complaints, other than the breakfast being pretty bad. Flight home, landed an hour early, watched some movie with Bernie Mac and Ashton Kutcher. It was stupid, but help pass the time. Again, an inedible meal, supposedly chicken teriyaki. ARRIVAL AT CUN AIRPORT – Immigration and customs were quick at 8:30 in the morning and were outside in a small van by about 9:00 a.m. TRANSFER – Had to wait awhile for van to be filled up and made two fairly quick stops at Secrets and Paradisus, and then a smooth ride to Playacar, by about 10:30. CHECK-IN – Quick and easy by a very attractive clerk who explained the reservation system, towel cards, safe locks, etc. while we sipped some Mango juice. In my opinon, the best thing about RIU Palace check-in is that the lobby has AC! Note that ala carte reservations are now available from 10:00 a.m. to noon and you can reserve for the next day. There is no line by 11:30 and there are some spots remaining. Also, at this time you do not need to select a dinner seating time and table for Don Julian. Show up whenever you want. Our room was not ready, but the clerk said it would be in about 45 minutes. Given our past experiences, we though that really meant about 2 hours. She told us we could still catch continental breakfast at one of the Beach restaurants. We had a nice breakfast consisting of more than the usual continental variety. There were eggs, bacon, hash browns, etc., as well as fresh juices and coffee. By the time we finished breakfast and had a drink at the lobby bar, (a little over an hour) our room was ready. As I walked up to the desk, 2 different clerks were calling my name and telling me our room was ready. ROOM - I requested a courtyard view, noting it was a special anniversary trip, but did not get one. Our view of the neighboring Viva Wyndam resort, which is heavily damaged, closed and undergoing heavy reconstruction. I was not happy, but did not complain. I later received a call from Stephanie in Public Relations apologizing for not being able to provide a courtyard view and asking if there was anything else they could do for us, such as reservations at one of the ala cartes. We already had a reservation at Sir Edwards, so I said “no thanks.” I thought the gesture was nice. We also received a call from the desk, simply asking if all of the room amenities were functioning. I also thought this was also a nice gesture. Everything worked fine. AC was super cold. No general musty smell in the room, but the couch smelled bad, as noted by another recent report…kind of like musty body odor smell. We threw a towel over the couch to sit. The look and design of the room was by far the best we have had in the Playa area. Whoever decided to have a hallway entry with an extra heavy wooden door is a genius. He or she eliminated one of the most common complaints about Playa resorts…hallway and outdoor noise from doors slamming and yelling. If you kept the inside door to the hallway shut, you could not hear anything in the hall. If you left it ajar, it was noisy. We also liked the room size and sunken living area…but try to remember there is a step down, especially after a day of drinking. I also loved the mini bar. Drinks were cold and being able to enjoy a Smirnoff and tonic or a Bacardi and cola in my room was really nice. One slight complaint – none of the nearby ice machines were working, but I had the lobby bartender fill our ice bucket a couple times with no complaints. The water was hot and had great pressure and lighting was adequate. Maid service was also adequate…only one towel animal, but who cares. I hope the Riu management is not reading this, but we took our towel animal home. Sorry, but it was the perfect souvenir for our 3-year old daughter. It was a pig (I think) and had little stick-on eyes . We tipped the maid $2 a day and also put $2 in the minibar the first day. It was stocked each of our two full days we were there. RESORT LAYOUT – We absolutely loved the layout and look of the resort. It truly looks like a palace. The lobby is breathtaking and the courtyard is very inviting and beautiful. You could hardly tell a hurricane had hit, with the exception of the missing palms and the large buoy washed up on the beach. The Riu is the perfect size for the number of guests staying there. It never seemed crowded at any of the bars, the pool or the beach. I think I now prefer the openness of the Riu Palace, as opposed to the natural jungle setting of resorts like the IB* and Palladium. I think it also makes for fewer insects in the evening. The other great thing about the Palace is that you can walk to the Lobby or to the beach/pool area without ever actually going outside the buildings. You can walk down the hallways, which are shaded and breezy. I really enjoyed this, as the heat is intense, especially when drinking and carrying all of your beach gear. BEACH – Incredible. The Riu built back far enough that, whatever erosion has occurred, there is still plenty of beach. Same white sand and beautiful water from previous trips, but a little murky, perhaps from the hurricane. Also, more seaweed than I remember, but still much nicer than the sand and water at the Sunscape Tulum and Palladium, in my opinion. The beach never seemed that crowded at the Palace, but the Riu Yucatan and some of the other Playa resorts were very crowded. The Palace actually has too many loungers on the beach. I would suggest that they stack about 50 or so off to the side and unstuck them only if a need arises. Shade is hard to come by with the palm trees being stripped, but this will remedy itself eventually. It would be nice to have some umbrellas or Palapas for shade. My wife prefers the sun and kept me out on the beach and in the sun most of each day. I was applying sunscreen non-stop and only the lower half of my face burned, which I attribute to lots of time in the water with the sun reflecting. The beach bar is a short walk and was staffed by Roy, the most friendly and efficient bartender we have ever encountered. He will remember your drink preference and will gladly fill a giant Bubba Keg with Corona or anything else you want, then comment “See you in 10 minutes.” There was a bee problem at the resort and poor Roy was swatting them with sticky board throughout the day. Please tip Roy a few bucks. He does his job without complaint under extreme conditions of heat. The only beach deeper and wider than the RIU Palace is the GALA. I would say it has the best beach of the Playacar resorts. There are tons of loungers and still room for 2 beach volleyball courts, a beach soccer field and just plain open space. The IB* beach was also crowded and nowhere near as deep as when we stayed there. Going further down (south?), the Royal Hideaway beach is very small and the Allegro (closed for hurricane repairs) is extremely small. Quite frankly, the Allegro needs to be completely rebuilt, with pool area moved away from the beach. There cannot be more than 50 or 60 feet from the resort’s flood wall to the water. POOL – The Riu Palace pool is not very impressive. It is really just two semi-circles around the pool bar areas. There is room to expand, either on the beach or in the middle area of the pool bar area, where there is seating that is never used (too hot). I think the Palace should consider adding a pool, maybe an adult-only right on the beach. We found the pools at all of the RIU’s to be too small for the number of guests. However, to our surprise, the Palace pool was never that crowded. We only had trouble finding loungers on one occasion in the early afternoon. The towel game is played here, despite a posted rule prohibiting the reservation of chairs. There were kids, but they were pretty well-behaved, much better than ours would have been. The quiet side of the pool is just that…quiet and relaxing. There is quick drink service around the pool and I alternated between the bar and using wait service. I tipped a few times, whenever I had some singles with me, but there is no pressure to tip. The pools at the Riu Playacar and Riu Yucatan were extremely crowded and noisy, with lots of kids. The Yucatan had lots of kids, loud music and shouting. We are very glad we did not end up staying at the Yucatan. I think what happens is that the Riu Tequila guests use the beach at the Yucatan and then end up hanging out at the Yucatan pool and pool bars, which makes for way too many people. We have stayed at the IB* twice and never had crowds like at the Yucatan. I am a pretty frugal person, but for the extra money it costs to stay at the Palace, it is well worth it for the lack of crowding. BARS – All stocked with premium liquor for the asking. You get no good stuff hidden under the bar or frowns when you ask for Absolut Vodka or Beefeater Gin. The bartenders are eager to give you a double and even ask most of the time. I got really toasted on Absolut on the rocks with a splash of lime juice the first full day we were there, which did not please my wife. I stuck to mostly beer the next day and paced myself. The drink menus are nice, especially for those that want tropical drinks, but don’t’ know what to ask for. My wife liked the Blue Corals and they tasted pretty much the same at all the bars. The lobby bar is air conditioned and a great place to hang out during the day or early evening. There are way too many smokers for my enjoyment as the evening progresses and it really smells of cigarette smoke late at night or early in the morning, when the AC is turned off. SERVICE – Incredible, no comparison to other resorts we have stayed. The service in the Don Julian Buffet was great. We never had to wait for someone to take our drink order and once taken, it was acted upon. I had a huge problem with the service in the Palladium buffet last year. It ranged from inconsistent to poor. There were often waiters standing around while we needed drinks, including morning coffee. We would have gladly served ourselves, but that was not an option. At the RIU, service at breakfast and dinner was perfect. I tipped our waiter Hernandez a couple bucks each night at Dinner. He never let my Champagne glass run dry and brought my wife a bottle of Pepsi faster than lightning. I also tipped the wait captain, who pretty much backed up Hernandez when it was busy. Even though you don’t have to sit at the same table each night, I would encourage everyone to do so. It is nice to get the same waiter each night. The courtyard drink service in the evening is nothing short of spectacular. When you sit down someone will take your drink order within less than a minute. The waiters are literally racing around with drinks and checking on you. If you indicate that you are fine, a piece of paper is placed under your ash tray to indicate that the waiter checked on you. There seems to be a very structured head waiter/waiter/busboy system, where service standards almost too strict. For example, we saw a cocktail napkin fly off a waiters tray when he was moving fast through the courtyard. The head waiter/supervisor immediately picked it up and then gave a pretty menacing glance at the waiter, presumably for letting this happen. We thought “lighten up, we couldn’t be happier with the service.” FOOD – Last, but not least, for the most part we enjoyed the food. Food is a very personal and subjective subject. My wife is sort of picky and really not that interested in food on vacation, other than getting basic nutrition and having some good ice cream and desserts available. I love to eat, especially things that are not available at home. In Mexico, I love to eat Ceviche, smoked salmon, grilled fish, etc. The Palace did not disappoint either of us. My wife was very happy with the breakfasts, burgers and guac at lunch and, especially the ice cream bar at dinner. She also enjoyed fajitas at Dinner, which are available in the Mexican area each night. I actually enjoyed breakfast the least. They pretty much had the standard fare, but no Mexican items and no changes. The bacon and omlettes were fine, as were the many juices and smoothies available. I was surprised and disappointed that there was no smoked salmon at breakfast. Lunches were great at the La Traviata and El Patio. We preferred El Patio, but it closes just before 3:00 and only managed lunch there one of the 3 days, based on our late lunch schedule preference. Both restaurants have the standard hot dogs and hamburgers, but La Traviata also has pizza and pasta, neither of which appeal to me at lunch. El Patio has grilled and fried fish (fish tacos rock), along with Mexican dishes. Both restaurants have really good salad bars. My wife enjoyed a chicken Caesar salad one day and she is usually afraid to eat salad in Mexico. Given our short time at the Palace, we only ate 2 dinners at Don Julian, but enjoyed both very much. I could almost live off the salad bar…smoked salmon, whole salmon, fresh tuna, deviled eggs with caviar, hearts of palm. I had a whole plate of cold items before I even checked out what else was available. The foot long homemade bread sticks go great with smoked salmon and capers. Each night they had Paella, one night with rice, the other with pasta. They always had grilled chicken breasts and beef steaks, as well as many potatos and vegetable casseroles. They had a carving station with roast beef and turkey, as well as freshly prepared pasta. There was not much cooked seafood, other than squid and what was in the Paella, but I suspect this changes if you are there 7 nights. There were many wine choice, but I stuck to Champagne at dinner. If you try to sample everything, you would probably get bored over a week’s stay. If you eat something different each night, you should be fine. The ice cream buffet is awesome. 5 different flavors and every topping imaginable. There is a chocolate fountain where diners can dip marshmallows. It doesn’t actually taste very good, but it is fun to watch people smile and use it. There is a more fudge-like chocolate topping for the ice cream. Prior to this, my favorite dinner buffet was at IB* Tucan/Quezel. The RIU Palace was similar and just slightly better. We ate at Sir Edwards our second evening and were not very impressed. The food is served banquet style. Everyone’s appetizers are brought out at the same time, then salads, then entrée, etc. I had some stomach issues, which I am blaming on the muscles Rockafeller(sp). My lamb was okay. Quite frankly, I was kind of toasted and my wife was upset with me on this evening, so it did impact our meal in a negative way. If we would have been in a better mood, we probably would have gone to the buffet for ice cream after this meal. ENTERTAINMENT – We only watched one dancing show. It was fairly brief and entertaining. Our last night they had a pretty good band playing in the courtyard from about 9 to 10, followed by the show and then another few songs. It would have been nice if the band had played until midnight, but I guess some guests might complain. There were quite a few older couples there who tended to go back to their rooms early. This is definitely not an evening party place, but you can cross the street to the Tequila for that. We checked out the disco, which was pretty much a teens and 20’s crowd. Note that the walk from the Palace lobby to the disco at the Tequila is probably shorter than the walk from most Tequila guestrooms. Also, there is late night food available outside the Tequila, including fresh grilled burgers. OVERALL – This is by far the best resort we have stayed at to date. I highly recommend it. Other than the minor complaints noted herein, this was a nearly perfect experience. If we can afford it, we may return with our kids next Summer. I know it is not the most kid-friendly resort, but I think if we alternate between the Yucatan pool and Palace beach, our kids won’t disturb the other guests too much. If too expensive, we may try the GALA next year, as its beach is definitely the best in Playacar. This site was, as always, very helpful in planning our trip. Be wary of extremely negative reviews and reviews where it is obvious that the traveler is not accustomed to staying in the particular region. Many of the things complained of (e.g. no ocean view rooms, only domestic beer) are pretty much standard for most resorts in this area and such information is commonly known and available if you do your research. Often, extremely negative reviews are the result of unpleasant surprises and isolated negative experiences. I always look for the trends and discount overly postive and negative reviews.

Reviews.Title: “5 Stars All The Way Around!!!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: From the moment we arrived, we were pampered and treated like royalty. The room had a beautiful balcony with ocean view. Rooms were cleaned twice each day, very clean facility. EXCELLENT customer service from the bars, restuarants, and hotel staff. We never had to wait for a drink! Even the Olympus activity planner in the hotel was great. We had a terrific time and would definetely stay at Riu Palace Las Americas again and again and again! I would recommend this all inclusive hotel resort to anyone!

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous resort! I don't understand the negative reviews...”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We had our wedding and honeymoon at the Riu Palace Mexico in July, 2005. We loved it and our group of 8 guests loved it as well. They raved about how it was the best vacation they had ever taken. Many of them have traveled to various resorts and taken cruises and they agreed that the Palace was exceptional. I really don't understand the negative reviews. I've read complaints about the TV stations, but when I'm on vacation, TV is one of the last things on my mind. I can watch it at home. Besides, there were plenty of English speaking channels and I have never stayed at a hotel in the states that offered an overabundance of translated channels for foreign guests. Also, there is a spa. The spa staff is wonderful. I had a wonderful body exfoliation. It is located near the pool. The front desk staff will direct you there. Myself and three other guests did get sick, but we attributed it to an overindulgence in alcohol and food. We all agreed not to let it get the best of us. We took some medication, stayed away from alcohol for a day or so, and we all felt great! The disco is not very far. It is right across the street at the Tequila (short walk). Seems to cater to a younger (high school/college) crowd, but it's nice to check out. If you are interested in more night life, catch a cab into the city. Food: The food is really good. Everyone in our group always found something they liked. One person didn't care too much for the food and ordered from Domino's, but they readily admitted that they were a picky eater. Don Julian's is open with a buffet for all meals. For breakfast, you can choose from eggs, fruits, juices, pancakes, french toast, sausage, bacon, cereal, breads, etc. I never ate lunch there. We ususally ate at El Patio (Mexican foods, chips/salsa) or La Traviata (pizza, lasagna, etc). They both have salad bars and have an open patio style. You could always find hamburgers, hot dogs, and french fries, too! At dinner we ate at Don Julian's some evenings. There was usually a theme such as seafood, martinis, chocolate fondue fountain, Mexican, etc. Again there was something for everyone. The desserts were OK, but we usually stuck to the ice cream sundae bar. The specialty restaurants were usually easy to make reservations for, plus it gave us an excuse to get up and get the day started. La Bodega is a wonderful Brazilian steakhouse that serves tender meats in a cool Brazilian setting. If you like Japanese food, Miyagi's has a nice upscale setting. I never ate at Sir Edward's, but one person in our group informed me that the lamb was wonderful. POOL: Nice size, always clean and at a comfortable temperature, and never overcrowded. BEACH: The staff cleans the beach every morning. The water is turquoise and feels wonderful. We were warned not to buy silver jewelry from the vendors on the beach. You can go into the city (5th ave) and find beautiful jewelry and other products (only a $5.00 cab ride). ROOM: Cleaned daily and the staff does a great job. We tipped every day and had some form of towel art each day. Others in our group didn't tip and they did not have any towel art. The fridge is stocked daily with Pepsi, Diet Pepsi, 7Up, bottled water, Corona, etc. The liquor dispenser is available. Some reviews have noted that there is nothing to mix with, but we assumed that we should use the beverages in the fridge and it worked out great. A bottle opener is supplied as well. The bathroom is a nice size. The water pressure in our second room was great. We were upgraded to a new room the day after we arrived. On the day of our wedding, the room was decorated with ballons and flowers. WEDDING: Beautiful place for a wedding. The coordinators were so helpful and they accommodate large and small weddings. GROUNDS: We arrived only a few days after Hurricane Emily hit. The place looked great. It was very clean. The flowers were down and some of the tops of the palm trees were a little bare, but hey, a hurricane had just hit. The things that RIU could control looked great. Last note: Our driver to the airport told us that the staff is only paid $5/day on average! Even though RIU tells you not to, we were so glad that we had tipped the maids, bartenders, wait staff, etc. They work much harder than what they are paid, if that's true. If you are considering this resort, I would strongly suggest that you visit!

Reviews.Title: “Another amazing vacation in paradise”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Riu Palace from July 29th to August 5th. We were two families 9 people in total. This was our second time returning for our family and a first time for the family we came with. All of us agreed by the end of our week stay that this was the most relaxing and beautiful vacation we have ever taken. Here are a few tips to help you out: The Front Desk: This may be our ONLY complaint area about the hotel. We arrived to check in at about 3:00 pm and they told us the rooms would not be availabe until 4 pm. This was not such a big deal because we were starving and went to eat at the beach front restaurant, which by the way was delicious. They gave us the keys to our room at 4pm. We had reserved four rooms and one of them was occupied when we went in, so we went back to the front desk and they apologized for the mistake and gave us the room right next door. One major complaint we had was that the front desk forgot to give us the key to the safe in the room so my mother had $100 stolen from her purse in the room on one of the days. After the incident we went and requested a key and they looked at us shocked and responded with "wow you didnt get one at check-in?" This is our only warning....ask for the safe key!! Other than this, our stay went much more smoothly. The Rooms: The rooms at the palace are very spacious and immaculately clean. Our room never smelled musty although our couch in the sitting area did smell a little damp but that was taken care of after we let them know. The shower in one of our rooms was leaking...we never complained about it but I think the maid noticed it and had it fixed which was much appreciated. We left daily tips for the maid and she always made towel animals in each of our four rooms (1090, 1118, 1086, and 1112). For my mother's birthday they decorated the entire room with balloons and surprised her, it was a very nice gesture that the hotel staff made for her. Every evening the maids would come by and asked if we needed extra towels which was nice even though we didnt really need them. The air conditioning in the rooms was very powerful and made if very comfortable for sleeping. The beds were a little hard but not a big deal, just drink some tequila from the mini bar and you will have no problems sleeping!! The Beach: The beach is absolutely gorgeous. We had sunny days our whole week and never any rain except for a few sprinkles at night. Turqouise waters clear to the floor and schools of fish swimming everywhere, it was truly a paradise. We never had any problems finding beach chairs and the shade provided from the palm trees was always great. We were all very nervous before going because we thought hurricane Emily had destroyed the beach, but the Palace's beach was completely intact and it seemed untouched! White sand everywhere and very refreshing ocean water makes it so that you never want to leave the beach. If you walk to the right of the Rui Palace, go all the way down past the last hotel (probably a half a mile or less) and there is a very beautiful deserted beach with blue water and white sand...the perfect setting for one of those corona commercials. I just hope it stays undeveloped. Trust me when I say this, I have traveled all over the world and never have I seen a beach this beautiful. It is like a dream. I could go on and on about it but I will just let you see it to believe it because words cannot describe the paradise. The Grounds: Again, we were apprehensive because we expected the hurricane to have left a mess, but when we got to the palace it looked perfect. Except for a few "balding" palm trees, the Palace grounds looked perfect. We couldnt even tell that there had been a hurricane, absolutely incredible. The landscaping is quite breathtaking and very much picture worthy. The Riu Palace is by far the best and most beautiful of the hotels in Playacar by comparison. There are always people sweeping, cleaning, and manicuring the landscape everytime with a smile and welcoming words for you. The pool looked nice although I can't comment too much because I never set foot in it. Why go to the pool when you have such a beautiful beach right in front? There is a swim up bar and also a seperate pool bar that we went to everyday when leaving the bach in the evening with a nicely stocked nacho bar and a popcorn machine...very convenient for a late afternoon drink and snack. The Food: The food at this place is absolutely extraordinary. Whoever disagrees with this had not traveled or tasted what real food is like because this is it my friends. Not once did any one of the nine of us get sick in any way, and trust me when I say we ate and drank our all inclusive's worth. The buffet at the Don Julian Restaurant is very very good and the food never gets old. One of the nights they had was Mexican night where it was a Mexican theme food with mariachis...very nice. The A-la-carte restaurants were also very good. You dont have to wake up early anymore to make reservations because they finally allow you to reserve between 10 am and 12 PM. We went to Sir Edwards on the second night for my Mother's birthday and they had decorated our whole table and the waiters then came out and sang "La Mananita" for her as the whole restaurant sang along. It was hilarious but very special to her. By the way, the waiters there are very keen on getting everyone drunk so be prepared! Another one of the restaurants was the new Japanese one called Miyagi. Needless to say, the food was excellent. Top notch Sushi and chicken teriyaki kabobs with tempura ice cream, all very very good. The atmosphere and decor even looks authentically Japanese ( I have been to Japan and can vouche for it). El Patio is the restaurant buffet on the beach for lunch but at night it turns into a Mexican A La Carte. I ordered the beef fajitas and they were incredible. Others in our party ordered the salmon and also thought it was fantastic. The meat itself was very soft and cooked to perfection. DO NOT doubt that the food at the Palace is absolutely extraordinary. On one of the occasions the chef even came out to our table during lunch and described to us in detail what that night's dinner buffet at Don Julian would be offering. He even kindly offered to make us whatever we wanted at anytime even if it was not on the menu...talk about service! Drinks: I don't know what most people complain about, but the Palace is DEFINATELY not stingy with alcohol. Every drink we ordered, whether it was cocktails or mixed drinks or beer were always very well loaded with alcohol. If you want more in your drink, you can ask and the awesome waiters and bar tenders have no problem in practically handing you the bottle. Roy is one of the waiters at the beach bar and he is EXTREMEMLY friendly and good at what he does. Ask him for anything and he will make it with a smile every time. Just remember, tipping these people a dollars goes a very long way and they will remember you for the rest of your stay. The mini bar in the room was always fully stocked with Bacardi Rum, Jose Cuervo tequila, Presidente Brandy, and Smirnoff Vodka. The fridge had bottles of Corona along with water bottles and various soft drinks. They restocked the fridge every single day. It was like living as a drunken king at the Palace! On some days there were even servers going around the beach offering tropical drinks to people...that was something new that I didn't remember from last year. Entertainment: This is the part where the Riu Palace can get a bit boring, but have no fear because Palace guests are free to use any of the other Riu resorts surrounding the area. For the younger crowd in our group, we went across the street to the Riu Tequila to enjoy drinks, shows, and a cool night club with a nice atmosphere for dancing and having fun. The best is being able to meet so many people from around the world. It is a great spot where all cultures come together to have fun. The Riu Yucatan has a lot of great activites during the day which you can also use such as volleyball, waterpolo, dancing, darts, etc...never a dull moment over there. The Riu Palace is more of a calm atmosphere with a relaxation mode setting. I like that beacuse you can relax but also have fun in the other hotels. The best part is that Riu Palace guests are allowed to use the other Riu hotels but the other guests cannot use the Palace....pure exclusivity keeping lower crowd numbers both at the Palace's beach and restaurants. All in all, there is always something to do if it's not jetski's, parasailing, snorkeling, or katamaraning. The Palace along with the other Riu resorts has a lot of great water activities to choose from. Our group did pretty much all of them. The Spa/Gym: Out of our group of 9 people, 7 of us did massages at the spa. $50 each for a 50 minute swedish massage...definately worth it and I highly recommend it. We all loved it. There is also a hot tub that you can use before your "spa treatment" located on the terrace that overlooks the ocean, very spectacular. The gym is not anything grand but it is nicely airconditioned and well equipped for the most part. Much better than other gyms in other resorts I have stayed in around the Riviera Maya area. I don't know where some people comment on the fact that the hotel does not have a spa...maybe they didnt look well enough because there most definately was a spa with a sauna, hot tubs, salon, massages, everything. All in all it was an incredible week. We are all planning our return trip for next year because the friends we made both with the staff and other foreigners left us with unbelieveable memories of a great vacation. The hotel staff really goes the extra step beyond their job requirements to make you laugh and enjoy your stay. Enjoy and Hasta La Vista!!!

Reviews.Title: “Dream Vacation”
Reviews.Author: AnnaBana
Reviews.Content: I am a 25 year old newlywed who stayed at to the Riu Palace July 26th – August 2nd. I found SEVERAL incorrect comments made in some reviews I have read, so I feel, since I was just there, I should dispel some of the false comments. Here they go: First of all, there IS room service. Simply look in the drawer underneath the television, they would see a menu for breakfast room service. Second of all, there are drinks brought to your room…if they’re not already in your fridge, that is! We have friends who asked for a different type of liquor that was not already in the dispensers, and an entire bottle was brought to them immediately. Third, there is food to be found 24-7: My husband and I were hungry at 2 am and when we referred to our food service schedule sheet that we received upon check in, we found that in the lobby bar, there was a large table with sandwiches and other snacks…as well as a fully functioning—WELL LIT—bar. Fourth, if you simply ask the folks at the restaurant, they do allow you to bring food to your room. My husband did so for me when we were rushing to get ready for a snorkeling trip at 7 in the morning. Fifth, I also noticed that the drinks seemed to need a little weak, so I simply ASKED, “Bartender, do you think I could have a double?” Sure wasn’t too difficult to simply ask. Sixth, regardless of WHERE in the world you eat, if it is not the American food you are used to, it can tend to upset a weak stomach. So just come prepared with pepto, tums and immodium. I had a little heartburn for 2 days, but of course, found that it was a bit more enjoyable to endure on the beach or by the pool instead of whining in my bedroom. I must say, the food was absolutely delicious, and I couldn't get enough of it, hence the likely reason for my discomfort...And just so that it is clear, I live in the city, and enjoy eating out several times a week. I know what good food is, and I can say it can certainly be found there. Their menu does a great job at appealing to many different palates. Seventh, there certainly is a full service spa and salon (with services such as manicures and pedicures, and hair cutting, coloring, waxing…). I happened to get a VERY enjoyable massage there…and as far as a disco, it was a brief. 5 minute stroll across the street to the Tequila. Personally, I actually prefer that so that I don’t have to listen to the pounding music while trying to sleep. In fact, that is why I chose the Riu Palace, so that I don’t have to endure loud and obnoxious people that tend to migrate toward those places. Eighth, there IS a beach bar, just a 25 second walk from your lounge chair (heaven forbid anyone actually get up and walk), and I also happened to get some very delicious drinks from the kind waiters who were enduring the heat on the beach to pass around some drinks. Ninth, it is correct, there are no umbrellas at the beach, but previous to Emily, the palm trees provided 100% shade instead of the partial shade seen when I was there, hence no need for the umbrellas. Tenth, there were plenty of mixers to go with the alcohol in the room—tonic water, sodas, and if not, the front desk is very obliging to bring up what you need. Eleventh, the small television across the room was across from the couch, where many people like to watch TV…and I enjoyed a few good movies on the Hallmark channel (not cheesy like our American Hallmark channel). Twelfth, I have heard this in many reviews, and had NO CLUE what the people were talking about: I had no problem AT ALL seeing in the shower, even though there wasn’t a light in there. All in all, I had the time of my life. The ONE negative comment I could make would be that the heat was a little too much for me (hallelujah the rooms are air conditioned), and I would recommend going November or December through May. My husband and I walked along the beach and also drove through Playacar, and found that by far, Riu Palace was the best of them all. Definitely go!

Reviews.Title: “Consistently Outstanding Resort with Wonderful Employees & Service”
Reviews.Author: LeopoldButtersStotch
Reviews.Content: My wife & I stayed for a short 5 night stay from July 30 - August 4, 2005. This was our third time at RIU Palace and our 7th stay in the Mayan Riviera. Let me first start off by saying there is no PERFECT resort. All of them have an issue or two, with RIU Palace being no different. We have tried to stay at a 5 or 6 star each trip and have tried a few of the adults only, which we liked. We felt that even though RIU Palace is not adults only, there are not that many kids there. (Before we get bashed...YES, we do have children). Anyhow, I will not bore everyone with the obvious details, but let me higlight a few points: RIU Palace is in fantastic shape considering a category 4 hurricane went through 2 weeks ago. The ONLY remnants at the RIU Palace were stripped off palm trees which we all saw the pictures of and MAYBE the loss of a few, unnoticeable yards of beach. Other than that, you could not tell. This is even more amazing since the resort directly to the north (Viva Maya Wyndam) is CLOSED and the amount of lost vegetation at the RIU Yucatan & Tequila. Don't worry though if you plan on going to the Tequila or Yucatan, both are functioning at 100%, except the vegetation. The Yucatan has done a very good job with the renovations and actually has a pool area nicer than the Palace now. The Beach is still wonderful, large with crystal clear water and alot to do. We spent an inordinant amount of time on the beach and in the ocean since we went to Aventura Spa last year and spent a week at a pool, since they have no beach. (We also got tired of 8 year olds cannonballing over our heads at the pool while their parents laughed, but more on that later). The beach bar was NEVER damaged as some reports said after Emily and the 8 ton buoy, while still there on the beach, is really not that big (and it still lights up and flashes at night). And the reports of the "big glass above the bar broke during the hurricane" are also completely false. First there is no big glass above the bar, everything was secured prior and it was a hurricane, not an earthquake. Rooms - RIU Palace has some of the better standard rooms in Riviera Maya, all marble and ceramic tile with GREAT, I MEAN GREAT housekeeping service with nightly turndown. We would go to breakfast at 8:15 AM and the room would be done when we got back. The Air conditioning seemed to work better this year and was cooler, for some reason. We also finally figured out the slight musty smell after 3 trips there (it never did bother us anyhow, but some folks make a big deal out of it) The sofa loveseat in the step down sitting area absords moisture and sea air all year with no de-humidifier - that is what smells musty!! - Again No big deal. Service - Again, out of all the resorts we stayed at, the service at the RIU Palace is the best. And I mean better, yes better than The Royal Hideaway where we had our own concierge. The RIU Palace's attention to detail is meticulous, from scrubbing the tile in the courtyard several times a day to the way the drink menus should be placed in the holders on the tables. Everyone greets you with a smile no matter what and they are very, very friendly to all guests, no matter what pains in the you know what the guests can be. The resort, like always was at capacity, with its normal collection of several nationalities. But again, the resort never feels overcrowded. I personally love meeting folks from Britain, Germany, Netherlands, etc, etc. And another point...please don't get caught up in the whole political/world events/everyone hates the USA thing. People are there to have a GOOD time, not discuss the United Nations. They really don't care - regardless what the media leads you to believe. The Brits are some of the BEST - when the subject of the London bombings did come up very briefly, this gentleman from the UK said one thing....."Now, it is our turn to get those --------".....nuff said. The Food - This is where I can never truly fall in love with the RIU Palace. The food is good to very good for an all inclusive, but I am not a big buffet person and the food at the buffet begins to all taste alike after a while. The food is the sole reason we visit Royal Hideway, Aventura Spa, Moon Palace, etc so we can have good ala carte options for dinner. Now, as far as the ala carte goes, they have recently changed the reservation system so listen up everyone...... Ala Carte (lets call then non-buffet) reservations are now made each morning between 10:00 am and 12:00 noon, not 7-9 am like in the past. And you can book the next day in addition. I personally like the old method, I always got what I wanted because I would set the alarm, run down at 6:50 am, be first get the reservation than run back to bed. Now, there is a line of 30-60 people which starts forming at 9:40 AM and everyone is mad because they want to be at the beach or need to leave for a tour. Adn let me tell you something, the curent day is practically filled very early from folks booking from the day before. So you can be one of the first in line and not get anything for the current night. I understand there is no perfect system, I actually liked the old one. The other problem is that the two best non-buffets are very, very small, seating only 40 people each. (Sir Edward & Miyagi). I call them non-buffets because a true ala-carte allows you to come anytime, not at just 6:30 & 9:00. Overall the food at Sir Edwards & Miyagi was very good, but Miyagi was way too slow for what you got. This actually was not the restaurant's fault but the inconsiderate guests who came in groups of 10 with kids 20 minutes late and expected everyone to wait for them since all the food comes out in courses. My best advice is to try alot of foods and be open minded. Don Julian, the buffet had great carving stations every night and pasta stations - it was the skillet meats at the main buffet that all tasted alike. Breakfast was exactly the same everyday, but that is expected at all buffets. Again, we prefer sit-down ala cartes where you can order off of a menu for dinner. RIU Palace as a whole, does a very good job with what they have to work with. We went in late July this year for family reasons, we usually go in early May and there were a few big differences.....Number one was bugs. I realize I am in the jungle in July but in 7 trips we never encountered that many mosquitos ever. Please do yourself a favor and bring bug spray. This also ruins the dinner experience at La-Traviata and El Patio, the two outdoor restaurants near the pool. Second was school was out and we never encountered that many kids at a resort that really isn' tfamily oriented. I cannot fathom why a family would go to RIU Palace with no child amenities when there is a great Iberostar complex two doors down and a fantstic 6 star Iberostar 15 miles north with lazy river, kid clubs, suites, ala cartes, etc, etc, etc. We would never take our kids here...period. They would be bored in my opinion, which would lead them to sit at the swim up bar all day order food and non-alcoholic drinks and spill it all in the pool. It would lead them to flood the bathroom at the pool, cannonball 20 times an hour off the side of the pool while honeymooners are trying to order a glass of champagne, or something like that. (those all happended). look I know they have as much rights, etc, etc, etc...but please, where are the parents??? I think the parents were waiting for a staff member to say something and no staff member is going to reprimand a guest - some it whent on and on and on. What really got interesting were the teenagers who were under 18 with the red wristbands that could not drink. Well, guess what color the other side of the red wristband is?...White. Which happens to be the same color as the adult wristbands. Again, not to beat a dead horse, but where are the parents and why would you bring a family, especially small kids, to a non-family resort? As a whole, it was a very good trip at a consistently great resort. The place has some challenges as far as dining, but the RIU Palace makes up for it in other areas. We will go back, but not in late July - When we do go back, we might try the new RIU Palace Riviera Maya scheduled to open in February, 2006. It is about 6 lots north of the current Palace between the Allegro and the Reef Club. It is going to be great.

Reviews.Title: “Riu Palace -- It really is the Corona commercial!”
Reviews.Author: deputysilva
Reviews.Content: WOW!! Well, Annabana (my wife) and I just got back last night from a week's stay at the Palace. I have lots to write but I will try to keep this as informative as possible. I've kept up with TripAdvisor for about 2 months before our stay at the palace. I have to say that most of the reviews are very correct. Our stay was from the 26th of July through the 2nd of August. Our Travel Agent booked our trip through RunAway Tours which did a fairly decent job at getting us to and from the Palace without any hiccups. The Cancun airport can be tricky when you are trying to find your driver. Do not get suckered into one of the many salesmen trying to sell you a cab ride to your destination. Be sure that when you do find your driver double check that they have a document that has your name on it. (Don't hesitate to be firm with anyone trying to be pushy, i.e (Taxi Drivers). With that said, I will begin my review of the palace. Introduction: The ride to the Palace is not much to look at. Very rural and poor. (The Hurricane that came through did very minimal damage so have no worries). As we arrived at the Palace you will understand why they call it as such! It is huge. It is clearly the best looking resort next to all of it's sizeably smaller neighbors. As we proceeded through the doors we were greeted by an extremely friendly concierge. She gave us a very detailed orientation of the grounds, where and when the meals were served, etc. We did not however, receive any welcome drink. It was fine though, we didn't even realize it until we were in our room. We were assigned to room 1147! If you can get this room, get it! It was perfect. A courtyard view, overlooking the beautiful fountains. Our room was very clean and did not smell at all musty. The A/C in the room was top notch. Almost too cold at times, but I enjoyed it as the weather in Playa del Carmen at this time is extremely hot! The beds were a little firm, I know everyone comments on this so I had to as well. We asked for a mattress pad and were none the wiser. Lots of closet space, plenty of dresser drawer space for all of your clothes and belongings. GROUNDS: After hearing very little about the damage of Hurricane Emily I was unsure about what the grounds would look like. Let me tell you that we could hardly even tell that anything happened at all. Some of the flowers from the shrubery are missing, some palm fronds were missing and that was about it. It was so clean, I couldn't believe it. The pools at the palace are very nice. They have a party side and a quiet side. Party side, of course where the bar is, has volleyball. The quiet side is where we spent most of our time, relaxing and taking in the sun! Now I will segue into the beach! BEACH: UNBELIEVABLE! Turquoise is the color of the water. The Palace has the best beach, hands down. It has the best of both worlds, shade and sun. We never had a hard time finding a lounge. The water is not only amazing in color, but the temperature is about 82 degrees! It is so warm! We took a walk down the beach on both sides of the Palace and it will make you appreciate how good you have it. Some of the other beaches are extremely busy, some have a lot of seaweed and other junk floating in the water. At the Palace, its just beautiful water and white sand. FOOD: I will be as detailed as possible. I'm sure everyone wants to know how the food was. I was very impressed with the amount of food and the presentation. I will start by telling you that you no longer have to wake up early to make reservations! You can now make reservations from 1000-1200. Much better. Don Julians which is where you will eat a lot of your meals is very good. I can only describe it as a grand buffet. It is catered more to the european pallete but it was very good. I was always able to find something yummy. Miyagi: Japanese style- Sashimi and tempura. Very tasty meal, you won't be too full though. Hey, you can always go to Don Julians if you're still hungry. Miyagis seems to be the most popular place but I wasn't totally impressed. Sir Edwards was very nice but too quiet. It was very formal. Food was very tasty, believe you me, they will try to get you drunk so be careful.... I was extremely impressed with the very underrated "La Bodega" Let me tell you, this was a feast! They serve you with 5 different kinds of meat! It was wonderful. I have never been so full in my life! Not sure if it was just me, but I was dissapointed in the dessert selection. It was pretty much just chocolate candies and little cakes. It was fine though, I couldn't eat much more after dinner anyway. Evening entertainment: After dinner everyone heads out to the courtyard to watch the live shows. We saw the Michael Jackson show which was rather interesting. Lots of dancing shows but if you want more to do after 11:00pm you'll have to venture out to 5th St. (Carlos n' Charlies or Senor Frogs). Overall: The price that you pay for the Palace is well worth it. There are so many details that this review does not do it justice. You will have to see for yourself. If I could do anything over, I would go to the Palace in March. Reason being, it was super hot during our stay. Almost too hot to do any excursions. If you go to the Yucatan Peninsula, stay at this resort. You will be well taken care of. If I've missed anything, my wife Annabana will cover it. Hope this helps.

Reviews.Title: “THIS IS THE BEST PLACE ON EARTH!!!!”
Reviews.Author: superwell
Reviews.Content: Well where to start.....the wife and I were there for our honeymoon from July 11th, to July 25th, 2005 and... This place is amazing...from when you walk in to when you check out this place rocks. The beds were hard and I knew that from the other reviews so I ordered the pads and they were delivered to me with in 1/2 hour. Beds and the room were always clean, room wasn't musty, we were in room 2063 (third floor), which over looks the fountains and is well worth the money...if you don't book it at home then slip them some money at the desk and ask them to upgrade you. While we were there the changed the rule to booking for meals..for all you lazy guys....now you book from 10am-12pm and at the lobby instead of at the restaurant. you can also book for 3 days in advance. This was a huge bonus as the waking up early wasn't an issue with me but when we got there you really don't like to wake up that early unless you were picky on the restaurant and time you wanted..don't believe everything you read here..some people are just out to make a bad name for this place. I didn't like the El Patio very much but the rest of the places are great and make excellent food. Beach: WAS amazing!!, lots of nice sand, water was great..not rocky as people say..I never went into the pool...not once....so I can't comment but the beach was great. Don't pay all this money to play in a pool....do that at home...save the money. There were always 100+ beach chairs to use..never had to wait or wake up early to get a chair.... Service: A++++ Everything I asked for I got..even asked for coconut rum in the room and bam...1/2 hour and it was in the room already..a full 750ml bottle. We got our honeymoon "kit" which was nice...got the nice towels folding into animals and that was very nice....we got about 5 made for us within the 2 weeks. Beds were turned down around 8pm every night as we has some afternoon naps and the beds were always made for the evenings. Staying for 2 weeks staff gets very freindly and shakes your hand on the way by and even some get to know you by name so it gets very cozy. I never got sick once in 2 weeks, food was always fresh and was replaced 5-6 times each in the sitting we were at. My only complait was with our sunquest tour girl, she never bent over backward once for us, even though we had some tough times with the huricane, which btw the staff took care of very well and never once did I feel unsafe and nor did we not have power, hydro or even food..as we had a hot breakfast the next morning :thumbs up: this place rocks!! I would go back in a minute and next year they are openingup the grand palace just up the street...and I think for our 5th anni. we will visit again. RIU's are top notch, then excel in everything they do, cook and clean..I have never been happier then after leaving the Riu Palace. Worth every penny and knowing then what I know now..i would of even paid more to stay here.

Reviews.Title: “The Best Wedding and Honeymoon”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I am very delayed in writing this review, however better late than never, especially b/c I used this website to decide where I was going to get married! We were married in October of 2004 and there were about 25 people down there with us, from three different places in the US and also in Canada. We were all extremley impressed with the hotel, it is absolutely stunning. The service was above average too. We did have the little towel animals in our room, my parents did not however. We figured out that if you tipped the maids every day, you got the animal towels, my parents waited until the end to tip, so no animal towels for them! Our ring bearer and flower girl were 4 and 5 years old and they had a fantastic time too. My grandmother who is 76 went parasailing and snorkeling with us, it is impossible to not have a good time there. There is plenty to do at the hotel and the other 3 that are located within walking distance. The wedding day was absolutely perfect. Weather, ceremony, flowers, nothing could have been better. There was another wedding there after ours and it rained, so the photographer made arrangements to come back the following day for the outdoor pictures, which I thought was very nice. We were upgraded to a suite free of charge for the second week we were there, which was so nice of them. The food wasn't over the top, but it was fine. I am a pretty picky eater and I had no trouble at all finding good food to eat three times a day. This is definitely not a party place, a few of our friends went elsewhere for night life, but there is live music and shows each night, but it ends around 11:00, if not before. I would recommend this resort to anyone as would all of the people we travelled with. If any of you have questions, please feel free to contact me. Hope this helped!

Reviews.Title: “Amazing RIU Palace”
Reviews.Author: hlprice
Reviews.Content: We have just got back from Riu Palace after an amazing time. We were there through the hurricane and like other reviews, the staff were brillient. Even though I was scared to death (!), they really made you feel safe. The hotel was fabulous. The food great as well as the staff being very attentive and friendly. And the beach was truely beautiful. I really do not understand people moaning about the heat and the air con as the rooms were cool but the rest of the hotel? Well, it is Mexico and summer time, what else do you expect. I also didnt feel that the drinks were watered down at all. I've been to other Carribean AI and let me tell you the drinks were NOT watered down at the Riu Palace! Please do not let some comments put you off. Its a brillient hotel and I definately recommend it to everyone, there is not one down point in my view (and I am pretty fusy!). Enjoy!!!

Reviews.Title: “great vacation the best hotel”
Reviews.Author: Yvonne,René
Reviews.Content: My wife and I (we are from Holland and are 38 and 39 years old) visited the Riu Palace Mexico from June 14 until June 29. We choose the Palace because we saw so many beautiful pictures and read al lot of positive reviews on the internet. Believe me, those positive reviews are completely true. The hotel is stunning. Everything was just perfect. The rooms are spacious with two beds pushed together. No problem for us. The beds are a little firm, but I have back problems and I slept like a rose without hurting my back. There was a nice minibar full stucked with sodas, coronas and enough bottles of water in it. They refill the bar every day. Also ther are four bottles of liquor (rum, vodka, tequila and brandy) above the minibar. Everything is included. The lobby and all the areas of the hotel were just beautiful and kept very clean. The buffet restaurant Don Julian was amazing. The food was great and there was a lot of variety. The other restaurants were also good. The Japanese restaurant is the most popular one, so for reservation you have to be there at 07.00h in the morning. The swimming pool was nice. There is a quit and a crowded side where they play volleybal. The beach was one of the most beautiful beaches I have ever seen. It was very clean. We never had problems to find two chairs any time of the day. The bars at the swimming pool and at the beach were exellent. But the best part of the hotel was the staff, and I mean the complete staff, the waiters, the bartenders, the maintenance people, the girls/boys who cleaned the rooms, the frontdesk people, everybody. They are always smiling and they greet you whenever they see you. Even if they don't get a tip, they will be friendly all the time. So take extra dollars with you and tip a lot. The staff realy deserve it. I have only one negative thing. When we were there the hotel was overbooked. Our travelagency told us that there were almost 100 rooms overbooked. This is for such a great hotel not exeptable. I hope this review will be helpful.

Reviews.Title: “Welcome To Paradise”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Welcome to Paradise was the greeting we received upon our arrival at the RIU Palace Mexico. The hotel was beautiful, the service was awesome, the people were so nice. The Ocean was a blue we have never seen before. We went for our honeymoon July 4th through July 10th. We had the best time. Can't wait to go back. Back to Paradise.

Reviews.Title: “Riu Palace Survives Hurricane Emily”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I just returned from a six-night stay at the Riu Palace, during which the area was hit by Hurricane Emily. While the damage to the building was minimal, there was substantial destruction of trees and bushes, which made the grounds a mess. Prior to the storm, the hotel was stunning, especially the landscaping, which I would expect to be replanted and resculpted in the coming weeks. Our goal of catching some R & R was certainly met at the Riu Palace, not withstanding the interruption of the hurricaine. The Palace's staff did an admirable job in preparing for the storm. We had a ground floor room and were transferred to a room on the third floor that we had to share with another couple. At first we were put-off by the move, especially the manner in which the cleaning staff rushed us out of our original room. Even though the storm was not scheduled to reach land for 10 hours, we were given no time to gather our things and were asked to leave the room immediately. Sure, the staff had a job to do, but we could have been given a warning that had given us, say, 15 minutes to pack our belongings. Other than this minor complaint, the emergency was handled incredibly well. The hotel never lost power, although the TV signal went out. We were able to sleep through the storm with mattresses on the floor whose matching boxsprings were (as we were instructed) butted up against the sliding glass doors to protect us. The next morning breakfast was served in the dining room, just hours after the storm. Here are a few pre-hurricane insights: I preface this by saying I am a rather discerning traveler, meaning that I notice (and am sometimes bothered by) things that other (less picky)people could care less about. The Palace is the most elegant hotel in the area that we saw. There were very few kids; most of the clientele were more-or-less classy Europeans or Americans, many in their 30's, 40's or 50's. Some of the other properties looked crowded, and the clientele trashy in comparison. The beach is outstanding, the nicest around, with plenty of lounge chairs and palm trees for shade. Be warned: the sun is EXTREMELY strong and you should put sunscreen on every few hours. I thought my after-shower application of SPF 30 was enough, but I wound up getting pretty badly burned, which can be a real downer when you're on vacation. The food is really very good. The main buffet restaurant was great and had plenty of selection. We liked the Japanese restaurand and Sir Edwards also. True, it isn't Michelin 5-fork quality, but who expects that at an all-inclusive? For what it is, it's excellent. Other Tripadvisor reviewers have laueded the staff as outstanding. I speak fluent spanish and found them to be pleasant and correct, but not exceedingly friendly, even though we gave extra tips (gratuities are included) from time to time. The maintance of the grounds was impressive. The maid did a great job cleaning the room, but each day seemed to find an inconvenient (for us) time to want to make up the room. The room was great, large, with a separate sitting area and couch. The bedspreads are pilly need to be replaced. The shower needs an overhead light. A vacation at the Riu Palace can get a little boring because I found that there isn't that much to do there besides relaxing near the beach and pool. Definately get out to the ruins and other attractions in the area. Take a walk to Playa del Carmen, the small town that is about a 30 minute walk from the hotel. The area is very safe and you will find good shopping, bars and restaurants. During our trip the heat made it difficult to do some of these things, so consider going when the heat isn't as oppressive. All in all I highly reccommend the Riu Palace and hope that they are able to quickly recover from Hurricane Emily. Enjoy!

Reviews.Title: “Absolutely perfect!”
Reviews.Author: dave6857
Reviews.Content: My wife and I spent our honeymoon at the RIU Palace from June 26 to July 2 and had the best time of our life. Guests are treated like royalty the entire time you are there. When we arrived our bar and fridge were fully stocked, but there was no diet pepsi. I called the front desk, and someone was at our door within minutes with several bottles. The maid service was great as our room was kept in top condition and we loved the evening towel service. The beach was great. With all of the palm trees it was easy to find a spot so my wife could lie in the sun while I enjoyed the shade, side-by-side. The food was excellent! We ate at each of the restaraunts except La Bordega. The food and service at each one was wonderful. I am 25 and my wife is 23 so we may a different view of things because of our age. I thought the drinks were great..always nice and strong! One nice thing with staying at the Palace is that you can go to all of the other RIU's around it and use their bars as well. That gives you access to about 14 bars in all. We decided to map out a bar tour and finish up at the Disoc at Riu Tequilla one evening. We also made use of the beachfront dining at Riu Yucatan for lunch serval times. The service at Riu Palace is what sets it apart. The employees really want your stay to be as wonderful as possible and do anything they can for you. If your looking for a party time kind of resort, this is not for you. If you are looking for a high-class getaway with that special someone in your life, this is the perfect place to go! We will definitely be returing!!!

Reviews.Title: “The biggest waste of money I have ever spent”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I went to this resort expecting 5 star service and food and all I can say is that the food was horrible, drinks watered down, and they only had one form of beer. I took my wife on this trip for our honeymoon and really wanted to impress her. The building itself is beautiful, the ocean in beautiful. Thats about all I can say for this resort. The people behind the front desk were limited in their ability to communicate, as well as the APPLE Vacations representatives. When I asked about upgrading because we were on a honeymoon they knew nothing about such an upgrade. I told them that I wanted to be at an ocean front view and they told me they didn't have any such rooms. When I asked what is fun and exciting to do at the resort they handed me a packet of information never explaining much of anything inside of it. I went to check into my room to find 2 double beds pushed together, a small television that does not offer movie purchasing options, a telephone that has no list of how to call the front desk or any of the other areas of the building. Every meal I ate left me more disappointed. McDonalds would have been considered elegant food if they had it. I didn't know that you could water down drinks the way they do, and if you want to make dinner reservations you have to get up and make them at breakfast (yes this is the only time that you can make a reservation for dinner meals) and if you not their before 8 am they are all booked out. ALL INCLUSIVE yeah right what a disappointment. If you take this trip good luck to you, but don't say I didn't warn you.

Reviews.Title: “You'll love the details”
Reviews.Author: JJGordon54
Reviews.Content: Stay was celebrating my wifes 50th Birthday. Playa is great for beaches and European travellers. Adds a great flavour. But what is better is The Palaces small details. The room size, the closet allowance, the towel supply, the courteous service all are top drawer. The capuccinos, the abundance and variety of the buffets, the cuisines quality in their restaurants, the coolness of the palm trees as an entrance to the fabulous beaches, the piano bar and the trumpeter, sax etc. the Weddings, the Chapel, the proximity to a great shopping experience, Playa del Carmen and best of all the staff from Eduardo, Javier, Carlos on down . They all add up to how All Inclusive is at its best. Riu Palace Mexico epitomizes where quality, value, variety and "sunfun" meet.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic Hotel & Beach”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed here for 2 weeks from 21st June to 5th July '05. We are 35 and 41 years old and went to celebrate our first wedding anniversary. We both thought the hotel was immaculate, the design of it, the grounds etc. I did think the rooms couldve done with a little TLC, new bed throws, curtains, and the bathrooms could do with upgrading. I thought the bathroom was pretty dark when taking a shower, a walk in shower would be better, i tripped twice climbing in and out of the bath to have a shower, not good for the less mobile or elderley. I took a couple of air fresheners for the room and bathroom but i didnt think it smelt musty. We enjoyed the food at the buffet that we didnt book any a la carte restauarants the second week. We didnt think they were that good apart from the Japanese. The entertainment is a bit weak, they could do with some dancing/disco afterwards, everyone tends to scurry off after the show finishes at 11pm. It would have been nice to have a dance or two. The beach is gorgeous, lots of white fluffly sand, the widest beach ive ever been on, lots of swaying palm trees too for shade if you want it.
