The weather was not too good whilst we were there, it rained a lot. I know this is the rainy season but some days it would just rain all through to night, we get enough rain in Britain! But when the sun did come out, it was very hot indeed. We both came back with tans, not the deepest however for a two week stay. We went to Chichen Itza - very long day, the coach picked us up at 7.45 am and we got back at 7.30 pm. It is a very interesting place but beware of all the sellers that come up to you every 5 seconds, that got on my nerves. My husband climbed to the top as if going to bed but came back down a little bit hesitant. Looked a bit dangerous to me, so i stopped at the bottome taking photos. We went to Xcarat for the day. What a place, this made my holiday and wish we had gone there earlier in our vacation so that we couldve gone back again. It cost us 12 dollars in a taxi from the Palace and they drop you right outside. Its 59 dollars each. There is everything in this place, the price also includes a show at night, which is spectacular. I wont say much, but you must go here, especially if you have children. We also went on a speed boat trip where you drive them yourself. I was scared to death i must admit. My husband however thought he was James Bond and just wound me up even more. It is a bit of a silly thing they have going on with the dinner reservations and should sort it. We couldnt stay at the Palace on our first night they were overbooked so we had to stay at the Royal Hideaway for one night. It was gorgeous though and apparently Brad Pitt, Jennifer Anniston and Tom Cruise stopped there, so if its good enough for them. However, the beach at the Hideaway is no way as good as the one at the Palace. We would go back but there are so many other places in the world to see. But we would try and stop at a Riu hotel for sure. Have a good time. Your holiday is what you make it.

Reviews.Title: “Just the Facts”
Reviews.Author: bigjim007
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Riu with a group of seven adults, two teens and one child. I have vacationed thoughout the islands for over 20+ years and have stayed at many high-end resorts. I mentioned this only to help put my comments into persective. Everyone has an option and here are mine: Grounds: Stunning and the best I have ever seen for a large resort ( 300+ rooms). The area is clean, well designed and simply incredible. Beach: Also Stunning - The beach has two large areas - One on the open beach and one under a great number of palm trees. Plenty of chairs and space for all. Rooms: All rooms are junior suites and are clean and spacious. My room was on the second floor with a courtyard view, this is the best location! Food: Buffet is buffet - The food was fine but nothing special. The four "high-end" resturants are average at best. Just do not expect gourment food and you will enjoy the buffet. Drinks: The number one issue with the resort - No top shelf, beer is Corona on tap only, drinks are served in small plastic cups, frozen drinks are terrible and the wine is average. Entertainment: The group does a nice job with the evening shows and daily activities. Service: Great job - Manuel is a the perfect person for his job! The front desk needs some help and Karima needs to smile more. Pool: Plenty of space and chairs - The water is very warm but clean. RIU PALACE - I hope they read these and encourage feedback! 1. Change your Beverage service to include more choices - Develop a "signiture" drink thats better then a standard mix in the bottle. 2. Have more late night snacks - Cold hamburgers and hotdogs are not he answer. 3. Fix the front desk - Too many people with no answers. 4. Change the reservation system - 7:00am on vacation is too early! 5. Teach the German guests some manners - They ignore lines and push though without concern for anyone. 6. Give Manuel a big raise! I hope this helps with your choice. I would return to the Riu Palace and look forward to this resort becoming a true five star. It is close but simply does not qualify as "five star".

Reviews.Title: “Riu Palace- The ULTIMATE place of pampering”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Riu Palace Mexico on our goneymoon from June 26-July 3 and I do not even feel I can express in words how wonderful this place was. Neither one of us had ever been to Mexico, and didn't know what to expect, but after staying at the Riu Palace, we will go back every year. I feel it is important to write a review because many people who have never been do not know what to expect, so please allow me to fill you in on what the Riu Palace has to offer. SERVICE- From the higher ups such as Karrima, and Javier to the bartender Miriam, the dining worker Bernardo, to the front door man Manuel EVERYONE at thia place treats you like royalty. It constantly amazed me how EVERYONE there did their job with such efficiency and such a smile. There was NEVER a time in which we felt we did not have good service. If I am not mistaken, the Riu has been given high ratings in customer service and they do not let you down. THE ROOMS- I was nervous about the rooms because some reviews I read said the rooms had little bugs in them and that the bathrooms were small- NOT SO. The rooms were very clean, and quite large- and there were NO bugs in sight. THE FOOD- I am a picky eater, and thought I would have trouble finding something I liked to eat instead it was the POLAR OPPOSITE. Everything to eat was great. Don Julian is the main restaurant served buffet style and there is NOT a shortage of selection- everything from steak to freah seafood, great sald bar, and an unbelievable Mexican section. La Bodega is a great Brazillian steakhouse, Sir Edward is a great restaurant where I had the best lamb ever, and if you like Oriental-Miyagi will blow you away. ENTERTAINMENT- Nightly performances that are amazing- Professional dancers and great music. Aesthetics- We checked out many other resorts while we were ther and NONE compared to the beauty or service of the RIU palace- they did not come close. LOCATION- Riu Palace is a 3 minute car ride to Playa Del Carmen, where you can shop and eat- Need I say more. The bottom line is, we met many people on our trip who said their resorts were o.k. but no one said they loved their resort. I, however, can say without a doubt that Riu Palace FAR exceeded my expectations, and we will be going back every year. I hope this helps!

Reviews.Title: “Great Honeymoon!!!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Wow! What a fantastic place. My wife and I spent our Honeymoon at the Riu between May 23-30. We had a great time. When you first enter the hotel, you enter a grand foyer with beautiful marble floors. We had arrived at the hotel after a very long flight and were able to get into our room after a small wait. The room was also fantastic. The majority of rooms are equiped with 2 double beds pushed together. There is also a nice little sitting area, with a TV. Our room was on the "1st floor" (really the 2nd floor), about half way down facing the waterfountains. Make sure you ask for a room facing the fountains or you will be facing the back side of the hotels next door. The only thing we were unhappy about, was that the rooms have thin walls. Not too big of a problem, considering it gave us something to laugh about.... The restaurants are pretty good. We ate at the buffet some nights (can't remember the name of it) and the gourmet and beach grill 2 nights each. The buffet always had a wide range of food, whether it was for breakfast, lunch or dinner. I was quite surprised that many people did not try the Mexican section as the local food was quite good. The gourmet wasn't too bad. We preferred the beach grill as men are allowed to wear shorts down there and the staff were very friendly. The first night we ate there, the waiter did a shot of Tequila with us! The one issue I have with the restaurants was having to book something in the mornings. If you are not down at the main restaurant to book by 8:30am for that evening, you will be eating at the buffet. Not the greatest thing, especially if you like to sleep in.... The pool was great. We never had a problem finding 2 chairs with an umbrella. A waiter always kept our drinks full. The beach was also nice. Again, never had problems finding 2 chairs and there are plenty of palm trees to keep you shaded. We went into the water twice. It was rough but lots of fun. The best part of the beach was the hammocks. We shared a large hammock almost every day. The only other issue we had, was that on the morning of check-out, we were up quite early to catch our flight. Unfortunately, the foyer does not have the Air Conditioning on overnight and it was bloody hot! They need to consider turning on the AC earlier in the morning.... Overall, the hotel is stunning and the staff extremely friendly. We had a fantastic time and look forward to going back in the future.

Reviews.Title: “who could ask for more”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: my husband and myself stayed at the palace may 23rd -6th june, we were celebrating our 25th wedding anniversary. from the moment we arrived the standard of service we recieved was second to none. food- where do i start, endless choice in the buffet, we did eat at sir edwards that was great, wasn't keen on the steak house (steak tough) but hey we certainly didn't go hungry!! rooms- beautiful and immaculate, we got back to our room one afternoon to find it full of red and white heart shaped balloons and fresh flowers. what an anniversary treat!! beach-beautiful we never had a problem finding a lounger no matter what time of day we decided to go, neither did we have to wait long before we were served cocktails pool- perhaps a little on the small side but even so a welcome break from the midday heat. on the whole this holiday was great, the property is stunning and the service was outstanding. if you are due to visit this wonderful place im sure you'll agree so enjoy. if your thinking of going- do it you wont regret it.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Place”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I (honeymooners) stayed at the Riu Palace for eight days. The place was unbelieveable. The grounds were immaculate. The workers worked so hard all day long even in the rain. They were constantly cleaning the tile floor just for it to get dirty again. Upon arrival, we were given a ground floor room. It had rained all day and for one reason or another the room was infested with what looked like flying ants. (We did not notice until at night). The room was cleaned immediately..sheets, etc. The same night as we were trying to sleep we could hear loud banging. Like stated previously they work all the time and had been doing some type of construction at 12pm. We also could hear the people walking on the top floor above us. The walls are very thin. We were told that there was no other room available so we stuck it out. We spoke with our Apple rep. the next day. We had a new room within two hrs. Definitely go with Apple!! Mario is great. He will make sure you are more than happy. We then got moved to the highest floor. It was great. No noise or bugs. The maid service was amazing. I am a neat freak and when I say the room was clean I mean it. The beach was great. More than enough chairs. Bring bug spray. I used it but still got some bites. The food was really good for a buffet. It was always different. There was something for even the most particular person. I must say be sure to bring Pepto. My stomach did give me some problems. I heard a lot of others say that they were a bit sick also. Once I took Pepto I was fine. The best part is the workers. They are awesome. The waitstaff/ bartenders are unbelieveable. They wait on you hand and foot. We tipped everyone. They all deserved it. We also found that if you tip you get better service. Remember a dollar to them goes a long way. Our expectations were met. We loved it. I was sad to say goodbye.

Reviews.Title: “Way Overbooked!!!”
Reviews.Author: RichAustinTX
Reviews.Content: Went with a group of 18 people. We had confirmed and fully paid reservations. We showed up at 1:30PM June 22, relatively early in the day for an arrival. Already the hotel was overbooked for the night. A wedding group of 42 was starting to check in at the same time and were told that they did not have rooms either. (A wedding that was supposed to be held at the hotel!!) We were all told we would be moved to Cancun for the night but there were still no guarentees of room availability the next night at the Riu Palace. The next morning the Riu Palalce still would not confirm reservations so we ended up spending our 3 nights in a sub-par Cancun hotel. Who knows how many poor souls showed up later in the day after us. Overall incrediable mismanagement.

Reviews.Title: “If you like the beach - this place is for you!”
Reviews.Author: jebria
Reviews.Content: My sister and I stayed at the RIU Palace Mexico June 14-19, 2005. We are beach lovers and, believe me, this beach is the very best. I was reading about comments about beach erosion - you can't win a battle with Nature. Of course there will be some erosion, but they work on the beach daily. If you have visited other beaches in the Riviera Maya, you will realize that this beach is Paradise. The color of the water is not to be believed. We met people who were world travelers--you name the beach and they were on it. They told us that the Palace is their favorite beach--in the world! This was our first trip to Mexico and I wasn't sure what to expect. The Mexican people are quite gracious and very helpful. We were never fearful--day or night. We even had a smooth transition through the Cancun airport and customs. The hotel and its entire staff were wonderful. The rooms were spacious and lovely--no foul odors. The grounds are beautiful--constantly being cleaned and spruced up. This is the best hotel for adults. Before dinner you can listen to the piano player in the beautiful hotel lobby and, after dinner you can listen to live music in the courtyard and enjoy tropical drinks. The fact that you can enjoy breakfast, lunch, drinks, dancing and shows at the other 3 RIUs within walking distance of the Palace is another plus. The town of Playa del Carmen is a 5 minute cab ride ($5) - don't miss this fun shopping experience. The Market Place across the street is also nice to visit. To sum up, you cannot beat the all-inclusive experience at the RIU Palace Mexico! Don't miss the opportunity to visit!

Reviews.Title: “The most gorgeous hotel in Mexico!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My Husband and I stayed at the Riu Palace for our 8 year anniversary June 5th-June 11th. From the time we arrived we were so pleased with our choice. The lobby and all areas of the hotel were very gorgeous! We have been to Mexico 7 times and this was the nicest hotel we have stayed at so far. We very much enjoy Cancun and the nightlife and the Marriott Casamagna and the JW are our top choices there however we have not ever stayed at the Rui hotels offered there. When we arrived at the Palace I did nothing but look around and feel I was in paradise. Our room was very nice and we lucked out and were given a courtyard room on the first floor which turned out to be very nice for gazing out into the courtyard in the evening before getting ready for dinner. The food was very good at Don Julian and we never made reservations for the alacart dining because we did not want to miss anything at the buffet and it was changed every night and had a different theme. We never watched the entertainment but it looked very good. If you want to watch the entertainment make sure to make your dinner seating for the 6:45 or you will not be able to get a seat for the shows. We took the 9:00 seating because we wanted to have a long beach day and thought that 6:45 would be too early for us but we should have thought about that because 9:00 was too late and we were really hungry by that time and then just wanted to turn in afterward. I really think they should have normal dinner times that people are used too such as 6:30 or 7:30, 6:45 and 9:00 are not average dining times. Also the beds are extremely HARD!!!! If you have a need for a soft bed insist on a bed topper. We had to be put on a list for one and were promised one our second day and still had to go to the front desk and call twice before one was put on for us. This was our only aggravation which was resolved and is to be expected at least once on a vacation anyway. We tipped the girl well that brought it for us and slept wonderful the rest of our week They made little towel animals for the bed which was very cute and a neat surprise to come back from the beach too. We took an Alourtnative tour called The Jungle Crossing which was a very neat experience. The ride on the Unimog through the jungle is very rough and the tour if definetly for the wild at heart. The tour also included ocean kayaking to a reef for snorkeling. You tied off your kayaks in the middle of the ocean and then jumped off. It was amazing! We then ate at a Mayan village and swam in 2 different places including a wonderful cenote that just blew us away by the beauty. Make sure to take sneakers with you for any tours, we did not and our feet took a beating! Make sure to take bug repellent! I used the Expedition by Avon Skin So Soft and it worked great without the harmful deet contaminates. Take insulated cups and they will fill them at the pool or beach bar. Your drink be it soda or beer will last a lot longer and the cups they give you are very small and only last a few sips and then your out and walking back again. That is about it. If you go it will not be a dissapointment. It is a beautiful, relaxing paradise. I actually got tears in my eyes when I had to leave which is unusual for me.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect Honeymoon!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We just returned from our honeymoon stay from June 6-13. This resort met all our expectations and more. We were warned ahead of time that the resort mostly attracted an older crowd. Although this is true there are lots of couples that honeymoon there that are in the 20's and 30's. We met wonderful friends durning the trip. The resort grounds are beautiful but some of the rooms have a horrible view. When we arrived they gave us a room facing the resort next door(which is under construction). This was a disaster because when we opended our balcony there were construction workers looking right back at us. We had to spend one night there but were soon moved to a room right on the front of the building facing the pool. This room was one of the best in the resort (room 128). I highly recommend that you ask to change if you are not happy, they are very accomadating. The food was great. There is something for everyone. We went on one tour, where we got to drive a 2 seater boats out to a coral reef and snorkel. This was so much fun! It was really resonably priced and worth it. My advice is to stay away from the snorkel people on the beach. They sell packages that include bananna boating, snorkelling and parasailing. It is dangerous and the snorkelling is a ripe off. Our friends did this and said they only followed a guide that had fish food and saw the same fish school for an hour. Lastly if you don't like to watch weddings the resort had about 14 in the week we were there. This did not bother me but it does mean lots of big groups of people. Overall I loved the resort and would reccomend it to anyone. The things I wrote are only to help not to complain it was a great place and worth the money.

Reviews.Title: “RIU Palace very good, not perfect”
Reviews.Author: bukowski
Reviews.Content: This is going to be long. I'll sum up here at the top so you don't have to wade through the whole thing if you don't want. Out of 5 stars, the RIU Palace scores 4.5 Service, 4 Food, 4 Room, 5 Beach, 4 Pool, 3.5 Entertainment, 5 Drinks, 3 Convenience of facilities, 4.5 Grounds, 3 Activities, 5 Staff. Fair warning: This report is downright ponderous at times. But there are a few nuggets in here that can help you in your plans for a Rivera Maya vacation. The USAir flights were very smooth – Boston to Charlotte, Charlotte to Cancun and hour later – so that we were right on schedule when we arrived in Mexico. We went through the check-in area very quickly, surprised at how easy it was, thinking that was customs. We were waiting for our bags by noon. That took a while, seeming longer I’m sure because we were impatient to get the vacation started. We finally got our bags and proceeded to the exit, then saw the actual customs area and laughed that we hadn’t realized that the previous checkpoint wasn’t the main one. But no problems, Sue pushed the button, it was green and when I went to do the same, the lady stopped me and just motioned for me to go along. I had read about the timeshare people so knew to be on the lookout for them, but I didn’t realize how sneaky and effective they would be. One guy in a uniform approached us near an official looking desk that I think said ‘Informacion’ and asked who we were with. We told him the name of the tour that was handling our transport to the RIU, and he swept us over to the desk. Now at this point, we’re thinking this might even be someone from our tour place, or someone who works for the airport. But he goes on to show us places on a map, and asks us questions – ‘Honeymoon or anniversary?’ – and shakes our hands in congratulations. We should’ve recognized the salesman spiel. A few minutes into him telling us where we were headed and how we would get there, he mentions The Spa Palace and how we should check it out and we’d get free tickets to Xel-ha, and it finally clicked for sure that this guy was one of the ones we’re supposed to avoid. I waited another minute for an opening in his selling pitch, said ‘No thanks’ firmly and pulled Sue away. We walked along toward the front of the airport, still unsure where we would find our transport, when another guy in a uniform pulled us aside. I quickly extricated us this time, and we made a break through the front doors, to sweet freedom and stifling heat. Sue noticed a ‘Best Day’ representative immediately, and we waited near him for about 15 minutes (and one $3.50 Sprite) before being escorted to our van. A guy insisted on taking our luggage on the short walk to the van. We gave him a buck, and he made sure the driver knew our destination – RIU Palace. We drove along the main highway for about a half-hour or so, then veered off to a smallish but nice resort and dropped off a couple. The driver pulled back out and told us RIU Palace was next. Ten minutes or so later we were there, and the few couples left on the bus said ‘Wow’ when they saw the entrance. It was kind of cool to think we would be staying at the best. The lobby was expansive and well appointed, with plush, red sitting pagodas, shining marble tile underfoot and somewhat garish chandeliers high above. The front desk was busy. We waited in line about 10 minutes before being helped by a smiling but distracted female employee. As she went through the wheres, whats and whens of the hotel, another worker brought us our welcome fruit drinks. A very pleasant welcome. As she finished her instructions, I mentioned that I had emailed a request ahead of time, and she asked another worker who seemed to be the boss. He smiled and said ‘yes, I know what you wanted, but I give you much better. You face the courtyard.’ When someone that I’m buying something from tells me ‘I give you something better than you ask for,’ my knee-jerk reaction is to think of the car salesman Eugene Levy played in ‘Vacation,’ when he tells Clark he doesn’t have the Arctic Blue Sports Sedan in stock, but instead he gets much better – the Family Truckster. So I laughed, said ‘much better, ok,’ and we were off to our room right away because it was already ready for us. We were going to take our bags, but a worker with his little luggage cart insisted that he take it for us. I forgot my welcome drink at the desk, and the woman called out to remind me to take it. I had done so much research beforehand that it actually detracted a little from the experience, because upon seeing the room, though I was excited, I wasn’t totally psyched because I had seen many pictures already. It was a great room, though. To address popular points: the beds are firm, but not too hard. Why they have two put together rather than one big one doesn’t make sense to me though. It was a little inconvenient. Hallway noise penetrates the walls, but hallway noise is infrequent. A really nice feature is the high ceilings with fan over the bed, giving it a chamber-like feel rather than just a room. The patio was also good-sized and a nice treat to sit out on and look down on the fountains directly below, or the main courtyard just to our right. That is, as long as the smoke fiends in the rooms surrounding us weren’t out sucking on their nicotine sticks. The shower was great, big, with plenty of room to move around and a strong, soothing stream. After unpacking, we put on our suits and hit the beach. The beach was expansive, palms everywhere, giving way to a wide swath of sand beyond and into the sea, which was hued in blue swatches, azure to sky blue and back again. The surf was strong but not overpowering. The extent of erosion was that the beach dropped suddenly about 8-10 inches right at the line of sea and sand, but it didn’t detract at all. We never had to work hard to find lounge chairs, either at beach or pool, despite the resort being crowded. The water was bath warm, clear to the sandy bottom and eye-stingingly salty. A man fed bread to a swarm of medium-sized fish in waist-deep surf and schools of minnows swept back and forth through the froth. I took a walk about 20 minutes south, past all the resorts, the last being the Gala, to where the forest still stands and the sand gets cluttered with refuse because there’s no cleaning crew patrolling undeveloped beach. Not sure why it remains undeveloped, but I hope it stays that way. I did some snorkeling from the beach there, almost nothing to see. I grabbed a few little shells, and swam through ubiquitous schools of minnows, but pretty boring. At a pile of rocks jutting into the sea, I sat for a bit to watch a pelican preening itself. I enjoyed our first meal – lunch at La Traviata, the open-air beachfront dining room – more than Sue did, but we were both happy with it overall. Plenty of choices, just that nothing was outstanding. I looked around for volleyball but couldn’t find a game to get into. I checked out the scuba shack to see when the earliest was that I could borrow fins, and found out they were only free of charge for one hour. Any longer cost $6, starting at 8 am. Dinner at Don Julian’s was pretty good, but Sue doesn’t like buffet as much, so we planned for me to get up early enough every day to make reservations at the a la carte restaurants (La Bodega, Sir Edwards, Miyagi’s, La Patio). I’d get to the little reservation desk everyday by about 7:15 AM or so, and already the early seatings were pretty much filled, so we ate at the 9 PM sittings mostly, which wasn’t bad because we prefer later meals anyway. With Sue being pregnant, this was not going to be a big party vacation. She didn’t have a single drink the entire trip, and I had just a few a day, except for the second night, when I had about 8 drinks over a few hours. They weren’t very strong. After our first dinner, we were still pretty tired from travel and just came back to the room, but caught some of the entertainment on the plaza and it didn’t seem like we were missing much. We did look at some of the wares the locals were selling on tables set up like a flea market around the plaza fountain. Our second day, I was determined to get in a volleyball game and saw on the activity board that there was a 3 pm match. I was up early to make the first sitting at La Bodega for that night, then did laps in the pool, which I had all to myself at that time, about 7:30 am. Breakfast was awesome, a huge selection and delicious, and I got to catch up on my ‘Walden’ while Sue slept back at the room (not a big breakfast person). After, I wandered around to take pics of the grounds, and checked out the RIU Tequila, a good-sized property. Though nice, it wasn’t quite up to the quality of the Palace. There were some feral cats wandering around which was cool to see. I wanted to make sure to show Sue later. The Tequila did have a good vibe, with a large, bustling open-air lobby. I noticed on their activities board -- which unlike the Palace’s, was large and in a conspicuous place, seemingly encouraging games and interaction among the guests, whereas Palace let that side go without fanfare – that there would be a tennis tournament on Friday evening, so I planned to take part in that. Sue and I hung out by the pool most of the day, finding a spot on the quieter side in some shade. We swam together, which we always enjoy doing. The water makes Sue silly. She likes to laugh in the pool, so I make stupid jokes and we pretend we’re professional dancers or secret lovers or something much more exciting than what we are. Of all the tremendously pleasant and accommodating workers we came across at the Palace, the towel girl, situated in a shack by the pool, was the nicest, always flashing a contagious smile and waving ‘hola.’ Sue liked her a lot. The volleyball was fun and competitive. A perfect mix of players, so that, while it certainly wasn’t pro level, we sustained good volleys and all put forth quite an effort. This taller German guy ended up on my team, and we played a few more games together in the ensuing days, along with Palace worker ‘King,’ who was a real wise-guy and a good player, and another Palace worker, who was a tall, mediocre player, about on par with me, who worked at night in the shows. Sue and I ended up taking lunch at La Patio, the beachfront restaurant that shared a building with La Traviata, for most of the days. Sue discovered the best guacamole she’s ever tasted, and ate that every day with fresh salsa and thick homemade nacho chips. Birds we identified as mocking birds, but don’t really know what they were – about the size and look of a small crow that issued so many different kinds of chirps and trills it seemed to imitate the sounds around it – were all around the grounds, and weren’t shy about sitting on the restaurant tables to snatch scraps. We also saw our first Agouti, a rodent-looking mammal about the size of a rabbit, with long hind legs and rat ears. Later, when we toured RIU Playacar, we saw a herd of them, like five or six, grazing on a lawn. Dinner that night at La Bodega was good. They brought meats in stages, slicing chunks from skewers right onto your plate, with a big dish of sides (spinach, mini potatoes, onion). We sat next to a nice mother/daughter from the Midwest. Sue enjoyed talking with them. She could identify with their relationship I think. After dinner, we had a couple drinks in the courtyard (the usual, mojitos) with Sue’s drink a virgin, which always required an explanation when the waiter gave a quizzical look or wry comment, like ‘why, who’s driving?’ The ambience at night is incredible. Home and its responsibilities fade away in the courtyard’s soft lights, cooling breeze, plentiful drinks, music (even if only so-so), and the din of blithe interactions of people from all over the world. The scene provides a perfect transition to bedtime, either as aphrodisiac or soporific. The next day I had a snorkeling trip to Akumal planned. Sue wasn’t up for off-site travel, so it was just going to be me. Plan was to rise early, eat breakfast, make dinner reservations (Miyagis) and grab a pair of fins just as the dive shop opened at 8 am. I got the fins and a woman at the shack took 10 minutes to explain to me the best way to get to Akumal. Just another example of the tremendously kind staff. With her advice, I was off to catch a taxi in front of the Palace, a reasonable quarenta pesos to the calle in Playa where you can pick up a collectivo. I enjoyed the ride into town, watching the locals chug and the occasional tourist trip along, past a small Maya ruins site and the Xaman-ha aviary, into the rough yet amicable and oft-speed-bumped streets of Playa del Carmen. I just missed the first collectivo to Tulum, but was first in line for the next, which came along in five minutes or so. A couple of U.S. ladies fell in behind me and I enjoyed eavesdropping on their conversation about their traveling experiences, mostly in Europe, on the cheap, living in hostels, eating authentic cuisine, things like that. We spoke a few words to each other on the bus trip since we were sitting right next to each other. As I saw the Akumal exit approaching, I told the driver, ‘Akumal por favor,’ and he pulled into a turnout. I handed him two twenties (pesos), not sure exactly how much the trip cost, and he asked it I was paying for anyone else. ‘No, solo mi.’ he handed me back one of the twenties. Very cheap transport. I knew from what the scuba shack lady told me that I had to cross the highway to get to the Akumal entrance. It was about a five minute walk from the highway to the arch proclaiming ‘Akumal,’ past a water purifying plant and the Akumal biblioteca, which was being tended to by a young woman who carefully swept its steps, dressed delicately in a sundress with a sweater folded around her shoulders. A feeling akin to envy at the beautiful simplicity of what her life must be like struck me. The reality probably was that her life was not simple at all, that she had as many everyday troubles as me. But why let reality get in the way of a tourist’s vantage point? At the archway, there was a hotel whose open-air lobby I passed through, and shops, a bank, some taxis, parking areas, and a flea-market style peddler’s row. A treed park gave way to the beach, where I was approached by a Mexican looking to give me a personal snorkeling tour. He promised to show me tortugas and all the best fish. I promised that, if on my own I didn’t see anything good, I would be coming back to him. It was still early enough that there were only a few people on the beach, which curved out far to my right as I faced the water. To my left, the beach came to an end as the shoreline became rocky and jutted out. Beyond that, where I could not see but was told, the beach picks up again around a bay known as Half-Moon. I wanted to get a feel for the place and maybe get some info from a local on the best entry point, so I ambled over to a beach-front restaurant just to my right and ordered a beer. Never too early para una cerveza en Mexico. The waiter told me he’d bring it to me so I took a seat in one of several wooden beach chairs situated along a low wall that separated the restaurant’s outdoor seating area from the beach proper. Relaxing there in anticipation – waiting for a beer, feeling the breeze-tempered sun, smelling the salted sea, hearing the muted excitability of a few hung-over tourists eating breakfast, wondering exactly what kind of exotic creatures I’d be seeing, and whether they’d include a majestic sea turtle – may have been the best four minutes of my vacation. Directly in front of the restaurant, close to shore and further off, many boats rocked on the waves. I assumed I’d be going off a little down the beach, away from the boats. When the waiter delivered my beer, I asked him about it -- first in broken Spanish before he switched, effortlessly (as was common among the locals) into English -- and he dismissed that notion, informing me that if I wanted to see turtles, then I should enter the water right where the boats were and swim out to just past where the furthest boat from shore was moored. Could I just leave my bag here in my chair? Of course, senor. I thanked and paid him, then sat back to imbibe the beer and ambience. I soaked it in for a while, then hit the bathroom, which was behind the inside seating area, past a little courtyard with outdoor showers. I don’t recall the name of the restaurant and I’m hoping this description will be enough to trigger someone familiar with the area to write me back with its name. I was primed for a great experience by the time I hit the water. I haven’t snorkeled much and was trepidatious at first as the sand became rock right at the water’s edge. But as soon as I was thigh-deep, I just fell to my belly and crawled my way along. Immediately I saw little fish. I swam past boats into deeper water, the sea floor dropping away, sand giving way to a bed of sea grass. The visibility was great, but not crystal clear. I saw a large, shadowy shape in the distance. It was too big to be anything but a rock, but I propelled myself toward it in curiosity. As I got closer, it took shape, my mouth drying and stomach leaping as it dawned on me that this ‘boulder’ was moving. No more than 15 feet below me was a gargantuan sea turtle, not bothered in the least by my clumsy splashing. He had a head the size of a pineapple, his beaked mouth lazily opening and closing on clumps of grass. Attached to its back was the biggest remora I’d ever seen, probably four feet long, but still shy of covering the shell’s diameter. I stayed with him for a while, occasionally raising my head above the water to make sure no boats were bearing down on me, before my excitement ebbed to an urge to see what else I could discover. In the two hours I spent there, I saw massive amounts of exotic fish – including a really cool-looking reed-shaped fish that was vertical instead of horizontal, and a large, long silvery bugger that darted off before I could get a good look at him, but that I suspect was a barracuda -- incredible coral formations, another turtle -- much smaller, and playful, leading me on a chase, continually rising to the surface four or five feet in front of me before diving again, leaving me in his vapor trail -- and one stingray, which glided through the grass in relatively shallow water as I made my way back in. I gathered my things from the restaurant chair and took the half-hour walk up the road to Half-Moon Bay. But I saw no turtles there, and the snorkeling was a relative disappointment. Set along the beach side of the road is a string of beautiful villas, with a few restaurants. Next time in Mexico, we’ll skip the all-inclusive resort and just rent a one-bedroom condo. It’s more satisfying here along the open road of Akumal than behind the gates of Playacar. Bikes outnumbered the cars. Lizards may have outnumbered the people. One lizard in particular was exciting to see, as it raced across the road ahead of me on two legs, its chest and stomach thrust out, perpendicular to the gravel, eyes skyward. Later, as I made my way back to 307, several iguanas sunned themselves in the rock-strewn courtyard of the library. The librarian was back inside. I spent a lot of the next day reflecting on the beauty of Akumal, and I felt the need to snorkel again, but didn’t want to leave Sue for as long a time it would take for another collectivo trip, so I went back south down the beach, past the first set of rocks to a bigger, second set. The snorkeling here is pretty good. Lots of big fish that like to stay close to the crags and their hiding places. Be careful not to let the surf smack you into the rocks. There’s nothing exceptional to see, but it did satiate my yen for snorkeling. Swimming around the first outcropping, I saw that it was just the start of an expanse of rocky shoreline. The water clarity becomes smoky here. I knew from trip research that that meant fresh water was entering the sea. I thought there may have been a cenote somewhere there, but wasn’t brave enough to dive in search for it, especially in the fuscous light of near-dusk. There was a fisherman casting deep into the ocean and I tried to explain how many big fish I was seeing right next to shore, but my English was gibberish in his German ears. Having had enough snorkeling, I decided to explore the rocks for tide pools. I didn’t find much interesting life in them, though. I walked along the intertidal shoreline for quite a while, not seeing much, then decided to make my way back, this time through a path on the edge of the forest. Here I saw five or six small lizards, which was almost worth the swarms of gnats that intermittently hung head-level along the path. It was getting closer to dark, so I hurried back north up the beach, pausing only to watch a small white crab – there were hundreds along the deserted beach – scuttle across the sand and down his hole, which seemed man-made in its perfect roundness. I’ll just finish up now with a few notable events that happened during the rest of out time at the Palace. First, the Michael Jackson show. Very entertaining. However, all the seats from which you can view the indoor shows are in smoking sections, which are dense with smoke from the heavy population of tobacco-happy Germans. Apparently, word that smoking is bad for you hasn’t reached Europe. Second, one night a very drunk man and a few others stayed in the courtyard until about 3 am being incredibly loud. Kept us up. I would think a Palace worker would’ve quieted him down. Third, I never got to do the tennis tournament because it poured for about two hours right when it was slated to happen. I think this was the only rain during the six days we were there. Other than a few small negatives, this was a great trip. The Palace grounds, workers, and beach are top-notch, while some other aspects, like food, bed, entertainment, and activities, didn’t quite measure up to the rest of the experience.

Reviews.Title: “Awsome Experience. Will go back”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Prior to booking my vacation, I read a lot of reviews on many resorts & was impressed with the number of positive reviews for the Palace. I was traveling with my wife & 2 daughters age 16 & 20. The 20 year old had her birthday there. Will key in on that later. Here's how the trip went: May 20th - May 27th. Arrival at the airport: Go on a friday if possible, the airport was empty, we flew through baggage & customs so fast, we were amazed! Checked in with the Apple rep & they had our transportation ready for us. I paid the premium for the private transfer, worth every penny. You go strait to the resort! Arrival at the resort: Manuel greeted us as we pulled up. He is the best! Always a smile on his face & I don't know how he does it, but he remembered our names! We were greeted at the desk with some fresh cold juice. Since we arrived at 10:30 am. (Yes 10:30! Less than 2 hours to get from the plane to the resort!) our rooms were not ready, no biggie, they escorted us to a room to get changed & freshed up, then we gave ourselves the nickel tour & sank right in! The lobby, grounds, pool & beach were constantly maintained & look as if they just cleaned it right before you showed up. I don't know how they do it, but every staff member makes eye contact with you & says "hola!" It's nice to be treated as if you are their friend. Not once did I see a disgruntled guest or staff member, nor did I ever experience any negativity from a staff member. Kudos to Jimmy & the anamation staff for really making things great. Go there & you'll find out. Be sure to go to Super Bingo @ 4:00. The restaurants were fabulous! I kind of regret not getting to Myagi's sooner. It was awsome. The buffet always had tons of fresh delicious entree's ready. The rooms were not musty. I'm not making this up here, it's as if they were keeping watch for when we left, because when we returned, BAM! Nice & fresh! Ask for a matress pad at checkin & you wont notice the firm beds. If the bed is still too hard, walk over to the liquor dispenser in the room & keep taking shots of tequila until is softens up. The only bad thing I can say about our stay was leaving. They really pamper you there. As for my daughters birthday,, they decorated the dinner table, came out & sang to her. Then, at the show that night, called her up on stage & the entire audience sang happy birthday to her. When she returned to her room, the room was all decorated with balloons & streamers, & the chambermaid made 2 animals & put them on her bed. THis was truly a value & time well spent! Feel free to contact me if you have any questions.

Reviews.Title: “Great honeymoon!!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Everything here was great! We stayed here the first week of June. The hotel was beautiful, employees were extremely friendly. The food was good and the variety was amazing. We ate mainly at the Don Julian. We did do the Sir Edward one night and loved it. However, there is no where to do laundry here unless you pay them to do it for it so be sure to pack lots of clothes. Also, you will need lots of casual-dressy clothes, since you have to dress up for dinner. Also, no iron in room. Bring snorkel and goggles for the ocean... it is so clear!! We wish we had brought ours! And bring bug spray... I spent the last couple days with bites all over my legs... not sure what it was from, either the bugs on the beach, or possibly bed bugs as another post refers to. Other than that, I cannot say enough good things about this resort and its staff. They truely do go out of their way to help you and exceeded all expectations.

Reviews.Title: “WOW! Never seen anything like this before”
Reviews.Author: uplandway
Reviews.Content: Arrived friday june 3rd. Booked through Gogo/Olympus Tours. We were at the resort within and hour of getting our luggage. The place was absolutely magnificent from the instant we stepped out of the fan. Whether it be the constant smiles or perfectly manicured grounds, this truly was the best vacation I have ever been on. Yes, the beds were a little hard. But we had bedpads within ten minutes of asking for them. The beds are made in the morning and then turned down in the evening. There are employees EVERYWHERE asking if they can get you anything. Unfortunately the drinks were not much to brag about, however the ones in the main lounge are were pretty good. The food at the buffets was decent. 3 out of 4. However, the resort truly shined with its gourmet dinners. Do youself a favor and eat at a gourmet restaurant as much as possible. You need to get up at 7 to reserve a table, but it is worth every ounce of sleep you miss. (Besides, you can just take a nap on one of the hammocks under the palm trea) Each dinner, eaten outside the resort, would have easily cost over $100 (American). Champagne, four course meal...INCREDIBLE. The thing that made this resort shine was its attention to detail. A new specialty trink in the courtyard before dinner, roaming cheese card after dinner, greeting line at every meal, and nonstop kindness. The beach and pool were great and there were always plenty of lounge chairs to choose from. If you read any complaints about this resort, I assure you they were superficial. Do yourself a favor and stay at Riu Palace in Playacar for as long as possible. You won't regret it.

Reviews.Title: “5 star for Mexican standards”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Stayed late May. Beach was awesome, enough loungers everywhere. Pool was warm but enough loungers there, as well. Grounds are beautiful. Food at Buffets, very good. Ala carte restaurants weren't worth it. Rooms were definetely musty, and many ants around the bathroom sink. Also, some sort of bed bugs possibly because we woke up with bites on two mornings.... For Mexican standards this is a 5 star, however the rooms were not. In America if you are used to going to 5 star hotels, realize this is not. If you have that known before you go, you will be just fine. It's worth it for the all inclusive.

Reviews.Title: “Best Beach and Grounds!!”
Reviews.Author: JaimeGV
Reviews.Content: Everyone who writes about how they love the Riu Palace is right! It was beautiful, clean, well-staffed, good food, etc...I found the reviews very helpful in making my decision to stay, but it would have been helpful to hear a little more about the grounds. I am a beach lover, and with the hurricanes hitting many hotels in playa last year, it was a concern of mine. The Riu certainly did not dissapoint! The pool was great, but if you wanted a little more breeze and some sand, the beach was wonderful. LOTS of room, never a problem finding a chair with shade or without...whatever you wanted, there was enough room for everyone and didn't have to get there early. Grounds were stunning, beach is better than anywhere I have stayed in playa so far. Only downfall - the reservation thing is a bit of a pain. Oh well, still totally worth it!!

Reviews.Title: “Absolute Paradise”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the RIU Palace Mexico May 14 - 21. This was our second trip to this resort and it will not be our last (our first trip was for two weeks in September 2004). From the moment we walked in the front doors of the Palace we were treated like royalty. Our first trip in September 2004 was fantastic and our recent trip was even better. Both my husband and I thought the customer service had improved (and it was fantastic to begin with). Several of the employees recognized us and said 'welcome home'. We requested the same waiter in the Don Julian restaurant and our request was granted. On our first night and again the morning of our last breakfast our table was decorated with beautiful flowers. I can't say enough good things about the RIU Palace. This place is top notch. We are already planning a third trip to what has become our favourite get-a-way spot. I will make one recommendation, bring the bug spray!! I had several bites on my legs from the little pests. No doubt they were attracted to my moisturizer as my husband didn't get bitten at all. Have fun!!

Reviews.Title: “Great overall value”
Reviews.Author: BigRico
Reviews.Content: We've just returned from 8 days at the Palace, May 20th through May 28th, and had a great, relaxing time. I'll try to give you the quick but specific run-down as we saw it. FOOD: (first things first) The buffets were great for all three meals. Great selection and quality. Not Bellagio style buffets, but more Flamingo Hilton style, if you are familar with Vegas. We ate at both La Bodega and Sir Edward, La Bodega was very good but I would beg to differ with the glowing reviews of Sir Edward. Being that it is billed as a "gourmet" restaurant, we expected a great meal and were terribly let down. Nice room and great service, but the food was seriously lacking. If you truly want a gourmet experience, take a cab to PDC and go to Ajua!, those guys rip (this is coming from former cook and Southern Californian who knows Mexican food). DRINKS: They were great, also had top shelf stuff if you ask for it (why drink the regular beer when you can have Negra Modelo?). Always found the mini-bar restocked upon our return. And, there are plenty of bars throughout the resort. POOL: Ok for me , a bit warm for the end of May, also a little small (my girlfriend thought it was perfect) but we were always able to find a lounger. And, fairly frequent bar service. BEACH: Great. Great water (my girlfriend thought it was a bit murky) great sand, great palm trees for shade and great hammocks. We were, again, always able to find a hammock or beach chair without any issue and without going down there at 8:00a to save one. ROOM: A little musty, but roomy with a great balcony. We lucked out and got a room with a courtyard view. The beds were pretty funny (2 fulls pushed together) and hard, but really no big deal. We did find ants and several other bugs in the room, which we found odd for such a nice property, and it's not like we left Jolly Ranchers on the counter.... Housekeeping did constantly throw my girlfriend's clothes on the floor when they cleaned, which was not cool. GROUNDS: Beautiful, immaculate, and always being tended to by the staff. Great lobby, really striking, just like you would expect in a grand hotel. Bar Cubano was very very nice as well. STAFF: They were all great, some remembered your drink order from 3 days prior, ergo my Mr. Johnny Walker monicker. Manuel was always at the front door and always friendly. I can't believe the lack of tipping we saw. Please understand that you have paid for the room, food and drinks but not the service. DO BRING PLENTLY OF ONES !!!! There was nothing worse than ordering your third drink and only having a pocket of $20s. OVERALL: I think we'd give it a 4-star rating, and qualify any 5-star ratings by saying that it is only 5-star by Mexican standards. The room (bugs and cleaning service) and Sir Edward were our only real disappointments, but again, beautiful property, great service, idillic beach and great food at the buffets. Plan your trip accordingly: If you are used to dry air, don't go between May and August. It was really hot and humid. Make sure you go into PDC, lots of fun at night with colorful shops and restaurants. Don't waste your time in Cozumel (Tiujuana east). The only nice beach is Playa Bonito and you have to rent a jeep to get that far south on the island, the rest of the beaches have guys hawking their wares .. and who needs another Monkey on a Surfboard statue?

Reviews.Title: “Vacation in Paradise”
Reviews.Author: lds0508
Reviews.Content: We just returned from a week at the Riu Palace Mexico 5/7-5/14. This was the best relaxing vacation we have ever had. From the moment you arrive at this resort, you are treated like royalty. Starting with Manuel, the doorman shaking your hand and welcoming you to Paradise and ending with tropical flowers strewn across your dinner table at Don Julian's in honor of your last night's dinner. The hotel is absolutely beautiful and meticulously clean. The lobby is all marble with crystal chandeliers, dark woods in the Cubano Lobby Bar, tile and wrought iron in the courtyard Los Mariachis bar with gazebo. The rooms were spacious and clean, fridge stocked fully, nightly turn down service. The entire center of the resort is palm trees and fountains, where you will be hard-pressed to find a fallen leaf, as the staff is out there cleaning constantly. The pools were the perfect temperature and the pool bar service was great. The Riu Palace has probably the best beach in Playacar. Plenty of palm trees for shade and still a large amount of beach in an area hit hard by erosion. We had no trouble finding lounge chairs at the pool or the beach at any time of the day. The food at the Riu is very good. Don Julian's, the buffet, has so much to offer that there has to be something for everyone. Breakfast was phenomenal with everything from eggs to french toast, all types of fruit, breads, etc. The coffee does leave something to be desired, so be proactive and order a cappuccino or double espresso instead! We only ate at one of the ala carte restaurants, Sir Edwards, and the food and service were very good. Getting reservations each day is not at all difficult, but we enjoyed the variety of the buffet so much and chatting with new friends at neighboring tables that we ate dinner there. Lunch at El Patio or La Traviata offers a good variety of buffet items and desserts, along with self-serve ice cream. The most outstanding thing about this resort is the service. The waiters, bartenders, animation team, and front desk personnel could not have done more for us to ensure that we thoroughly enjoyed our stay. Everyone has an "Hola" when you pass by and is more than happy to fulfill your requests. We asked for a mattress pad, as the beds are firm, and it was on the bed by the time we returned to our room the first day. The bar personnel do an awesome job of making sure your glass is never empty, your ashtray is clean and even replace your coaster under your glass if wet. The animation team runs activities all day long, and it is fun to join in and get to know these great young people, many of whom are multilingual. They also put on shows at night several times a week and work quite hard at keeping you entertained. Other evening entertainment included dance shows and a magic show. They were all good. Each night a band plays dance music in the gazebo from dinner until 10:00 pm when the show starts. Before our trip, I read every review I could find on the Riu Palace. Let me assure you, you cannot go wrong at this resort. They go above and beyond in every aspect. We are already planning a return trip as we had one of the best vacations ever. As they say at the Riu, this trip was Muy Excelente!

Reviews.Title: “It is a Palace!!!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My wife and I asked my brother and his wife to come with us to Playa del Carmen as we usually travel to Cabo and wanted to try something new. Some research was done and the Riu Palace seemed the perfect fit and came highly recommended by Trip Advisor reviewers.We were not disappointed. The place is as immaculate as they write about. Every morning and throughout the day a throng of staff was polishing, mopping and doing paint touch ups. The staff was friendly and though ever visible were non-intrusive. They always seemed to put down what they were doing to help carry bags or greet us or see if there was anything we needed.The beach is first rate with hammocks a plenty and beach chairs (some in the sun,some under palm trees) all over. The beach is amazing and the water a breathtaking turquoise. Be prepared to see European style sunbathing, which was very subtle and tasteful but just know ahead that your children may have some questions. It was also fun to explore the other Riu premises open to Riu Palace guests. Each has its own atmosphere. The Palace is more elegant and low key. Several weddings took place during our stay. The Playacar is more kid friendly and has a "happening swimup bar" where the guests can feel comfortable to be a bit more jovial and "let their hair down." The Tequila also seemed a better choice for children and teens with a more casual element. The Yucatan was closed for remodeling. There are many activities available right from the immediate beach area and they are reasonably priced. We were able to do a snorkle and parasail package for just $58 per person. The service was superior to any we have had during our previous 4 all-iclusive vacations(and we thought those vacations were great) The rooms were well stocked- no second rate liquor here-the in room bars have Smirnoff, Bacardi, Jose Cuervo etc as well as mixers, sodas and tonic waters. Also plenty of bottled water. We never had to ask for any items to be restocked....the minibar items were replaced constantly. The restaurants we tried provided excellent food and service. We ate at Don Julian's most frequently. There is a great variety offered for all meals. The only thing we missed a little was finer wines, but the Mexican wine offered was OK and flowed freely. At breakfast, there were eggs prepared in every style imaginable, several meats and many freshly squeezed juices plus excellent espresso in addition to coffee and buckets of champagne to make our own mimosas. The dress code for men's evening attire demands long pants, so be sure to pack a few pair....we wish the hotel would consider dress shorts for men (ie Dockers) because it is quite warm in the evenings and the dress for women was very lenient. The only other thing that was a little bit difficult was making sure we had dinner reservations each night...they need to be made early and there were times when our excursions took us out earlier than the reservation desk opened. If there were one casual restaurant that could be available without dinner reservations, it would beneficial. There was nightly entertainment and we especially enjoyed the talented dancers. The excursions we arranged were done right at the hotel at the Sun Trips desk. Monique, the Sun Trips representative, was very helpful and informative. We chose to go to Tulum/XelHa for one day and it was a great combination. Our favorite though was a full day adventure to Chichen Itza. It does take a few hours to get there, but the bus ride was comfortable and the guide entertaining and knowledgable...all was highly organized; we were well cared for with beverages and food, too. The stop at a cenote for a quick swim was welcome and beautiful...we did give our input on the tour survey that more time could have been allowed at the Cenote and the brief shopping stop omitted (the things you could buy at this stop were no different than all the stuff you could buy in the hotel or other Playa del Carmen shops) The ruins were amazing. We could not believe how up close we were allowed to experience them and touch them, etc. We learned from more than one tour personnel that the pyramid is very likely to be restricted from climbing after this year....so if it is something you have always wanted to do, you may want to consider it as soon as possible. There was an abundance of shopping on 5th Avenue only a few minutes cab ride away from the Palace (be prepared for assertive sales approach), but it was good to discover that taxi fairs have been regulated so it only costs $4-$5 dollars one way per taxiload (not per person). We could go on and on, but in summary, we loved our vacation and highly recommend the Riu Palace.

Reviews.Title: “Greatest all-inclusive I have ever experienced!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I highly recommend this hotel to anyone who wishes to experience total relaxation without any worries about quality, luxury, cleanliness, and class. This hotel was unlike other all-inclusives where I have stayed. For one, the grounds and room were spotless. Two, the food was of five-star quality. Extremely varied and of North American, five-star cosmopolitan standard (i.e. Montreal, New York, Los Angeles). The Mexican food, of course, was especially delightful. I wish to highlight the many "special touches" that made this place one to remember for my boyfriend and I: - the spacious beach with many symmetrically planted palm trees that offer shaded areas (including hammocks) far from the busy, motorized beach sports; - the amazing buffets for all meals and high quality a-la-carte and steak house restaurants; - the many activities available near the hotel (at walking distance or short $5 cab ride away); - the convenient and well-stocked mini bar in the room; - the roomy bathroom (excellent marble shower) with even a bidet; - the served drinks (with a photo-menu) that are never watered down. Some tips that made the trip even more enjoyable for us: We never bothered spending the money for the tours and travelled using first-class buses leaving from the main bus terminal in Playa Del Carmen. This way, you can travel for $3 (Tulum) to $10 (Chichen Iza) safely, with air conditioning and DVD movies. Much cheaper than the $75 tours being offered at the hotel. Even paying for entry fees and lunch, we were never out more than $25 per person for a whole day trip. Other tip: the nightlife in Playa Del Carmen is worth exploring, especially the firedancers at 11PM at The Blue Parrot. But, watch drink prices. In one "high scale" roof-top bar [forgot the name unfortunately] we were charged US$10 for one margarita! Another tip for ScubaDivers, the hotel scubadiving was much too expensive for us so we explored dive shops in the town. My boyfriend negotiated a $30 per dive rate, instead of the $65 per dive offered at the hotel, and enjoyed 15 dives, including 2 cenotes and 1 Cozumel (we had to get there ourselves with the ferry though). The only disadvantage is getting to town for each dive yourself, but it's only a short 20 minute walk on the beach and very relaxing in the early morning. You are also less bothered with crowded expeditions filled with less experienced divers. One last tip: bring enough suntan lotion, because one small bottle runs you $15 in the town. So overall, while Playa Del Carmen is more pricey than other Carribean destinations such as Cuba, it was well worth the extra money if you account for the fantastic service and food/drink quality, and the many activities nearby. I was never so sad to return home from a vacation. Did not miss my own bed at all. I even miss the little "serengue" that hang around the hotel grounds (look like a mix of groundhog and squirrel without the tail!). Oh yeah, and I never saw one fly, mosquito or ant anywhere and I have a big, bug phobia! Have a great time at the Riu Palace -- we certainly hope to return at Christmas. And hi and big thanks to Sherry and Chris for the laughs!

Reviews.Title: “Best Resort in Playacar”
Reviews.Author: North_Shore
Reviews.Content: Visited mid-May, 2005. Would stay again w/o even thinking about it. Paid $129 per person, per night for hotel stay. Service unbelievable - smiles everywhere all the time! All aspects of staff - cleaning, bar, food, guest-services were excellent. Hotel manager Ernesto has this place in perfect condition - employee morale was fantastic. Food was very, very good. (Would say 'excellent' but respectful of food snobs) Wine is $5 a bottle but very drinkable. Calafia from Baja & a Portuguese Liquor not tippy-top shelf but very close - just ask for Bacardi, Jose Cuervo, Finlandia, etc. Beer was Corona or Modelo. ROH rooms are very, very nice - spacious, sparkling clean. Two full-sized beds pushed together are firm & comfortable. In-room bar stocked with top-shelf liquor. Fridge constantly stocked with water, Pepsi, Pepsi light, 7-up, orange pop & mixer. Plenty of closet space & drawers. Grounds are immaculate & gorgeous. Courtyard tile polished 2x a week, cleaned daily. Landscaping outstanding. Pool is perfect - I mean perfect. Split into two, one side is for the "whoo-hoo!" crowd playing volleyball, includes the gorgeous swim-up bar Las Conchas. The other side of the pool is quiet & calm. Kiddy pool, too. Hot tub was closed for remodeling. Work out facility very, very nice. Free weights galore, three treadmills, two bikes IIRC, universal machine, leg machine, etc. Beach was the best in Playacar - both the public portion & the guest-only area. The guest-only part was by far the best - we walked all up & down Playacar to confirm this. Hammocks everywhere surrounded by pristine sand and shady palms. Clientele 75% non-USA. Either Canadians or Western Europeans (predominantly German). If you are sensitive to cigarette smoke & men in tight bathing suits you will have a hard time here. Apparently the smoking-is-harmful message has not gotten out everywhere! Clientele for the most part was upscale. Age range approximately: 98% over 30 years old. 60% over 50 years old. Could count the children on two hands, teens on one. Average age appeared to be 44.3 ;) Restaurants: Don Julian was great for breakfast & dinner Miyagi was great Sir Edward was great - be sure to dress up! Service / decor is very fancy. El Patio was great for lunch, just OK for dinner La Traviata was great for lunch & snack Did not try La Bodega (traveled with a vegetarian) Negatives - Coffee served at breakfast was not potable.

Reviews.Title: “Paradise . . . almost”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband I went the first week of May for 8 days for our 25th wedding anniversary. We were treated like a king and queen. The hotel was beautiful, clean, friendly and helpful people and wonderful service. We experienced only one bad thing, which was that the beds and pillows were very hard and uncomfortable; we both have bad backs. The food was wonderful. You did have to book your dinner in the morning, but that wasn't a big deal. It might have been for people with children. We slept late and still got some bookings for dinner. The beach is beautiful and clean as well as the pool. Bar service is everywhere. No problems with pool or beach chairs at all. A lot of palm trees to enable you to get out of the sun. Bring your own glasses for the bars at the beach and pool; they will fill them up!!!! Went to town twice and never felt uncomfortable. Nice little shopping plaza just a few blocks down from the hotel, however, you can barter in Playa del Carmen. If you read complaints, I don't know what people expect unless they are royalty. How about some Heavenly Beds like the Westins?

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful almost perfection”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We just got back the other day from our honeymoon at the Riu Palace and I must say it was beautiful! I won't go into all the good things as they have already been mentioned. I'll just say what is true and that is it is stunning. We walked to the other RIU hotels and they were not even close to being as spectacular. The beach and pool were excellent and the food was great. I really have to hand it to them, the food was really well done. I was expecting average food for an all inclusive resort but it was really great. I recommend trying all the restaurants. Our favorites were La Bodega and the Japanese place. The rest however were top notch. The service was excellent also and everyone was very friendly. Now I only have a couple complaints. One was the disco next door. at anothere resort. If you are in one of the rooms on the outer part of the right side (right if you are facing the beach) you will know what I mean. Every night at 11PM until 2AM the music booms. I don't know what the other reviewer was talking about it not being that bad but it was loud. We were closer to the middle so maybe we were closer. The first night I asked for another room but it was fully booked. With the door closed you can still hear the thumping beat. To me this is not acceptable for a 4 star resort. For the money you pay and the older clientle it was unexpected. The bad part is it is a totally different resort (Wyndam Resorts I think?) and there isn't much RIU can do about it. They should however complain. So if you can get a courtyard room grab it as soon as possible. If not then you will get used to it and by the middle of your trip you will get used to it. Though you should not have to on you vacation. The only other complaint was the checkout time we got which was 12 NOON. Our shuttle for our plane left at 5PM so we were a little limited. They couldn't give us a later check-out time becasue they really needed the rooms (they say). However they do put your bags into the room and provide a place to change if you need to. Now don't let those two complaints deter you from going. Just be aware that no hotel is perfect. The RIU Palace comes close though. That being said I would stay there again in a heartbeat. I would just make sure to get a courtyard room and plan my checkout day. A 4 and half star resort for sure!

Reviews.Title: “Surreal, Unbelievable, like a dream”
Reviews.Author: nayzee
Reviews.Content: Absolutely Unreal!! Riu Palace is an excellent resort, way-way more than expected. 6 family members altogether (no children). We had the time of our lives. I would recommend this resort to any one who wants to have a laid back, beautiful time. Staff were awesome/food great/Atmosphere unbelievable. I felt totally pampered. Upon arrival the man taking our suit cases said to me, "Welcome to Paradise". It did not take me long to get it.We stayed for 1 week May 3-10th and it was not long enough. I could just ramble on and on. To anyone considering staying here you will not be disappointed. We plan on returning for a week in February and taking our children. The only complaint I have read here and agree with is that the beds are hard. It is true the beds are hard-but-I had no problem sleeping at all and was such a minor thing I do not even want to mention it. I have read complaints about the food getting boring?HA there is such a huge selection for every taste at every meal (buffet) We did try a few of the gourmet restuarants but to tell the truth I was very satisfied with the buffets. Did I mention the service was awesome!! All I can say is GO and you will NOT reget it! I consider it a vacation of a life time.

Reviews.Title: “Riu Rocks!”
Reviews.Author: Revelstoke
Reviews.Content: This place was fantastic! We would stay here again in a heartbeat (my wife and I came for our 10th anniversary and we wanted something nice and relaxing)...This is it...(If you're into the party scene - you can just head across the street to the Riu Tequila in the evenings - the action takes place there...You can use the facilities (bars, disco, etc) at the Tequila, Yucatan et al. but they can't use yours!) The layout of the beach is fab, with lots of palm trees for shade - which is good for a red headed Canadian like myself. No need to save your beach lounge chairs at the crack of dawn either (like at the Riu Yucatan) because there is a plethora to choose from any time of the day...(take a stroll down past the resorts to the rock overhang (only about a 15 min. walk - opposite direction to Playa del Carmen) for some nice peaceful snorkeling (lots of fish too!). The staff will bend over backwards for you at the palace, they are always friendly and helpful...they won't hesitate to move you to another room if you aren't satisfied.... The food was great, the buffet had huge selection of freshly prepared, tasty treats that would suit even the fussiest eaters. To get away from the crowds in the evening - go upstairs in the Cubana bar (the piano bar) no one sits up top, you'll have the whole place to yourself! (it was pretty funny watching all the Russians sitting around the piano singing '50's show tunes) There is an adaquate excercise facility as well on site, with universal gym, bikes, treadmills etc. to burn off some of the calories you'll be packin' on. If you are looking for a beautiful, relaxing spot, (great service included), for the $ the Riu Palace Mexico rocks....

Reviews.Title: “Best Hotel in Playa”
Reviews.Author: steljor
Reviews.Content: We just come from our 5 times stay in the Riu Palace and ever time we go is better and better ,the new manager is excellent, and the staff is the most friendly people we ever encounter in a hotel. Food is outstanding, everything is very clean, and the beach paradisiac.

Reviews.Title: “Palace more than expected!”
Reviews.Author: PAlovestotravel
Reviews.Content: My friend and I stayed at the palace from May 1 - May 8. Although I had read alot of reviews on the palace - I was not prepared for the beauty of this hotel and it's beach. Our biggest problem occurred with the first room they put us in - it faced the Riu Yucatan. Our travel agent called and asked if it would be noisy and he was assured we would not hear anything = wrong!!! The construction starts at 7am and continues to 6pm. They are putting in another pool, repairing roofs, and the noise was generated by a jackhammer and what sounded like a nailing gun. It could be heard in our room. We asked to change rooms, and had to wait a day to switch to a room that faced the Wyndham. They are also making repairs, but the noise was not that noticeble and it only lasted a few days. That side of the hotel also faces the Wydham disco/club area and you could hear music, but not overbearing. The food was outstatnding, and we tried most of the restaurants. Most impressive was Sir Edwards. We liked the buffet, and probably could have eaten there each nite - Chef's night was the best - Beef Wellington, shrimp, salmon. All excellent. They do not serve cocktails at the restraunts, but you can get beer or wine. Seom folks stop at the bar and bring a drink in with them. We did take huge insulated mugs, and that worked out perfectly for us. No complaints when we asked for drinks in them. We ate at the steak house and it was very good. They do run a tight schedule with reservations - we arrived at the steak house at 715 - got our meal at 820 - and were then prompted that we had 5 minutes left at 840 as the next seating was coming. We stayed a few minutes longer for dessert and then left. Our second room was beautiful, very clean - I was amazed to see the housekeepers scrubbing the balcony area with a scrub brush. The entire resort is cleaned thoroughly every day. We did ask if we could switch to a courtyard room, but were told it is $60 extra per day. The reservation sytem is a pain, but I got up early two days to make reservations. The beds are hard, so ask for the mattress pads when you check in - we did that with both rooms and they quickly came and remade the bed. This hotel is beautiful - but more importantly is the attitude of the staff. They work extemely hard to make you happy and they are always smiling and greeting everyone with a Hola! My friend and I both agreed that this was the best place that we have ever stayed at and we can't wait to return. The beach was perfect, and there was no need to "put a towel down" - we always found lounge chairs and just put them where we wanted them. Other information - taxi's to Playa are $5. And worth it if you are going in the day and don't want to contend with the heat. (90's) The 5th avenue area is a great place to visit and has many shops and stands and clubs. We never felt unsafe the entire time in Playa. And the palace will not allow anyone in without the Riu wrist band. This is a remarkable place, and you will feel like you found paradise.

Reviews.Title: “Dream Vacation!”
Reviews.Author: megw2
Reviews.Content: My husband and I spent our Honeymoon at the Riu Palace: April 20th through the 26th. I will say that prior to my trip I read just about every review of this hotel listed on this site and on the forum here. I learned one thing: Some people will never be happy. We honestly can’t find one thing to complain about. We arrived at the hotel around noon on Wednesday. We were blown away by the lobby alone. The resort is gorgeous, and immaculate. You can tell that a lot of work goes into keeping the grounds so clean. We were greeted with a welcome drink at the front desk and told our room wouldn’t be ready until 3:00. They took our luggage for us and we walked around the resort a bit and ate at lunch Don Julian’s. We went back to the desk at 2:00 and were given room 1041. The rooms are very spacious. You walk into a hallway with the bathroom off of it. Then through another doorway is the sleeping area. There is a sitting area with couch, table, television and dresser just beyond the sleeping are. The balcony is just beyond that. There wasn’t much of a view but we had a private balcony with high walls. The rooms were big and spacious with plenty of closet space. The hallways are tile so footsteps outside the room do carry. We shut the interior door to the room every night when we went to sleep and couldn’t hear a thing. We did get towel animals on 4 days of the trip…they were very cute. But towel animals won’t make or break a vacation. I would stay here even if there were NO towel animals. The nightly turn down service was nice. In addition to turning down your bed that actually bring fresh towels (for the 2nd time that day) and take out your trash. The room fridge was stocked with water, soda and Corona. And the cabinet contained dispensers of Jose Cuervo, Bacardi, Absolut and some kind of Brandy. We actually didn’t use any of the liquor provided in the room. We drank at the bars around the resort. Our favorite bar was La Cubana: we enjoyed a few drinks there while listening to the pianist every night before dinner. I cannot say enough about the staff at this hotel.
